translated_text:
M
More than 400 mercenaries from the Wagner group, a private armed militia of Russian origin, are in Kiev with direct orders from the Russian regime to kill Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky and Ukraine's rulers.
The news is released this Monday by the British newspaper
The Times
, which points out that the mercenaries traveled from Africa, with the promise of a considerable financial bonus.
O
Wagner group
has gained notoriety in recent years, especially for its military actions in Africa. The militia is responsible for protecting oil companies and Russian interests in Cabo Delgado (Mozambique),
in Mali
, in Zambia, in
Central African Republic
, among other countries, often clashing with Islamic extremists and local forces.
Recently, the
Mali's provisional government rejected European forces
led by France and Denmark to support the country in fighting local jihadists,
preferring services
of the Wagner group mercenaries.
Moscow continues to deny any formal relationship with the militia, despite the affinity between Putin and the group's oligarch owner, Yevgeny Prigozhin. The official services provided by the Wagner group are maintenance and military training.
The news comes at a time when Ukrainian and Russian authorities
will gather on the border with Belarus
to try to negotiate a peace agreement.
According to The Times, the mercenaries traveled to Kiev on Saturday and the Ukrainian government reacted immediately, imposing a stricter curfew to guard the city against Kremlin saboteurs.
The Russian invasion of Ukraine enters its fifth day this Monday, having killed more than 350 Ukrainian civilians so far.

Ukraine presented
complaint against Russia
at the International Court of Justice, accusing Vladimir Putin's regime of planning a genocide.

translated_text:
Home
War in Ukraine
Switzerland applies European Union sanctions on Russia
Usually neutral, Switzerland will freeze assets on Kremlin leaders and reaffirm solidarity with Ukraine.
Protests in the Swiss city of Bern against the invasion of Ukraine by Russian troops.
¬©¬†EPA/SALVATORE DI NOLFI
Diogo Ferreira Nunes
28¬†February,¬†2022¬†‚Ä¢¬†14:11
Share
this article
Facebook
Twitter
WhatsApp
Email
Share
Comment
Historic decision in Switzerland: the local government announced that it will apply European Union sanctions on Russia. The decision was announced this Monday by the Federal Council of the country that is usually neutral in war matters, according to Reuters.
Switzerland will freeze, with immediate effect, the assets of Russia's top leaders: President Vladimir Putin, Prime Minister Mikhail Mishustin and Foreign Minister Sergey Lavrov.
"By taking this decision, Switzerland is responding to the serious violations of international law for which these assets are responsible", explains the statement from the Federal Council.
Local authorities also announced the ban on commercial relations with the Donetsk and Luhansk regions, which are no longer under the jurisdiction of the Ukrainian Government. The measure has been applied since 2014 in relation to the Crimea and Sevastopol regions.
Close
Subscribe to newsletter
Subscribe to our newsletter and have the news in your email every day
Subscribe
Thank you very much for your registration.
The 2009 agreement to facilitate the granting of visas to Russian citizens, with the exception of diplomatic personnel, was also suspended.
Swiss airspace will also be closed to flights from Russia from Monday afternoon, with the exception of connections for diplomatic, medical or diplomatic purposes.
Switzerland announced that it will deliver 25 tons of supplies to Warsaw, to help the Ukrainian population heading to the Polish capital and other border countries.
Switzerland joins the countries of the European Union, the United Kingdom, the United States, Canada, Japan and Australia on the list of nations that are imposing restrictive measures on Russian leaders following the invasion of Ukraine, which began in the early hours of Thursday.

translated_text:
Home
International
Putin demands recognition of Crimea, denazification and neutral status of Ukraine
The Russian president explained to his French counterpart the prerequisites for any agreement to put an end to the invasion of Ukraine.
¬©¬†EPA/SERGEY DOLZHENKO
DN/AFP
28¬†February¬†2022¬†‚Äî¬†17:03
Facebook
Twitter
Comment
Share
Topics
War in Ukraine
International
Russia
Vladimir Putin
Related
international
Ukraine. Membership of the European Union? "We have to deal with more practical things"
minister of defense
Cravinho says that Putin and his regime underestimated the EU's ability to unite
Russian President Vladimir Putin declared this Monday to his French counterpart, Emmanuel Macron, that he demands the recognition of Crimea as Russian territory, as well as the "denazification" of the Ukrainian government and a "neutral status" for Kiev, as conditions for the end of the invasion of Ukraine.
Putin demanded
"the recognition of Russian sovereignty over Crimea, the end of demilitarization and denazification of the Ukrainian state and the guarantee of its neutral status"
as prerequisites for any agreement, the Kremlin said in a statement released after their telephone conversation.
Macron asked the Russian president to spare civilians and civil infrastructure in Ukraine, as well as some of the main Ukrainian roads, during a 90-minute telephone conversation between the two, the French leader's office said in a statement.
Close
Subscribe to newsletters
News Diary
and receive information first hand.
Subscribe
"President Putin confirmed his willingness to make commitments on these three points," the statement said.
Macron too
"reiterated the international community's demand to halt the Russian offensive against Ukraine and reaffirmed the need to implement an immediate ceasefire"
, said Elisha.
The French president also asked Putin to respect international humanitarian law and allow aid shipments to reach the population.
This phone call was the latest in a series of conversations between the two leaders, in which Macron initially sought to prevent the Russian invasion and then limit its damage.
Earlier this month, Macron went to Moscow to speak personally with Putin, having returned to Paris with assurances of what he called "Putin's desire to maintain the stability and territorial integrity of Ukraine."
After Monday's conversation, Macron suggested that the two leaders remain in contact in the coming days "to avoid a worsening of the situation", something that Putin agreed with.
In the last few hours, Macron also spoke several times with Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky, again praising his "sense of responsibility" in negotiations with Moscow.
After another Defense Council this morning at the √âlys√©e Palace, French Foreign Minister Jean-Yves le Drian said, visibly moved, that the French authorities had obtained guarantees from the Russians that the French still present in Kiev could leave the capital safely, by road and rail.
"The roads to leave Kiev from the south are not completely safe, but there is now a possibility of leaving the city [...] The Russians have indicated that all civilians can leave freely via the Kiev-Vasylkiv highway", stated the minister, declaring that France is unable to provide support on these roads to its citizens.
There will still be around 1000 French people in Ukraine, according to the French Ministry of Foreign Affairs.
France also decided to intensify sanctions on Russian oligarchs, and is carrying out an internal investigation to determine which real estate assets in the country belong to the Russian elite that supports Putin.
This afternoon, Macron will participate with Olaf Scholz, German Chancellor, Ursula Van Der Leyen, President of the European Commission, and Charles Michel, President of the European Council, in a meeting with the leaders of Canada, the United States, Italy, Japan, Poland, Romania and NATO representatives, in order to discuss Russia's invasion of Ukraine.
After this meeting, the French head of state will have dinner with the leaders of European institutions.
Russia launched a military offensive in Ukraine early Thursday morning, with ground forces and bombing of targets in several cities, which has already killed more than 350 civilians, including children, according to Kiev. The UN reported more than 100,000 displaced people and almost 500,000 refugees in Poland, Hungary, Moldova and Romania.
Russian President Vladimir Putin said that the "special military operation" in Ukraine aims to demilitarize the neighboring country and that it was the only way for Russia to defend itself, with the Kremlin specifying that the offensive will last as long as necessary.
The attack was condemned by most of the international community and the European Union and the United States, among others, responded by sending weapons and ammunition to Ukraine and strengthening sanctions to further isolate Moscow.

translated_text:
The War
World
Ukrainian and Russian negotiators end meeting and announce new round
Lusa Agency
Feb 28, 2022
18:30
0
Comments
Photo EPA
The Ukrainian and Russian delegations ended the talks they held throughout the day in Belarus, and admitted a new meeting "soon".
"The parties have established a series of priorities and issues that require certain decisions" before a second round of talks, said Mikhail Podoliak, one of the Ukrainian negotiators, cited by the AFP agency.
His Russian counterpart, Vladimir Medinsky, said the new meeting would take place "soon" on the border between Poland and Belarus.
The two parties reached an agreement for this meeting in Belarus through the mediation of the President of this neighboring country and ally of Moscow, Alexander Lukashenko.
The talks took place at one of Lukashenko's residences, in the Gomel region, close to the border between Belarus and Ukraine, and not far from the Chernobyl nuclear power plant, which is located on Ukrainian territory.
The Ukrainian presidency had said it would demand an immediate ceasefire and the withdrawal of Russian troops, who invaded Ukraine again on Thursday, after Moscow had already annexed the Ukrainian peninsula of Crimea in 2014.
Russia did not want to reveal what positions it would defend in the negotiations, but Russian President Vladimir Putin today conditioned any agreement on a set of demands, in a telephone conversation with his French counterpart, Emmanuel Macron.
These demands include recognition of Russian sovereignty over Crimea, the "demilitarization and denazification" of the Ukrainian state, and a neutral status for Ukraine, according to the Kremlin (Presidency).
Putin calls Kiev's pro-Western government "neonazi".
The negotiations took place on the fifth day of fighting, during which violent clashes broke out in Ukraine's second city, Kharkiv (east), where local authorities reported that at least 11 civilians were killed in Russian shelling.
Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky, who had admitted that he did not have much hope for the success of the negotiations, today called on Russian soldiers to lay down their arms and return to Russia.
Shortly before the announcement of the end of the talks, Zelensky signed Ukraine's formal application for membership in the European Union (EU), which was promised to the Ukrainians in 2008, at the same time that the North Atlantic Treaty Organization (NATO) also approved the country's entry, at a summit in Bucharest.
The refusal of the then pro-Moscow President, Viktor Yanukovych, to sign an association agreement with the EU was the source of a popular uprising that led to his removal in 2014.
In reaction, Russia annexed Crimea and fomented a separatist war in the Donbass, eastern Ukraine, which has since caused more than 14,000 deaths.
This new invasion of Ukraine has already caused hundreds of deaths on the Ukrainian side, while Russia has admitted casualties, but without revealing numbers.
Around half a million people have fled Ukraine for neighboring countries since Thursday.
The invasion was condemned by most of the international community and triggered protest demonstrations in many countries, including Portugal.
The EU and several countries, such as the United States, the United Kingdom and Japan, have imposed harsh sanctions against Moscow, including in areas such as banking or aviation, and which also target personalities such as Putin himself and his head of diplomacy, Sergei Lavrov.
FIFA and UEFA today announced the suspension of the Russian national team and clubs from all international competitions, similar to what has happened in other sports.

International Criminal Court opens investigation into Russia for crimes against humanity
Prosecutor General says "there is a reasonable basis to believe that alleged war crimes and crimes against humanity have been committed in Ukraine"
DN/Lusa
28¬†February¬†2022¬†‚Äî¬†22:31
Facebook
Twitter
Comment
Share
Topics
War in Ukraine
International
Russia
Ukraine
International Criminal Court
Related
ukraine

war in ukraine
Paulo Fonseca: "We saw the military columns, we heard the sirens, always with that feeling of danger"
The International Criminal Court (ICC) has opened a formal investigation into Russia's invasion of Ukraine for alleged war crimes.
"I am convinced that there is a reasonable basis to believe that alleged war crimes and crimes against humanity have been committed in Ukraine"
since 2014, said the attorney general of the international body based in The Hague (Netherlands), Karim Khan, in a statement cited by international agencies.
In 2014, Russia invaded and annexed the Crimean peninsula, in southeastern Ukraine, after a movement of popular protest in favor of the country's integration into the European Union (EU).
Close

and receive information first hand.
Subscribe
At the same time, pro-Russian separatists with support from Moscow started a war in the Donbass region, in eastern Ukraine, which had caused more than 14,000 deaths and 1.5 million people displaced until the current invasion.
The ongoing Russian invasion of Ukrainian territory has further aggravated the situation on the ground.
Russia launched a military offensive in Ukraine early Thursday morning, with ground forces and bombing of targets in several cities, which has already killed more than 350 civilians, including children, according to Kiev.
The UN reported more than 100,000 displaced people and almost 500,000 refugees in Poland, Hungary, Moldova and Romania.
Last Friday, Ukraine's Foreign Minister said that the country had started collecting data on the actions of the Russian Armed Forces in the context of the invasion of Ukrainian territory to send it to the ICC.
Lithuania said today, through its Minister of Justice, that it wanted the ICC to investigate alleged war crimes and crimes against humanity committed by Russia and Belarus during the invasion of Ukraine.

translated_text:
The War
World
Macron asks Putin for ceasefire, Russian leader demands "demilitarization" of Kiev
Lusa Agency
Feb 28, 2022
17:06
0
Comments
Photo EPA
French President Emmanuel Macron today asked Vladimir Putin for an immediate ceasefire in Ukraine and safe conditions for the¬†exit of civilians from Kiev, while the Russian President demanded the "demilitarization" of the country under¬†Russian invasion.
According to a statement sent to newsrooms by the √âlys√©e Palace, Macron also asked, during a conversation lasting more than an hour, for an end to attacks against civilians and residential areas, as well as the preservation of all civil infrastructure. Vladimir Putin will have "confirmed his commitment" to these demands.
The Kremlin also made it known in a press release that Putin declared to his French counterpart the demand, as conditions for the ceasefire, of the recognition of Crimea as Russian territory, the "denazification" of the Ukrainian Government and a neutral status for Ukraine.
At a time when talks are taking place between Russian and Ukrainian delegations, the French President also proposed to Vladimir Putin that the two continue in contact in the coming days in order to "prevent the situation from worsening" and the Russian leader also agreed.
In the last few hours, Macron also spoke several times with the Ukrainian president,¬†Volodymyr Zelensky, again praising his "sense of responsibility" in negotiations with Moscow.
After another Defense Council this morning at the √âlys√©e Palace, French Foreign Minister Jean-Yves le Drian said, visibly moved, that the French authorities had obtained guarantees from the Russians that the French still present in Kiev could leave the capital safely, by road and rail.
"The roads to leave Kiev from the south are not completely safe, but there is now a possibility of leaving the city [...] The Russians have indicated that all civilians can leave freely via the Kiev-Vasylkiv highway", stated the minister, declaring that France is unable to provide support on these roads to its citizens.
There will still be around 1,000 French people in Ukraine, according to the French Ministry of Foreign Affairs.
France also decided to intensify sanctions on Russian oligarchs, and is carrying out an internal investigation to determine which real estate assets in the country belong to the Russian elite that supports Putin.
This afternoon, Macron will participate with Olaf Scholz, German Chancellor, Ursula Van Der Leyen, President of the European Commission, and Charles Michel, President of the European Council, in a meeting with the leaders of Canada, the United States, Italy, Japan, Poland, Romania and NATO representatives, in order to discuss Russia's invasion of Ukraine.
After this meeting, the French head of state will have dinner with the leaders of European institutions.
Russia launched a military offensive in Ukraine early Thursday morning, with ground forces and bombing of targets in several cities, which has already killed more than 350 civilians, including children, according to Kiev. The UN reported more than 100,000 displaced people and almost 500,000 refugees in Poland, Hungary, Moldova and Romania.
Russian President Vladimir Putin said that the "special military operation" in Ukraine aims to demilitarize the neighboring country and that it was the only way for Russia to defend itself, with the Kremlin specifying that the offensive will last as long as necessary.
The attack was condemned by most of the international community and the European Union and the United States, among others, responded by sending weapons and ammunition to Ukraine and strengthening sanctions to further isolate Moscow.

Court will investigate alleged "war crimes" and "crimes against humanity"
Lusa Agency
Feb 28, 2022
21:07
0
Comments
Photo EPA
The Prosecutor General of the International Criminal Court (ICC) today announced the opening "as soon as possible" of an investigation into alleged "war crimes" and "crimes against humanity" in the conflict that has ravaged Ukraine since 2014.
"I am convinced that there is a reasonable basis to believe that alleged war crimes and crimes against humanity have been committed in Ukraine" since 2014, said the prosecutor general of the international body based in The Hague (Netherlands), Karim Khan, in a statement cited by international agencies.
In 2014, Russia invaded and annexed the Crimean peninsula, in southeastern Ukraine, after a movement of popular protest in favor of the country's integration into the European Union (EU).
At the same time, pro-Russian separatists with support from Moscow started a war in the Donbass region, in eastern Ukraine, which had caused more than 14,000 deaths and 1.5 million people displaced until the current invasion.
The ongoing Russian invasion of Ukrainian territory has further aggravated the situation on the ground.
Russia launched a military offensive in Ukraine early Thursday morning, with ground forces and bombing of targets in several cities, which has already killed more than 350 civilians, including children, according to Kiev.
The UN reported more than 100,000 displaced people and almost 500,000 refugees in Poland, Hungary, Moldova and Romania.
Last Friday, Ukraine's Foreign Minister said that the country had started collecting data on the actions of the Russian Armed Forces in the context of the invasion of Ukrainian territory to send it to the ICC.
Lithuania said today, through its Minister of Justice, that it wanted the ICC to investigate alleged war crimes and crimes against humanity committed by Russia and Belarus during the invasion of Ukraine.

In conversation with Macron

The Russian president explained to his French counterpart the prerequisites for any agreement to put an end to the invasion of Ukraine.

Russian President Vladimir Putin declared this Monday to his French counterpart, Emmanuel Macron, that he demands the recognition of Crimea as Russian territory, as well as the "denazification" of the Ukrainian government and a "neutral status" for Kiev, as conditions for the end of the invasion of Ukraine.
Putin demanded
"the recognition of Russian sovereignty over Crimea, the end of demilitarization and denazification of the Ukrainian state and the guarantee of its neutral status"
as prerequisites for any agreement, the Kremlin said in a statement released after their telephone conversation.
Macron asked the Russian president to spare civilians and civil infrastructure in Ukraine, as well as some of the main Ukrainian roads, during a 90-minute telephone conversation between the two, the French leader's office said in a statement.
"President Putin confirmed his willingness to make commitments on these three points," the statement said.

Macron too
"reiterated the international community's demand to halt the Russian offensive against Ukraine and reaffirmed the need to implement an immediate ceasefire"
, said Elisha.
The French president also asked Putin to respect international humanitarian law and allow aid shipments to reach the population.
This phone call was the latest in a series of conversations between the two leaders, in which Macron initially sought to prevent the Russian invasion and then limit its damage.
Earlier this month, Macron went to Moscow to speak personally with Putin, having returned to Paris with assurances of what he called "Putin's desire to maintain the stability and territorial integrity of Ukraine."
After Monday's conversation, Macron suggested that the two leaders remain in contact in the coming days "to avoid a worsening of the situation", something that Putin agreed with.

translated_text:
The War
World
Number of refugees exceeds 422 thousand people
Lusa Agency
Feb 28, 2022
11:26
0
Comments
PHOTO¬†EPA/ROBERT GHEMENT
The number of Ukrainians who fled the country due to the Russian invasion exceeds 422 thousand people, in addition to more than 100 thousand people internally displaced by the conflict, the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees (UNHCR) reported today.
Poland, Hungary, Moldova and Romania are currently the main destinations for this flow of refugees, according to the UNHCR on its Twitter account.
Both UNHCR and the Ukrainian Government warned last week of the possibility that the number of refugees could rise to five million people, that is, almost a tenth of Ukraine's population.
Since the start of the Russian attacks last Thursday, the UN High Commissioner for Refugees, Filippo Grandi, has called on Ukraine's neighboring countries to "keep their borders open to those seeking safety and protection".
UNHCR spokesperson in the United Kingdom, Laura Padoan, indicated, in a statement also released on Twitter, that the UN agency is verifying information that Ukrainians are being prevented from boarding trains to escape the Russian offensive.
According to the Ukrainian Government, since the beginning of the crisis in Crimea and Donbass in 2014, 1.5 million internally displaced people have been registered in the country.
Russia launched a military offensive in Ukraine early Thursday morning, with ground forces and bombing of targets in several cities, which has already caused around 200 deaths, including civilians, and more than 1,100 injuries, on Ukrainian territory, according to Kiev.
The attack was condemned by most of the international community and led to emergency meetings of several governments, including the Portuguese, and the North Atlantic Treaty Organization (NATO), EU and UN Security Council, with mass sanctions being approved against Russia.

translated_text:
"P
I can confirm that Roman Abramovich was contacted by the Ukrainian side for support in reaching a peaceful resolution, and that he has been trying to help since then," said the spokeswoman, quoted by Al Jazeera television.
The spokeswoman declined to comment on the war between Russia and Ukraine, as well as Abramovich's involvement, "considering what is at stake."
Abramovich's involvement in mediating the conflict was initially reported by the British newspaper Jewish News, which said that Ukrainian authorities had contacted the Russian businessman through his Jewish contacts in Ukraine.
The President of Ukraine is the son of Jews and has family members who died in the Holocaust, according to the Israeli press.
Roman Abramovich became a naturalized Portuguese citizen in April 2021, as he is a descendant of Sephardic Jews expelled from Portugal in the 15th century.
Ukrainian film director Alexander Rodnyansky said Abramovich was the only one to respond to Ukraine's requests.
"I can confirm that the Ukrainian side has been trying to find someone in Russia willing to help them negotiate peace. They have a relationship with him through the Jewish community and have asked him for help," said Rodnyansky, quoted by the Spanish agency EFE.
"Although Abramovich's influence is limited, he is the only one who has responded to their calls for help," he added.
Abramovich announced at the weekend that he was leaving the management of Chelsea in the hands of the club's foundation, due to the UK's current stand-off with Russia.
Some media in Israel, the country that gave Abramovich a passport, said that the Russian billionaire is present at the peace talks between Russia and Ukraine in Belarus, but the information has not yet been confirmed.
The talks take place on the fifth day of fighting in Ukraine, which was once again invaded by Russia after losing the Crimean peninsula to Moscow in 2014.
The Russian offensive has already caused hundreds of deaths and half a million refugees.
The attack was condemned by most of the international community, with many countries and the European Union (EU) imposing harsh economic sanctions against Russian interests, including in the banking and aviation sectors.
Russian President Vladimir Putin said that the "special military operation" in Ukraine, launched early Thursday morning, aims to demilitarize the neighboring country and that it was the only way for Russia to defend itself, with the Kremlin stating that the offensive will last as long as necessary.
The UN General Assembly is meeting today to discuss the war in Ukraine, after Russia used its right of veto in the Security Council to prevent the approval of a resolution condemning its action.

Roman Abramovich involved in mediating the crisis at the request of Kiev
Lusa Agency
Feb 28, 2022
16:00
0
Comments
Russian businessman Roman Abramovich has accepted a request from Ukraine to help mediate peace talks with Russia, a spokeswoman for the owner of English football club Chelsea said today.
"I can confirm that Roman Abramovich was contacted by the Ukrainian side for support in reaching a peaceful resolution, and that he has been trying to help since then," said the spokeswoman, quoted by Al Jazeera television.
The spokeswoman declined to comment on the war between Russia and Ukraine, as well as Abramovich's involvement, "considering what is at stake."
Abramovich's involvement in mediating the conflict was initially reported by the British newspaper Jewish News, which said that Ukrainian authorities had contacted the Russian businessman through his Jewish contacts in Ukraine.
The President of Ukraine is the son of Jews and has family members who died in the Holocaust, according to the Israeli press.
Roman Abramovich became a naturalized Portuguese citizen in April 2021, as he is a descendant of Sephardic Jews expelled from Portugal in the 15th century.
Ukrainian film director Alexander Rodnyansky said Abramovich was the only one to respond to Ukraine's requests.
"I can confirm that the Ukrainian side has been trying to find someone in Russia willing to help them negotiate peace. They have a relationship with him through the Jewish community and have asked him for help," said Rodnyansky, quoted by the Spanish agency EFE.
"Although Abramovich's influence is limited, he is the only one who has responded to their calls for help," he added.
Abramovich announced at the weekend that he was leaving the management of Chelsea in the hands of the club's foundation, due to the UK's current stand-off with Russia.
Some media in Israel, the country that gave Abramovich a passport, said that the Russian billionaire is present at the peace talks between Russia and Ukraine in Belarus, but the information has not yet been confirmed.
The talks take place on the fifth day of fighting in Ukraine, which was once again invaded by Russia after losing the Crimean peninsula to Moscow in 2014.
The Russian offensive has already caused hundreds of deaths and half a million refugees.
The attack was condemned by most of the international community, with many countries and the European Union (EU) imposing harsh economic sanctions against Russian interests, including in the banking and aviation sectors.
Russian President Vladimir Putin said that the "special military operation" in Ukraine, launched early Thursday morning, aims to demilitarize the neighboring country and that it was the only way for Russia to defend itself, with the Kremlin stating that the offensive will last as long as necessary.
The UN General Assembly is meeting today to discuss the war in Ukraine, after Russia used its right of veto in the Security Council to prevent the approval of a resolution condemning its action.

translated_text:
"The visit of Foreign Minister Lavrov to Geneva to participate in the Human Rights Council and the Conference on Disarmament has been cancelled", says the message released on social media by the Russian Representation, also referring to the ban on Russian commercial flights in the European Union.
Ukraine on Monday won broad support for an urgent debate at the UN Human Rights Council on the Russian invasion, in which Kiev will call for an investigation into alleged human rights violations by Moscow.
Russian attacks dominated the opening of the 49th session of the Human Rights Council, which runs from today until April 1, in which the Russian Foreign Minister was expected to participate.
"The escalation of military operations by the Russian Federation in Ukraine is leading to an increase in human rights violations," said United Nations Secretary-General Ant√≥nio Guterres at the opening of the Council in a video message.
"Throughout history, there have been moments of profound gravity, which divided the course of events between a before and an after, very different, more dangerous. We are at a turning point", said the UN High Commissioner for Human Rights, Michelle Bachelet.
Bachelet also revealed that the UN has recorded 102 deaths, including seven children, and 304 injuries, since the start of the Russian invasion of Ukraine, and warned that the real numbers must be "considerably" higher.
The Ukrainian ambassador, Yevheniia Filipenko, said that the balance available to the Ministry of Health is more than 350 fatalities, including 16 children, and around 1,700 injured.
Russia's invasion of Ukraine will be the subject of an urgent debate at the Human Rights Council on Thursday, and the Ukrainian Government, supported by a broad coalition of countries, intends to demand the creation by the UN of an international commission of inquiry, as exists for Syria.
According to the draft resolution, Ukraine requests that UN experts investigate alleged human rights violations in Crimea and the breakaway territories of Luhansk and Donetsk since 2014, as well as in the rest of the country since 2022.

Negotiations between Russia and Ukraine have ended for now. Putin demands ceasefire
Feb 28, 2022 - 16:35 ‚Ä¢
Ricardo Vieira, with agencies
Representatives of Russia and Ukraine intend to hold a "second round" to try to end the war. Putin demanded the demilitarization of Ukraine and wants the international community to recognize Crimea as Russian territory.
A+
/
A-
Photo: Sergei Kholodilin/EPA
The round of negotiations between representatives of Russia and Ukraine has come to an end for now.
Those envoys to Gomel, in Belarus, will return to Kiev and Moscow for consultations with the respective governments and there could be a second negotiation, according to the France Press agency.
Representatives of Russia and Ukraine intend to hold a "second round" to try to end the war, says the Ukrainian negotiator, cited by France Press.
Putin wants demilitarization of Ukraine
Russian President Vladimir Putin imposes conditions to end military operations: he wants the demilitarization of Ukraine and wants the international community to recognize Crimea as Russian territory.
The conditions were defined in a telephone conversation with his French counterpart Emmanuel Macron.
The French President, in turn, demanded an end to attacks on civilians, not targeting civilian infrastructure and guaranteeing safe access to the main roads, especially south of the capital, Kiev.
The two leaders also committed to maintaining contact over the next few days.
Ukraine demands ceasefire and withdrawal of troops
The Ukrainian delegation that met in the morning at the place where negotiations with Russia were taking place had announced that they were going to demand an √¢‚Ç¨≈ìimmediate√¢‚Ç¨ ceasefire and the withdrawal of Russian troops.
√¢‚Ç¨≈ìThe Ukrainian delegation arrived in the area near the border between Ukraine and Belarus to participate in the negotiations√¢‚Ç¨ at 9:00 am in Lisbon, the Ukrainian presidency said in a statement.
√¢‚Ç¨≈ìThe key issue is the immediate ceasefire and the withdrawal of troops from Ukrainian territory,√¢‚Ç¨ the same document states.
The President of Ukraine, Volodymyr Zelensky, signed this Monday a formal request for the country's accession to the European Union.
An image posted on social media shows the Ukrainian head of state with the pages of the membership application.
Asked about Ukraine's will, the head of European Union diplomacy says that the issue is not on the agenda and that he needs to respond "in the next few hours, not in the next few years".

translated_text:
Home
International
Nuclear threat does not stop sanctions on Russia
Nato, the United States and the EU condemn Putin's "dangerous rhetoric and irresponsible conduct." The European Union, for the first time, finances the purchase of weapons to help a country under attack and reinforces sanctions. Russian attempts to occupy Kiev and Kharkiv were met by Ukrainian resistance. In the next few hours there may be negotiations in Belarus between delegations from Russia and Ukraine.
Arthur Cassiano
27¬†February¬†2022¬†‚Äî¬†23:24
Facebook
Twitter
Comment
Share
Topics
War in Ukraine
Ursula von der Leyen
Jens Stoltenberg
International
Vladimir Putin
Volodymyr Zelenskyy
Related
war in ukraine
Historic decision in the EU: 450 million to arm the Ukrainian army
USA
Biden speaks to allies today to coordinate response
ukraine
Russian Defense Ministry says civilians can leave Kiev freely
And on the fourth day the nuclear threat emerged. "I order the Defense Minister and the Chief of Staff to put the [nuclear] deterrent force of the Russian army on special combat alert," Putin said.
The explanation for this order is linear: "aggressive statements" and "hostile measures" against Russia. Vladimir Putin's sentence, in full, revealed on Russian television is this: "Western countries are not only taking hostile measures against our country in the economic sphere, but also senior officials from the main NATO members have made aggressive statements towards our country".
Almost immediately, the White House spokeswoman accused the Russian president of "manufacturing threats that don't exist."
Close
Subscribe to newsletters
News Diary
and receive information first hand.
Subscribe
"It is a repeated pattern", said Jen Psaki, "that we have seen from President Putin during this conflict, which consists of fabricating threats that do not exist to justify continued aggression. At no time has Russia been threatened by NATO or Ukraine (...) We will resist this. We have the ability to defend ourselves".
"This is dangerous rhetoric. It is irresponsible conduct," Jens Stoltenberg, NATO secretary general, told CNN.
"They are not only threatening Ukraine, but also NATO allies and are demanding," he explained, "that we withdraw all of our armed forces from the Alliance's eastern flank."
Interviewed by the BBC, Stoltenberg went further with his words and warned that "our message is very clear: NATO countries defend and protect each other. NATO does not want war with Russia, we are not looking for confrontation (...) we are a defensive alliance, but there should be no misunderstandings or miscalculations about our ability to defend allies" in the face of possible attacks.
NATO's faults and responsibilities? Stoltenberg completely rejects Moscow's accusations: "It was Russia that started the war, that it is conducting a large-scale military invasion of a peaceful, sovereign nation, so there is no doubt that Russia is responsible. President Putin is responsible for this conflict (...) What we are doing is simply helping Ukraine by helping them assert their right to self-defense."
In 2008, at the Bucharest summit, NATO promised Ukraine and Georgia that they would become members of the Alliance.
For his part, the head of Ukrainian diplomacy was emphatic in his response: "We will not surrender, we will not capitulate, we will not give up a single centimeter of our territory."
"It's an attempt to put pressure on the Ukrainian delegation" [which will be on its way to the border with Belarus for negotiations with Moscow representatives], but this [nuclear] threat will not break us", assures Dmytro Kuleba.
The intensification of the conflict led the European Union, for the first time, to finance the purchase and delivery of weapons and military equipment to help a country under attack.
Sweden also broke this rule yesterday, a protocol in place since the USSR invaded Finland in 1939.
Ursula von der Leyen, president of the European Commission, revealed new sanctions hours later. "The closure of EU airspace to Russian-owned, Russian-registered or Russian-controlled aircraft", including the oligarchs' private jets, which "will not be able to land, take off or fly over EU territory".
Other measures include "prohibiting Russian oligarchs from using their financial assets in European markets", banning "the Kremlin's media machine (...) toxic and harmful disinformation" from the EU space. In other words, "Russia Today and Sputnik [owned by the Russian state], as well as their subsidiaries, will no longer be able to spread their lies to justify Putin's war."
Moscow has imposed censorship on Russian media outlets, banning the use of expressions such as "invasion", "offensive" or "declaration of war" in news about what is officially described as a "special military operation" aimed at "keeping peace".
Ursula von der Leyen announced yet another measure: sanctioning "the other aggressor in this war [Belarus], the Lukashenko regime", which is "accomplice in this vicious attack against Ukraine" and which will be the target of a "new package of sanctions".
The EU's High Representative for Foreign Policy, Josep Borrell, highlighted the unprecedented "another taboo that has fallen: that the EU would not supply weapons in a war. Yes, we are doing so, because this war requires our commitment in order to support the Ukrainian army. Because we live in unprecedented times (...) this is the first time in history that the European bloc will supply lethal equipment to a third country".
"Putin's war is not just against Ukraine. We have to understand the gravity of the situation for us Europeans and for global security," he warned.
Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskyy added a new call for more sanctions: the expulsion of Russia from the UN Security Council.
"Russia has taken the path of evil and the world should deprive it of its place on the United Nations Security Council," he said.
On Friday, Russia prevented the UN Security Council from approving a resolution condemning the invasion of Ukraine by its troops, the second since 2014, when it annexed Crimea.
The resolution received 11 votes in favor and abstentions from China, India and the United Arab Emirates, but the Russian veto was enough to make the initiative unfeasible.
On the ground, few changes are known. The city of Kharkiv remains under Ukrainian control despite Russian announcements that they had taken the city - the "intense battle" was fought with the help of Ukrainian reservists; Kiev has resisted the attacks of the last 48 hours; in Dnipro, for the first time, alarm sirens sounded; ballistic missiles were launched against Ukraine from Belarus and hit the airport in the city of Zhytomyr; and for the first time Moscow admits that there are Russian soldiers killed in combat, but does not reveal numbers.
Ukraine speaks of 4,300 casualties among Russian troops.

U
A new round of peace talks between Ukraine and Russia is expected to take place in the coming days, after, on the fifth day of the Russian invasion, the leaders of the two countries met in Gomel, Belarus, to agree on a possible ceasefire and the withdrawal of Russian troops.
Volodymyr Zelensky, President of Ukraine,
made official this Monday the application for membership of the European Union
(EU), "a historic moment" for the country. The information was released after the head of state called for Ukraine's immediate entry into the bloc.¬†For its part, the European Parliament (EP) announced that it will adopt a resolution on "Russian aggression against Ukraine" at Tuesday's extraordinary plenary session in Brussels, in which it is expected to
advocate granting Ukraine the status of a candidate country for accession.
Already more than
500 thousand people
fled the Russian invasion to neighboring countries, according to data from the United Nations (UN).
Follow the latest developments on the conflict in Ukraine here BY THE MINUTE:
00h00 -
Good night! Here ends this MINUTE monitoring of the conflict between Russia and Ukraine, which will be resumed on Tuesday morning, in a new record.
00h00 -
Biden continues to have no intention of sending troops to the conflict in Ukraine
At a time when Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky continues to appeal for support from the West to put an end to the Russian invasion of his territory, he apparently will not be able to count, at least soon, on North American support on the ground. According to White House press secretary Jen Psaki, the president
Joe Biden remains steadfast in his commitment to keeping US troops out of conflict
, reports CNN.
23:57 -
Military must avoid Zaporizhia nuclear plant, UN warns
The International Atomic Energy Agency (IAEA) warned today that
military actions at the Zaporizhia nuclear plant avoided
, the largest in Ukraine, a country invaded by neighboring Russia.
23:53 -
Brazil will welcome Ukrainians, reveals Bolsonaro
Brazilian President Jair Bolsonaro said this Monday that the country will receive Ukrainian citizens through humanitarian visas, in an interview with the Jovem Pan channel. The decision will be published this week by the federal government.
23:51 -
EU sanctions 26 more oligarchs, businessmen and members of the Russian government
The European Union (EU) today added to its
sanctions list 26 Russian oligarchs and businessmen
from the oil, banking and financial sectors, members of the government, high-level personalities and an entity linked to gas.
23:46 -
Supporters of Russian opponent Alexey Navalny call for "civil disobedience"
Supporters of Alexey Navalny, the currently imprisoned Russian opposition leader, today called on
"civil disobedience" of the Russian population
in protest against the invasion of Ukraine ordered by Russian President Vladimir Putin.
23:45 -

increase the supply of Algerian gas
faced with the conflict in Ukraine after the Russian invasion.
23:44 -

The Cardinal Patriarch of Lisbon called today for the war in Ukraine to be resolved "
humanly and with mutual respect
" and not with "brutality".
23:22 -

23:09 -
Extraordinary Council of Ministers addresses reception of Ukrainians

It is recalled that the Prime Minister, Ant√≥nio Costa, offered "a word of confidence to the Ukrainian community residing in Portugal" after the Russian offensive. "Tell them that
will count on all our solidarity
, who have been very welcome and that their family, their friends, their acquaintances who understand that they should seek safety and destiny in Portugal to continue their lives are also very welcome."
22:49 -
Zelensky lifts visas for foreigners willing to fight for Ukraine

foreigners willing to fight for Ukraine against the Russian offensive will not need a visa
, at least while martial law is in effect. The measure comes into effect this Tuesday.
"Together we defeated Hitler, and we will defeat Putin too," Ukrainian Foreign Minister Dmytro Kuleba wrote on Twitter.
Foreigners willing to defend Ukraine and world order as part of the International Legion of Territorial Defense of Ukraine, I invite you to contact foreign diplomatic missions of Ukraine in your respective countries. Together we defeated Hitler, and we will defeat Putin, too.

February 27, 2022
22:40 -
"It ends well." There are 38 people arriving on the repatriation flight to Portugal
The first repatriation operation of Portuguese, Portuguese-Ukrainians and their families
came to an end today
, as stated by Foreign Minister Augusto Santos Silva in statements to journalists.
"A first group began this evacuation on Thursday, a second group on Friday. With the closure of airspace in Ukraine, the first part of the journey had to be done by land. The two groups crossed the Ukrainian border with Moldova and then headed to Romania where they converged", explains the person in charge, adding that, in Bucharest, it was "possible to organize an air connection and it is this flight that now ends", with 38 people.
22:18 -

exclusion of Russia as a member of the United Nations (UN) Security Council
, stating that "a state that commits war crimes against civilians cannot be a member" of this body, quotes The Kyiv Independent. ‚ÄúBuying Russian goods is now paying to kill people,‚Äù he concluded.
Russia will have launched
56 rockets and 113 cruise missiles in the last five days of the invasion
, said the Ukrainian president.
22:17 -

The war in Ukraine is rapidly changing the world order, which could have
impact on Africa‚Äôs relevance in the global panorama

22:16 -

"very unlikely"
the sending of the Rosalind Franklin robot to Mars in 2022, due to European sanctions against Russia, a partner in the mission, in response to the invasion of Ukraine.

restrict access to Russian media outlets RT and Sputnik News in the European Union (EU) on their Facebook and Instagram platforms

We have received requests from a number of Governments and the EU to take further steps in relation to Russian state controlled media. Given the exceptional nature of the current situation, we will be restricting access to RT and Sputnik across the EU at this time.
‚Äî Nick Clegg (@nickclegg)
February 28, 2022
9:29 pm -

The game between Sp. Braga and Santa Clara, played this Monday, featured a

. When the stars took to the Pedreira pitch, 23 Ukrainian children also entered the field. All wearing the same t-shirt: 'Give Peace a Chance'.
9:27 pm -

30 Ukrainian refugees
, which will be removed from border areas in Poland and Romania, the municipality announced today.
9:26 pm -

full support for Ukraine's entry into the European Union (EU)
, following an accelerated procedure, as requested by Kiev as part of the Russian invasion.
8:52 pm -
Turkey blocks ships in the Bosphorus and Dardanelles straits
A
Turkey banned all warships from passing through the Bosphorus and Dardanelles straits
, "riverside or not on the Black Sea", announced this evening the Minister of Foreign Affairs, Mevlut Cavusoglu.
8:43 pm -
Ukraine demands that Russia be expelled from Interpol
Following the invasion carried out on its territory, the
Ukraine came to demand that Russia be expelled from the International Criminal Police Organization (Interpol)
, reports The Guardian. The demand was made by the Ukrainian Minister of Internal Affairs, Denis Monastyrsky, asking for this expulsion to be immediate.
8:39 pm -
Portuguese operators offer free calls to Ukraine
Telecommunications operators
Meo (Altice Portugal), NOS, Nowo and Vodafone Portugal are offering free calls to Ukraine
, a country that last week was the target of an invasion by Russia.
8:26 pm -
International Criminal Court opens investigation into Russia for war crimes
The International Criminal Court, in the Dutch city of The Hague,
will open an investigation into alleged war crimes committed by Russia against Ukraine
, following the invasions that have lasted five days, says The Guardian.
8:12 pm -
Members of Russian diplomatic mission to the UN expelled from the US
Russian Ambassador to the UN Vassily Nebenzia announced today that
12 members of its diplomatic mission have been ordered to leave the United States by the end of March
.
20:08 -
Sirens sound in Kiev after explosions
Explosions were heard again in Kiev, the Ukrainian capital, where it is currently 7pm. The sirens also sounded again.
BREAKING: An explosion has been heard in Kyiv with air raid sirens ringing out across Ukraine's capital amid Russia's invasion.

pic.twitter.com/Pg5mURqOZA
‚Äî Sky News (@SkyNews)
February 28, 2022
20:08 -
European Parliament will defend granting candidate country status
The European Parliament will adopt a resolution on "Russian aggression against Ukraine" at Tuesday's extraordinary plenary session in Brussels, in which
should defend the granting of Ukraine the status of a candidate country for accession
.
19h57 -
To remember:
Zelensky formally signs the application for membership of the European Union.
"It's a historic moment!", celebrated the organization, in a Twitter post.
A new round of peace talks is expected to take place in the coming days,
said the Russian state agency RIA.
"Nothing justifies the use of nuclear weapons"
, said Ant√≥nio Guterres, UN Secretary-General, during the emergency general assembly, appealing to the power of dialogue.
Switzerland and Finland leave neutrality.
Switzerland announced that it will
apply the European Union's sanctions package against Russia
, while Finland took the
"historic decision"
to supply weapons and supplies to Ukraine.

here
.

Belarus ready for Moscow-Kiev talks
Ukraine on Sunday agreed to the idea of talks with Russia, although it said it was "not very confident" they could put an end to the Russian invasion launched on Thursday morning.
Kharkiv city, Ukraine

Belarusian authorities announced this Monday that they were ready to host the planned negotiations between Russia and Ukraine, although the delegations have not yet arrived, on the fifth day of the invasion launched by Moscow.
"The venue for Russia-Ukraine talks in Belarus is ready and we are waiting for delegations," the Belarusian Ministry of Foreign Affairs said on the social network Facebook.
The message was accompanied by a photograph of the conference room, with a long table with a dozen chairs on each side and the flags of the three countries in the background.
Ukraine on Sunday agreed to the idea of ‚Äã‚Äãtalks with Russia, although it said it was "not very confident" they could put an end to the Russian invasion launched on Thursday morning.
Close

Thank you very much for your registration.
Talks between Ukrainian and Russian delegations are scheduled for the border between Ukraine and Belarus, despite Belarus being used as a retreat base by Moscow forces for the attack on Kiev.
The talks will take place "without preconditions", according to Ukraine, which guaranteed that it does not intend to capitulate.
Kiev indicated that the President of Belarus, Alexander Lukashenko, an ally of the Russian head of state, Vladimir Putin, promised that Russian military equipment (planes, helicopters and missiles) stationed on Belarusian territory would remain on the ground during the arrival, negotiations and departure of the Ukrainian delegation.
Russia launched a military offensive in Ukraine early Thursday morning, with ground forces and bombing of targets in several cities, which has already killed at least 352 civilians, including children, according to Kiev. The UN reported nearly 370,000 people displaced to Poland, Hungary, Moldova and Romania.
Russian President Vladimir Putin said that the "special military operation" in Ukraine aims to demilitarize the neighboring country and that it was the only way for Russia to defend itself, with the Kremlin specifying that the offensive will last as long as necessary.
The attack was condemned by most of the international community and the European Union and the United States, among others, responded by sending weapons and ammunition to Ukraine and strengthening sanctions to further isolate Moscow.

On the fifth day of the Russian offensive in Ukraine, the first round of negotiations between Moscow and Kiev began and ended, which formally signed the application for membership of the European Union. Meanwhile, the number of attacks and victims continues to increase. Read below the main points that marked the day.
- At least
102 civilians died and 304 were injured
in Ukraine since Thursday, but the real numbers are "considerably higher", the United Nations High Commissioner for Human Rights estimated. The latest balance of the Ukrainian Government
raises to 352
the number of deaths.
- They started
negotiations between Ukraine and Russia
in Belarus. Kiev pointed out as the objective of the delegation meeting an "immediate ceasefire and the withdrawal of troops". On the Russian side, negotiator Vladimir Medinsky said that Moscow wants to reach an agreement in the interests of both parties. The first round ended with the promise of more meetings "in the coming days".
- Before the meeting, Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky (who is outside the Ukrainian delegation in the negotiations),
directly appealed to Russian troops to stop fighting
- "Drop your weapons and leave", he said in a video - and
formally signed the application for membership of the European Union
. A senior EU official opened the door to discussion, but referred it to a summit in March.
- A Russian missile
killed dozens and injured hundreds of civilians
in Kharkiv, one of the Ukrainian cities hardest hit by fighting, the Interior Minister said.
- The
Air raid sirens sounded again in Kiev
, where explosions were heard. In Chernihiv, about 150 kilometers from the capital, a
missile hit a residential building
in the city center, causing a fire.
- The UN estimated that, since Thursday, more than
half a million people have left Ukraine
to neighboring nations. The European Union assured that refugees will be guaranteed
the right to live and work in the 27 member states
over the next three years.
PUB
Indian university students living in Kiev cross the border with Hungary on foot
Photo:¬†Attila KISBENEDEK / AFP
- Amnesty International denounced the
use of cluster bombs
(banned since 2010 by an international convention that neither Moscow nor Kiev have signed) in an attack on a daycare center in Okhtyrka, on Friday, arguing that the case should be investigated as a "war crime".
- Ukraine's Western allies reinforced the
sending weapons
for Ukrainian troops (Finland alone announced the sending of 2500 assault rifles, 150 thousand cartridges and 1500 anti-tank weapons).
- Turkey, with good connections to both Kiev and Moscow, will implement an international pact that will potentially
limit access of Russian ships to the Black Sea
fur
Dardanelles Strait, controlled by Ankara, to prevent an escalation of violence in Ukraine. The country officially recognized on Sunday "a state of war", which authorizes it, under the Montreaux Convention, to block vessels in the event of conflict.
- French President Emmanuel Macron spoke with Russian leader Vladimir Putin,
reiterating the demands
for Moscow to stop the offensive.
- Russia
banned 36 countries, including Portugal, from its airspace
. And fired the
flight cancellation
to and from Moscow.
- In sport, FIFA and UEFA
suspended Russian football clubs and the national team
of all international competitions. And the executive board of the International Olympic Committee has recommended that international sports federations ban Russian and Belarusian athletes from competing in events.
- The
Russian ruble (the country's currency) fell by 40 percent today
, after unprecedented international sanctions were announced against Moscow's financial system. The European Central Bank has revealed that the European branch of Russia's Sberbank is "bankrupt or likely to go bankrupt" due to deposit withdrawals.
- Ukraine demanded that the
Russia is expelled from Interpol
, accusing the country of using the International Criminal Police Organization to detain political opponents around the world, particularly in Ukraine.

Shakhtar Donetsk's coach, Italian Roberto de Zerbi, and the club's Brazilian players have already left Ukraine, fleeing following the invasion by Russia, the leader of the Ukrainian football championship reported today.
"Shakhtar's Brazilian players left Ukraine, with their families. Yesterday [Sunday], they traveled from Kiev to the border and today they crossed it. They are in Romania at the moment. They left the country together with the foreign players from Dynamo Kiev", explained the Donetsk club.
Shakhtar said the players' evacuation was possible thanks to the "personal intervention" of UEFA president Aleksander Ceferin, as well as the leaders of the Ukrainian Football Federation, Andrii Pavelko, and the Moldovan Football Federation, Leonid Oleinichenko.
Roberto de Zerbi published a message on social media, expressing himself happy to return to Italy, but noted that he will only be fully there "when Ukrainian players, Ukrainian friends and all the people of Ukraine are free too".
Of the 11 Brazilian players who play for Shakhtar Donetsk, there are five with experience in Portuguese football: Pedrinho (Benfica), Ismaily (Estoril Praia, Olhanense and Sporting de Braga), Fernando (Sporting), Dod√≥ (Vit√≥ria de Guimar√£es) and Marcos Ant√≥nio (Estoril Praia).
The Ukrainian football championship, which was supposed to resume last weekend after the winter break, was suspended on Thursday due to the imposition of martial law in the country, prompted by the start of the military offensive launched by Russia.
The competition is led by Shakhtar, a team that has played for years outside the city, considered the capital of the Donbass region, the initial focus of tension between the two countries, with a two-point advantage over Dynamo Kiev, the reigning champions, after playing 18 rounds.
Defender N√©lson Monte, who this season transferred from Rio Ave to Dnipro, third in the competition, seven points behind Shakhtar Donetsk, is the only Portuguese player competing in the Ukrainian league, having returned to Portugal on Saturday.
Russia launched a military offensive in Ukraine early Thursday morning, with ground forces and bombing of targets in several cities, which has already killed more than 350 civilians, including children, according to Kiev. The UN reported almost 500,000 people displaced to Poland, Hungary, Moldova and Romania.
Russian President Vladimir Putin said that the "special military operation" in Ukraine aims to demilitarize the neighboring country and that it was the only way for Russia to defend itself, with the Kremlin specifying that the offensive will last as long as necessary.
The attack was condemned by most of the international community and the European Union and the United States, among others, responded by sending weapons and ammunition to Ukraine and strengthening sanctions to further isolate Moscow.

Slovenia supports Kiev's accelerated entry into the EU
Lusa Agency
Feb 28, 2022
21:02
0
Comments
Photo EPA
The Slovenian Government today expressed its full support for Ukraine's entry into the European Union (EU), following an accelerated procedure, as requested by Kiev in the context of the Russian invasion.
"You have our full support", wrote Slovenian Prime Minister Janez Jansa on the social network Twitter, in response to a message in which his Ukrainian counterpart, Denys Shmyhal, assured that "the time has come to stamp on paper" that Ukrainians are an "inalienable part" of the European community.
Shmyhal indicated that his country applied to join the EU through a "special process", while Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky requested that approval of the process be "immediate".
Jansa had said on Sunday night that if Ukraine falls to the Russians, there will be a "domino effect" and Russia will also attack Moldova, Georgia and countries in the Western Balkans and Baltics, warning of what could be the start of a global conflict.
Last week, the Slovenian Prime Minister and his Polish counterpart, Tadeusz Morawiecki, proposed to the other EU countries that Ukraine join the EU by 2030.
Russia launched a military offensive in Ukraine early Thursday morning, with ground forces and bombing of targets in several cities, which has already killed more than 350 civilians, including children, according to Kiev. The UN reported more than 100,000 displaced people and almost 500,000 refugees in Poland, Hungary, Moldova and Romania.
Russian President Vladimir Putin said that the "special military operation" in Ukraine aims to demilitarize the neighboring country and that it was the only way for Russia to defend itself, with the Kremlin specifying that the offensive will last as long as necessary.
The attack was condemned by most of the international community and the European Union and the United States, among others, responded by sending weapons and ammunition to Ukraine and strengthening sanctions to further isolate Moscow.

translated_text:
The War
World
China calls for reduced tensions at the start of talks between Moscow and Kiev
Lusa Agency
Feb 28, 2022
14:22
0
Comments
China, which refuses to condemn Russia for the invasion of Ukraine, today called for a de-escalation of the conflict, at a time when the two parties began negotiations in Belarus.
In statements made today, Chinese Foreign Ministry spokesman Wang Wenbin did not condemn Russian President Vladimir Putin's recent decision to put his nuclear forces on alert, and called on the parties involved to "remain calm and exercise restraint to avoid further escalation."
China "supports all efforts to reduce tensions and reach a political solution", he added, while Russian and Ukrainian negotiators establish the first contacts in Belarus, a country allied with Moscow.
Since the beginning of the conflict, Chinese diplomacy has tried to maintain a balance between its political proximity to Moscow and its traditional defense of the "sovereignty and territorial integrity" of States.
Beijing refused to approve a UN Security Council resolution on Friday condemning Russian aggression, but it also did not vote against it, taking refuge in abstention.
The communist regime says it "understands" Russia's "reasonable" demands in terms of security, taking into account Moscow's complaints against NATO enlargement.
In the same statements, Wang also criticized the sanctions adopted by Western countries against Russia, believing that they will only create new problems.
China has not clarified whether or not it was warned about the invasion of Ukraine by Putin, who met with Chinese leader Xi Jinping in Beijing in early February, on the occasion of the opening of the Winter Olympic Games.
Beijing ignored warnings from Western intelligence services that a Russian attack on Ukraine was imminent, leaving its roughly 6,000 citizens living on Ukrainian territory under threat of war.
The Chinese embassy in Kiev initially asked its fellow citizens to identify themselves with a Chinese flag, and announced air evacuations to China.
But, on Saturday, the diplomatic mission reviewed its instructions and asked Chinese citizens to maintain maximum discretion.
Faced with the worsening situation on the ground, the Chinese embassy in Kiev abandoned its withdrawal plans on Sunday.
On social media, internet users report incidents between Ukrainians and Chinese living in the country.
"Ukrainians are in a difficult situation and are suffering a lot," said Chinese ambassador to Ukraine Fan Xianrong in a video broadcast on Sunday, in which he asked Chinese people "not to argue with locals."
"We have to understand their feelings," he added.
Russia launched a military offensive in Ukraine early Thursday morning, with ground forces and bombing of targets in several cities, which has already killed more than 350 civilians, including children, according to Kiev. The UN reported almost 500,000 people displaced to Poland, Hungary, Moldova and Romania.
Russian President Vladimir Putin said that the "special military operation" in Ukraine aims to demilitarize the neighboring country and that it was the only way for Russia to defend itself, with the Kremlin specifying that the offensive will last as long as necessary.
The attack was condemned by most of the international community and the European Union and the United States, among others, responded by sending weapons and ammunition to Ukraine and strengthening sanctions to further isolate Moscow.

translated_text:
The War
World
Zelensky reiterates call for Ukrainian EU membership "without delay"
Lusa Agency
Feb 28, 2022
10:24
0
Comments
PHOTO¬†EPA/PRESIDENTIAL PRESS SERVICE HANDOUT
Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky today reiterated his request to the European Union (EU) to accept "without delay" the accession of Ukraine, which has been fighting a Russian invasion for five days.
"We are approaching the EU regarding the integration of Ukraine without delay through a new special procedure," Zelensky said in a video speech, cited by the French agency AFP.
"I'm sure it's right. I'm sure it's possible," said the President of Ukraine.
Zelensky had already asked the EU for Ukraine's immediate integration on Saturday.
"It is time to end, once and for all, the long discussion and decide on Ukraine's accession to the European Union," Zelensky then wrote on the social network Twitter, after speaking on the phone with the President of the European Council, Charles Michel.
Ukraine's intention to join the EU was the source of a revolt that led to the removal of pro-Moscow President Viktor Yanukovych in 2014.
In reaction, Russia invaded and annexed the Crimean peninsula and fomented a separatist war in the Donbass, eastern Ukraine, which has caused more than 14,000 deaths since then.
Russia invaded Ukraine again last Thursday, but its troops have encountered resistance from the Ukrainians.
Russian President Vladimir Putin said that the "special military operation" in Ukraine aims to demilitarize the neighboring country and that it was the only way for Russia to defend itself, with the Kremlin specifying that the offensive will last as long as necessary.
The attack was condemned by most of the international community and led to harsh economic sanctions against Russian interests, including President Vladimir Putin and his head of diplomacy, Sergei Lavrov.
The EU and the United States, among others, also responded by sending arms and ammunition to Ukraine.
Volodymyr Zelensky

Kiev says it halted Russian advance and Russian troops are demoralized
Lusa Agency
Feb 28, 2022
08:06
0
Comments
Shutterstock photo
The Ukrainian military command assured today that the country's armed forces prevented Russian troops from advancing towards Kiev and that they are demoralized and suffered considerable casualties.
"All attempts by Russian occupation troops to achieve their goals have failed," Ukrainian army commander-in-chief Oleksandr Syrski said of Russian attempts to invade the outskirts of the capital.
Syrski, quoted by the UNIAN news agency, stressed that "the enemy suffered considerable casualties".
"The Russian troops are demoralized and exhausted. We have shown that we know how to defend our home from those who were not invited," said the general.
According to the army, all enemy troop movements are under control.
Russia launched a military offensive in Ukraine early Thursday morning, with ground forces and bombing of targets in several cities, which has already killed at least 352 civilians, including children, according to Kiev. The UN reported nearly 370,000 people displaced to Poland, Hungary, Moldova and Romania.
Russian President Vladimir Putin said that the "special military operation" in Ukraine aims to demilitarize the neighboring country and that it was the only way for Russia to defend itself, with the Kremlin specifying that the offensive will last as long as necessary.
The attack was condemned by most of the international community and the European Union and the United States, among others, responded by sending weapons and ammunition to Ukraine and strengthening sanctions to further isolate Moscow.

Ukraine's accession to the European Union (EU) requested by Kiev will be debated by the 27 member states of the community bloc, with the decision being taken unanimously, with Brussels reminding today that there is "a procedure to be respected".
Faced with Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky's call for immediate approval of the country's accession to the EU, the President of the European Council, Charles Michel, stressed, in an interview with the television channel BFM.TV, that this is "a debate that will take place".
Michel also said he intended to invite the Ukrainian leader to participate "on a regular basis" in European Council meetings, as already happened this month.
Charles Michel also recalled that there is a "strong" partnership agreement between the EU and Ukraine and that it can still be strengthened.
The President of the European Council recalled that Kiev must present a formal request, a request that the European Commission must analyze and issue an official recommendation, with the Member States making the decision.
For his part, the spokesperson for the European Commission, Eric Mamer, highlighted that "there is a procedure to respect".
Zelensky today reiterated his request to the EU to accept "without delay" the accession of Ukraine, which has been fighting a Russian invasion for five days.
"We are approaching the EU regarding the integration of Ukraine without delay through a new special procedure," Zelensky said in a video speech, cited by the French agency AFP.
"I'm sure it's right. I'm sure it's possible," said the President of Ukraine.
Zelensky had already asked the EU for Ukraine's immediate integration on Saturday.
Russia launched a military offensive in Ukraine early Thursday morning, with ground forces and bombing of targets in several cities, which has already killed civilians, including children, according to Kiev.
The UN reported several thousand people displaced to Poland, Hungary, Moldova and Romania.
Russian President Vladimir Putin said that the "special military operation" in Ukraine aims to demilitarize the neighboring country and that it was the only way for Russia to defend itself, with the Kremlin specifying that the offensive will last as long as necessary.
The attack was condemned by most of the international community and the European Union and the United States, among others, responded by sending weapons and ammunition to Ukraine and strengthening sanctions to further isolate Moscow.

A Ukrainian sailor who tried to sink a luxury yacht allegedly belonging to a Russian arms tycoon in the Spanish archipelago of Mallorca was traveling to his native Kiev today to join Ukrainian forces.

Taras Ostapchuk told The Associated Press that he expected to join Ukrainian soldiers or civilian militias trying to halt the advance of Russian troops toward the capital, Kiev, and other parts of their homeland.

The crew member of the luxury boat moored in Port Adriano, in Palma de Mallorca, had been arrested on Saturday after trying to sink the boat to harm his boss, whom he accuses of manufacturing helicopters with which his country is being attacked, according to the archipelago's online publications √öltima Hora and Di√°rio de Mallorca.
Taras Ostapchuk
Newspapers report that the Civil Guard arrested the sailor at noon on Saturday for damage caused to a yacht owned by Alexander Mijeev, a senior executive at a corporation that manufactures military equipment.
The arrested man explained in court that he opened several valves in the boat's engine room with the aim of sinking the yacht, after seeing attacks on civilian buildings in his city, Kiev, by the Russian army that invaded Ukraine.
Taras Ostapchuk warned his shipmates to abandon ship, but they notified port assistance services to prevent the ship from sinking.
When arrested, the saboteur claimed that the owner of the luxury yacht was a criminal who was enriching himself with the weapons that are killing his compatriots.
After being taken to court, he was provisionally released.
Russia launched a military offensive in Ukraine early Thursday morning, with ground forces and bombing of targets in several cities, which has already killed more than 350 civilians, including children, according to Kiev. The UN reported more than 100,000 displaced people and almost 500,000 refugees in Poland, Hungary, Moldova and Romania.
Russian President Vladimir Putin said that the "special military operation" in Ukraine aims to demilitarize the neighboring country and that it was the only way for Russia to defend itself, with the Kremlin specifying that the offensive will last as long as necessary.
The attack was condemned by most of the international community and the European Union and the United States, among others, responded by sending weapons and ammunition to Ukraine and strengthening sanctions to further isolate Moscow.

Zelensky reiterates call for Ukrainian EU membership "without delay"
"I'm sure it's right. I'm sure it's possible," said the President of Ukraine about his application to join the European Union.
President of Ukraine Volodymyr Zelensky
¬©¬†EPA/UKRAINIAN PRESIDENTIAL PRESS SERVICE
Dinheiro Vivo/Lusa
28¬†February,¬†2022¬†‚Ä¢¬†10:31
Share

Comment
Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky reiterated this Monday his request to the European Union (EU) to accept "without delay" the accession of Ukraine, which has been fighting a Russian invasion for five days.
"We are approaching the EU regarding the integration of Ukraine without delay through a new special procedure," Zelensky said in a video speech, cited by the French agency AFP.
"I'm sure it's right. I'm sure it's possible," said the President of Ukraine.
Zelensky had already asked the EU for Ukraine's immediate integration on Saturday.
Close

Subscribe
Thank you very much for your registration.
"It is time to end, once and for all, the long discussion and decide on Ukraine's accession to the European Union," Zelensky then wrote on the social network Twitter, after speaking on the phone with the President of the European Council, Charles Michel.
Speaking to the Euronews channel on Sunday night, the president of the European Commission, Ursula von der Leyen, said that Ukraine will join the EU, but gave no indication whether the process will be quick, as Zelensky demanded.
"Over time, Ukraine must join the EU, this country is one of us, and we want to see it in the European Union," he said.
Von der Leyen added that the EU has a process of integrating the Ukrainian market into the single market and very close cooperation with Ukraine in the area of ‚Äã‚Äãenergy.
Ukraine's intention to join the EU was the source of a revolt that led to the removal of pro-Moscow President Viktor Yanukovych in 2014.
In reaction, Russia invaded and annexed the Crimean peninsula and fomented a separatist war in the Donbass, eastern Ukraine, which has caused more than 14,000 deaths since then.
Russia invaded Ukraine again last Thursday, but its troops have encountered resistance from the Ukrainians.
Russian President Vladimir Putin said that the "special military operation" in Ukraine aims to demilitarize the neighboring country and that it was the only way for Russia to defend itself, with the Kremlin specifying that the offensive will last as long as necessary.
The attack was condemned by most of the international community and led to harsh economic sanctions against Russian interests, including President Vladimir Putin and his head of diplomacy, Sergei Lavrov.
The EU and the United States, among others, also responded by sending arms and ammunition to Ukraine.

China "supports all efforts to reduce tensions and reach a political solution", he added, while Russian and Ukrainian negotiators establish the first contacts in Belarus, a country allied with Moscow.

In the same statements, Wang also criticized the sanctions adopted by Western countries against Russia, believing that they will only create new problems.

The Chinese embassy in Kiev initially asked its fellow citizens to identify themselves with a Chinese flag, and announced air evacuations to China.
But, on Saturday, the diplomatic mission reviewed its instructions and asked Chinese citizens to maintain maximum discretion.
Faced with the worsening situation on the ground, the Chinese embassy in Kiev abandoned its withdrawal plans on Sunday.
On social media, internet users report incidents between Ukrainians and Chinese living in the country.

"We have to understand their feelings," he added.

Home
International
Roman Abramovich in Belarus to help with negotiations between Ukraine and Russia
At Kiev's request, the Russian millionaire, owner of Chelsea, is in Belarus to help with negotiations between Ukraine and Russia, with a view to ending the conflict between the two countries.
DN
28¬†February¬†2022¬†‚Äî¬†12:16
Facebook
Twitter
Comment
Share
Topics
Ukraine
Russia.
International
Related
ukraine
"It's a total war from Russia to Ukraine, we cannot stand idly by"

Ukraine. Membership of the European Union? "We have to deal with more practical things"
Russian millionaire Roman Abramovich is in Belarus to help with talks between Ukraine and Russia, which are taking place this Monday in the border city of Gomel. According to the news provided by the
The
Jesusalem Post
, the Chelsea owner participates in the negotiations, which aim to end the conflict between the two countries, at the request of the Ukrainians.
With Portuguese nationality
, awarded since April, under the law that benefits the descendants of Sephardic Jews expelled at the end of the 15th century, Abramovich has close ties with Jewish communities in Ukraine and Russia, according to the Israeli newspaper.
Ukraine's ambassador to Israel, Yevgen Kornichuk, declined to comment on Abramovich's involvement in the negotiations, but said: "we appreciate anyone who can help, if they have enough influence."
Close
