and receive information first hand.
Subscribe
The newspaper also states that Alexander Rodnyansky, a film producer nominated twice for an Oscar, is in close contact with Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky and his team. The producer told the publication that the Ukrainian government contacted him and other members of the Jewish community in Russia asking for intervention in resolving this conflict.
Rodnyansky says that he spoke with Abramovich and that the Russian millionaire decided to get involved in efforts to try to end the war.
"The Ukrainians were trying to find someone in Russia who could help find a peaceful solution," Rodnyansky explained. "They asked for help and Roman is the person who decided to help and mobilize support for a peaceful resolution," said the producer, quoted by The Post.
"I can confirm that Roman Abramovich was contacted by the Ukrainian side to help reach a peaceful resolution and that he has been trying to help ever since," said a spokesman for the Russian millionaire,
without, however, confirming that Abramovich is in Belarus.
Watch the video showing the start of negotiations here:
It should be noted that the owner of Chelsea, who is close to Russian President Vladimir Putin,
announced that he entrusted the leadership of the European and World football champion club to the administrators of his foundation
of charity.
"I have always made decisions with the best interests of the club in mind. I remain committed to those values. That is why I now entrust the trustees of the Chelsea Charitable Foundation with the management and care of Chelsea," Abramovich explained.
In a short statement published on the Londoners' website, Abramovich says he understands that "they are currently in the best position to look after the interests of the club, players, staff and fans".
Ukraine demands immediate ceasefire
Talks between delegations from the two countries have already begun, with Ukraine demanding an immediate ceasefire and the withdrawal of Russian troops from the country.
The Ukrainian delegation arrived in the area near the border between Ukraine and Belarus to participate in the negotiations at 9 am in Lisbon, the Ukrainian presidency said in a statement.
"The 'key issue' is the immediate ceasefire and withdrawal of troops from Ukrainian territory,"
refers to the same document.
‚ö°Ô∏è Russia-Ukraine talks kick off in Belarus
pic.twitter.com/zA6FMZN1LF
- Belarus MFA (@BelarusMFA)
February 28, 2022
Before the talks began, Kremlin adviser Vladimir Medinski said Moscow wants to find "an agreement" during talks with Kiev.
"Every hour that the conflict drags on, Ukrainian citizens and soldiers die. We agreed to reach an agreement but it must be in the interests of both parties," he said.
Medinski on Russian television.
"Drop your weapons, get out of here", Zelensky appeals to Russian soldiers
Also this Monday, the
Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky
, today called on Russian soldiers to lay down their arms, in a message released before talks with Moscow, in which Kiev demands the withdrawal of Russian forces. Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky, today called on Russian soldiers to lay down their arms, in a message released before talks with Moscow, in which Kiev demands the withdrawal of Russian forces.
"Drop your weapons, get out of here, don't believe your commanders, don't believe your propagandists. Just save your lives," Zelensky said in a message in Russian, quoted by the French agency AFP.
#BREAKING
Ukraine leader urges Russian soldiers to lay down arms
pic.twitter.com/V3iOzStBeB
- AFP News Agency (@AFP)
February 28, 2022
Zelensky today reiterated his request to the European Union (EU) to accept "without delay" the accession of Ukraine, which has been fighting a Russian invasion for five days.
"We are approaching the EU regarding the integration of Ukraine without delay through a new special procedure," Zelensky said in a video speech, cited by the French agency AFP.

Speaking to the Euronews channel on Sunday night, the president of the European Commission, Ursula von der Leyen, said that Ukraine will join the EU, but gave no indication whether the process will be quick, as Zelensky demanded.
"Over time, Ukraine must join the EU, this country is one of us, and we want to see it in the European Union," he said.
Von der Leyen added that the EU has a process of integrating the Ukrainian market into the single market and very close cooperation with Ukraine in the area of ‚Äã‚Äãenergy.
Ukraine's intention to join the EU was the source of a revolt that led to the removal of pro-Moscow President Viktor Yanukovych in 2014.
In reaction, Russia invaded and annexed the Crimean peninsula and fomented a separatist war in the Donbass, eastern Ukraine, which has caused more than 14,000 deaths since then.
Russia invaded Ukraine again last Thursday, but its troops have encountered resistance from the Ukrainians.
Russian President Vladimir Putin said that the "special military operation" in Ukraine aims to demilitarize the neighboring country and that it was the only way for Russia to defend itself, with the Kremlin specifying that the offensive will last as long as necessary.
The attack was condemned by most of the international community and led to harsh economic sanctions against Russian interests, including President Vladimir Putin and his head of diplomacy, Sergei Lavrov.
The EU and the United States, among others, also responded by sending arms and ammunition to Ukraine.

Minister of State and Foreign Affairs, Augusto Santos Silva, will receive, on Monday night, at Humberto Delgado Airport, national and Ukrainian citizens forced to leave the country in recent days due to the Russian invasion, organized by the Portuguese authorities.
In brief statements to the media, in a space inside the airport, Santos Silva highlighted the "completion of the first citizen repatriation operation" which, he stressed, "ends well".
With the closure of airspace, the first part of the journey had to be made over land, he said, adding that the groups crossed the Ukrainian border with Moldova and then headed to Romania, from where the air connection was organized.
"Some of these people stayed in Romania, while there is no possibility of returning to Kiev", said the official, also referring to the Portuguese ambassador to Ukraine and the remaining employees of the Kiev embassy. Other people will have traveled by their own means.
On this flight, therefore, "38 people arrive, Portuguese or Portuguese-Ukrainian citizens and their families". On board there is a pregnant woman at the end of her term which, according to Santos Silva, motivated the support of an INEM team during the trip.
The flight, operated by TAP, is expected in Lisbon at 11:10 pm. There, people will have support ‚Äúfrom SEF, the high commission for migration and Social Security‚Äù. For practical purposes, he says, the Portuguese embassy in Kiev is open, where there are three employees, of Ukrainian nationality.
Portuguese students have already crossed the border
The two Portuguese students who faced difficulties in crossing the border from Ukraine to Poland these days have already done so, reports Santos Silva. However, there are still around 40 Portuguese people in Ukraine "who have not yet decided to leave", and with whom the embassy maintains contact. On the other hand, around 75 Portuguese have already decided to leave the Ukrainian country since the Russian invasion began.
The Minister of Foreign Affairs assured this evening that "there is no limit" to the number of refugees to be received in Portugal.
"We are very used to the Ukrainian community, which is the first factor in the good integration of these people"
, he said, recalling that there are around 28,600 Ukrainians living in Portugal at the moment.
In reaction to Ukraine's request for membership in the European Union, which Volodymyr Zelensky wants to be approved immediately, Santos Silva says he agrees with Borrell - High Representative of the European Union for Foreign Affairs - who stated that this process would last at least two years. ‚ÄúWhat‚Äôs important is now,‚Äù he reiterated.

translated_text:
The War

Finland makes "historic" decision to supply weapons against invasion
Lusa Agency
Feb 28, 2022
18:03
0
Comments
Photo EPA
Finland - a member of the European Union, but not of NATO - today announced the "historic" decision to supply weapons to Ukraine, following the Russian invasion.
"Finland will provide military assistance to Ukraine. This is a historic decision for Finland," Finnish Prime Minister Sanna Marin said during a press conference.
Finland will supply 2,500 assault weapons, 150,000 ammunition, 1,500 rocket launchers and 70,000 field rations, said Defense Minister Antti Kaikkonen.
"Germany's change of line was particularly significant," said Kaikkonen, to explain the decision, also in line with neighboring Sweden.
Germany broke with its doctrine of not supplying weapons to countries in conflict, announcing the delivery to Kiev of 1,000 anti-tank rocket launchers, 500 Stinger surface-to-air missiles, nine artillery pieces, 14 armored vehicles and 10,000 tons of fuel.
Traditionally, Finland, which has more than 1,300 kilometers of border with its Russian neighbor, does not export weapons to conflict zones.
Until now, this Nordic country had only decided to send bulletproof vests, helmets and a mobile hospital to Ukraine, to support this country against the Russian army.
Swedish Prime Minister Magdalena Andersson announced on Saturday that the country has taken an "exceptional decision", unprecedented since 1939, when Sweden helped Finland invaded by the Soviet Union, and will send 5,000 anti-tank rocket launchers to Ukraine.
Russia launched a military offensive in Ukraine early Thursday morning, with ground forces and bombing of targets in several cities, which has already killed more than 350 civilians, including children, according to Kiev. The UN reported more than 100,000 displaced people and almost 500,000 refugees in Poland, Hungary, Moldova and Romania.
Russian President Vladimir Putin said that the "special military operation" in Ukraine aims to demilitarize the neighboring country and that it was the only way for Russia to defend itself, with the Kremlin specifying that the offensive will last as long as necessary.
The attack was condemned by most of the international community and the European Union and the United States, among others, responded by sending weapons and ammunition to Ukraine and strengthening sanctions to further isolate Moscow.

Livro: nas duas √∫ltimas semanas, entre o COVID, a situa√ß√£o na Ucr√¢nia e os outros afazeres pessoais, entre os quais o ser o Uber de servi√ßo da fam√≠lia (como t√£o bem define, o meu bom amigo Francisco, o trabalho de chofer que realizamos com a fam√≠lia) li com prazer ‚ÄúConservadorismo: A luta por uma tradi√ß√£o‚Äù, de Edmund Fawcet. Uma an√°lise hist√≥rica, ou como o autor o define, um ensaio hist√≥rico, que nos leva numa viagem ao pensamento conservador. Fawcet √© um liberal confesso, mas primeiro √© um estudioso da hist√≥ria das ideias, conseguindo, neste fant√°stico livro, ‚Äúler‚Äù o pensamento conservador, sem qualquer tipo de reserva. Aconselho vivamente.
2. Henry David Thoreau, foi um abolicionista americano, que escreveu um dos mais importantes livros de sempre. Uma obra que devia morar nas mesas-de-cabeceira de todas as casas: ‚ÄúA Desobedi√™ncia Civil‚Äù, escrito em 1849.

A primeira obriga√ß√£o das pessoas √© fazer o que elas acreditam ser o certo e n√£o seguir o que √© ditado pela maioria. Quando um governo √© injusto, as pessoas devem recusar-se seguir as suas determina√ß√µes. Ningu√©m √© obrigado a dedicar a sua vida a eliminar os males do mundo, mas h√° um imperativo moral de recusar participar neles. Isso inclui recusar fazer parte de uma institui√ß√£o injusta, em que se pode transformar um governo.
O pensador duvida da efic√°cia reformista quando esta sai de dentro da governan√ßa, argumentando que votar n√£o pode ser tudo, porque de alcance limitado. A participa√ß√£o cidad√£ √© de enorme import√¢ncia.
Obviamente que os tempos s√£o outros. Mas a possibilidade da desobedi√™ncia civil est√° sempre em cima da mesa.
Passemos a uma poss√≠vel defini√ß√£o, para que a quest√£o fique mais clara, e consideremos a desobedi√™ncia civil como a recusa activa e n√£o violenta de aceitar aquilo que os governos determinam. Ou seja, aquilo que considerado injusto deve ser combatido, nem que isso leve √† ilegalidade, ao n√£o cumprimento da lei.
A desobedi√™ncia civil, quando assumida por muitos, causa claras perturba√ß√µes, concentra a aten√ß√£o e descredibiliza quem governa, enquanto for√ßa o debate com o objectivo de provocar mudan√ßas fundamentais no todo social e na realidade onde vivemos. A desobedi√™ncia civil n√£o precisa ser extremista, nem deve recorrer √† viol√™ncia. Todos podemos ser activistas. Pequenas ac√ß√µes individuais podem levar a outras maiores, servindo de inspira√ß√£o, para os que podem n√£o ter a certeza, sobre o modo como canalizar as suas preocupa√ß√µes. S√£o in√∫meros os exemplos de desobedi√™ncia civil: a luta das mulheres inglesas pelo direito ao voto, a marcha do sal de Gandhi, a luta contra a segrega√ß√£o nos EUA, etc.
A recusa dos madeirenses em cumprir com as resolu√ß√µes governamentais, que exigem que se mostre, √† entrada dos estabelecimentos, certificados de vacina√ß√£o e/ou testes, √© um acto de desobedi√™ncia civil espont√¢neo.
Com isto, mostram os madeirenses, ser um povo maduro que distingue o que √© justo do injusto, do que faz sentido do que n√£o tem sentido nenhum.
3. N√£o se falando muito nisso, o primeiro pa√≠s ocupado por Moscovo, foi a Bielorr√∫ssia. Est√° ocupado por for√ßas locais que servem de suporte ao regime ilegal e antidemocr√°tico de Lukashenko e pelas For√ßas Armadas Sovi√©ticas, perd√£o, Russas. Foi por a√≠ que as hordas invasoras moscovitas entraram e descem na direc√ß√£o de Kyiv (forma correcta de escrever o nome da cidade ucraniana, Kiev √© o nome em russo). O presidente bielorrusso √© um fantoche que faz o que Putin manda. Um ditador que n√£o tem o seu povo do seu lado e que se presta a tudo em troca de protec√ß√£o.
Em 2020 escrevi nestas p√°ginas: ‚Äúum dia Vladimir Putin chegou ao poder na R√∫ssia e voltou a querer fazer desta uma pot√™ncia imperial. Recuperou o criador do fascismo crist√£o, Ivan Ilyn, desenterrou a Eur√°sia e iniciou o seu combate sem tr√©guas √† democracia, tal qual a conhecemos‚Äù. Na Ucr√¢nia, Putin, decidiu saltar um dos degraus que a dec√™ncia implica. ‚ÄúUltima ratio regum‚Äù, era uma frase que Lu√≠s XIV mandava gravar nos canh√µes do seu ex√©rcito. Nenhuma das raz√µes de Putin pega. A maioria da popula√ß√£o do Donbass era, em 2014, marginalmente, de origem ucraniana. Hoje n√£o ser√° assim, porque com a ocupa√ß√£o russa de Donetsk e Luhansk ‚Äî porque foi isso que aconteceu ‚Äî os ucranianos fugiram para o outro lado.
H√° povos que n√£o t√™m mem√≥ria, outros pouca, mas os ucranianos n√£o esquecem. Nos anos 30, os sovi√©ticos/russos, cometeram um dos maiores massacres da hist√≥ria, deixando morrer √† fome cerca de 6 milh√µes de ucranianos. Foi o Holodomor.
A conversa de que a Ucr√¢nia √© russa, √© puro revisionismo hist√≥rico. A Ucr√¢nia √© mesmo mais antiga do que a R√∫ssia. O Rus de Kiev (Rus √© uma palavra de origem n√≥rdica que pode significar ‚Äúremador‚Äù ou mesmo ‚Äúsueco‚Äù e que remete para a origem viking de Kyiv) formou-se no s√©culo IX. A funda√ß√£o da cidade vem do s√©culo V. Moscovo nem existia em nenhum dos dois momentos. Por casamento, integrou o Gr√£o-Ducado da Litu√¢nia durante dois s√©culos e, depois, andou de m√£o em m√£o entre polacos, russos e teut√≥nicos, at√© ter declarado a sua independ√™ncia, quando a R√∫ssia se retira da I Grande Guerra, depois da revolu√ß√£o de Outubro.
Alegar que se invade um pa√≠s para o desarmar e desnazificar, √© das coisas mais absurdas que se usaram at√© hoje para justificar este ‚Äúviva la muerte‚Äù decretado por Putin. O desarmamento, face √† despropor√ß√£o de meios, √© um absurdo. E a desnazifica√ß√£o, quando Zelensky √© judeu √©, t√£o s√≥, rid√≠culo.
N√£o h√° nada que justifique isto, a n√£o ser a loucura de um fascista, que quer o ressurgir do imp√©rio russo. Para Putin a maior trag√©dia do s√©culo XX foi a queda da Uni√£o Sovi√©tica. Ter pa√≠ses democr√°ticos, ou em vias de o serem, nas suas fronteiras, assusta-o. Tem medo que a democracia se pegue ao seu pa√≠s. Tem medo que os russos sejam contaminados pelo exemplo da liberdade e se tornem exigentes.
4. E tudo isto induz ao medo. Depois da pandemia, chega o medo da guerra, o medo do nuclear. Eu j√° vivi este medo. O medo dos blocos. Ocidente de um lado e URSS do outro. A Guerra Fria. Assisti ao desastre que foi a descoloniza√ß√£o portuguesa e √†s diversas guerras civis que se seguiram nos novos pa√≠ses. √Ä fome na Eti√≥pia, √† guerra na Som√°lia, Afeganist√£o, Jugosl√°via, √† queda do Muro de Berlim que levou √† derrocada da URSS. A este medo estou habituado. O medo √© terr√≠vel se nos deixarmos dominar por ele. Mas muitas das vezes √© o que nos faz avan√ßar. A UE nasceu devido ao medo de uma nova guerra em solo europeu. N√≥s n√£o morremos de amor pelos espanh√≥is, os franceses n√£o morrem de amor por ningu√©m, os suecos e os dinamarqueses tratam-se com superioridade, os checos odeiam os eslovacos e vice-versa, os italianos do norte n√£o podem com os do sul e ‚Äúversa-vice‚Äù, os austr√≠acos sentem-se superiores aos alem√£es porque j√° foram um imp√©rio e os alem√£es t√™m hist√≥ria recente, etc. O que nos uniu foi o medo. translated_text:
Chronicles
Civil Disobedience
Nuno Morna
Feb 28, 2022
02:00
0
Comments
1. Book: in the last two weeks, between COVID, the situation in Ukraine and other personal tasks, including being the family's Uber service (as my good friend Francisco so well defines it, the chauffeur work we do with the family) I read with pleasure ‚ÄúConservatism: The fight for a tradition‚Äù, by Edmund Fawcet. A historical analysis, or as the author defines it, a historical essay, which takes us on a journey into conservative thought. Fawcet is a self-confessed liberal, but first he is a student of the history of ideas, managing, in this fantastic book, to ‚Äúread‚Äù conservative thought, without any type of reservation. I strongly advise.
2. Henry David Thoreau, was an American abolitionist, who wrote one of the most important books of all time. A work that should live on the bedside tables of every home: ‚ÄúCivil Disobedience‚Äù, written in 1849.
Thoreau argues that conscience is above the dictates of laws. He criticizes American institutions and social policies, mainly slavery and the Mexican-American War, and leaves the basis of what he considers to be the need to resist, against what is wrong, on an individual decision basis.
For Thoreau, the government is rarely useful and holds power based on a majority, this being the representation of the strongest group, and not because it holds the most legitimate point of view. People's first obligation is to do what they believe is right and not follow what is dictated by the majority. When a government is unjust, people must refuse to follow its orders. No one is obliged to dedicate their life to eliminating the evils of the world, but there is a moral imperative to refuse to participate in them. This includes refusing to be part of an unjust institution, which a government can become.
The thinker doubts the reformist effectiveness when it comes from within governance, arguing that voting cannot be everything, because it is limited in scope. Citizen participation is of enormous importance.
Obviously times are different. But the possibility of civil disobedience is always on the table.
Let's move on to a possible definition, so that the issue becomes clearer, and consider civil disobedience as the active and non-violent refusal to accept what governments determine. In other words, what is considered unfair must be combated, even if it leads to illegality, non-compliance with the law.
Civil disobedience, when assumed by many, causes clear disturbances, focuses attention and discredits those who govern, while forcing debate with the aim of bringing about fundamental changes in the social whole and in the reality in which we live. Civil disobedience does not have to be extremist, nor does it have to resort to violence. We can all be activists. Small individual actions can lead to larger ones, serving as inspiration for those who may be unsure of how to channel their concerns. All of this, in turn, can help pave the way for a greater understanding of the whole, leading to necessary changes.
There are countless examples of civil disobedience: the struggle of English women for the right to vote, Gandhi's salt march, the fight against segregation in the USA, etc.
The refusal of Madeirans to comply with government resolutions, which require that vaccination and/or test certificates be shown at the entrance of establishments, is an act of spontaneous civil disobedience.
With this, Madeirans show that they are a mature people who distinguish between what is fair and unfair, what makes sense and what makes no sense at all.
3. Not to mention much about it, the first country occupied by Moscow was Belarus. It is occupied by local forces that support Lukashenko's illegal and undemocratic regime and by the Soviet, sorry, Russian Armed Forces. It was from there that the invading Muscovite hordes entered and descended towards Kyiv (the correct way to write the name of the Ukrainian city, Kiev is the name in Russian). The Belarusian president is a puppet who does what Putin says. A dictator who does not have his people on his side and who will do anything in exchange for protection.
In 2020 I wrote on these pages: "one day Vladimir Putin came to power in Russia and once again wanted to make it an imperial power. He recovered the creator of Christian fascism, Ivan Ilyn, dug up Eurasia and began his relentless fight against democracy, as we know it." At the end of January (the 31st) I returned to the subject and made a mistake, not considering it possible that Putin would go that far. In the rest I was and I am right. And, the previous week, the 24th had touched on the subject.
In Ukraine, Putin decided to jump one of the steps that decency implies. ‚ÄúUltima ratio regum‚Äù, was a phrase that Louis XIV had engraved on the cannons of his army. This was intended to say that the Kings' final argument was the use of weapons. There were so many arguments that could still have been used.
None of Putin's reasons stick. The majority of the population of Donbass was, in 2014, marginally, of Ukrainian origin. Today it won't be like that, because with the Russian occupation of Donetsk and Luhansk ‚Äî because that's what happened ‚Äî the Ukrainians fled to the other side.
There are people who have no memory, others little, but Ukrainians don't forget. In the 1930s, the Soviets/Russians committed one of the biggest massacres in history, starving around 6 million Ukrainians to death. It was the Holodomor.
The talk that Ukraine is Russian is pure historical revisionism. Ukraine is even older than Russia. Kievan Rus (Rus is a word of Norse origin that can mean ‚Äúrower‚Äù or even ‚ÄúSwedish‚Äù and which refers to Kyiv's Viking origin) was formed in the 9th century. The city's foundation dates back to the 5th century. Moscow didn't even exist at either time. Through marriage, she was part of the Grand Duchy of Lithuania for two centuries and then went hand in hand between Poles, Russians and Teutonics, until she declared her independence, when Russia withdrew from the First World War, after the October revolution.
Claiming that a country is invaded to disarm and denazify it is one of the most absurd things that has been used to date to justify this ‚Äúviva la muerte‚Äù decreed by Putin. Disarmament, given the disproportion of resources, is absurd. And denazification, when Zelensky is Jewish, is simply ridiculous.
There is nothing that justifies this, other than the madness of a fascist, who wants the resurgence of the Russian empire. For Putin, the greatest tragedy of the 20th century was the fall of the Soviet Union. Having democratic countries, or about to be, on your borders scares you. He is afraid that democracy will spread to his country. He is afraid that Russians will be contaminated by the example of freedom and become demanding.
4. And all of this induces fear. After the pandemic, the fear of war arrives, the fear of nuclear weapons. I have already experienced this fear. The fear of blocks. West on one side and USSR on the other. The Cold War. I was born in the year of the Cuban missile crisis. The Prague Spring. I witnessed the disaster that was Portuguese decolonization and the various civil wars that followed in the new countries. To the famine in Ethiopia, the war in Somalia, Afghanistan, Yugoslavia, the fall of the Berlin Wall that led to the collapse of the USSR. I'm used to this fear. Fear is terrible if we let ourselves be dominated by it. But many times it is what moves us forward. The EU was born out of fear of a new war on European soil. It was one of humanity's greatest civilizational advances. We are not in love with the Spanish, the French are not in love with anyone, the Swedes and Danes treat each other with superiority, the Czechs hate the Slovaks and vice versa, the Italians in the north cannot deal with those in the south and vice versa, the Austrians feel superior to the Germans because they were once an empire and the Germans have a recent history, etc. What brought us together was fear. The fear that these things could lead to or lead to armed conflicts. Of course, afterwards, we had the bonus of trade relations, of the more powerful countries contributing more, helping the less developed ones (yes, I know that Portugal is not an example in this, but I met another miserable Portugal), of the differences beginning to attenuate.
I already know this fear.

translated_text:
Faced with Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky's call for immediate approval of the country's accession to the EU, the President of the European Council, Charles Michel, stressed, in an interview with the television channel BFM.TV, that this is "a debate that will take place".
Michel also said he intended to invite the Ukrainian leader to participate "on a regular basis" in European Council meetings, as already happened this month.
Charles Michel also recalled that there is a "strong" partnership agreement between the EU and Ukraine and that it can still be strengthened.
The President of the European Council recalled that Kiev must present a formal request, a request that the European Commission must analyze and issue an official recommendation, with the Member States making the decision.
For his part, the spokesperson for the European Commission, Eric Mamer, highlighted that "there is a procedure to respect".
Zelensky today reiterated his request to the EU to accept "without delay" the accession of Ukraine, which has been fighting a Russian invasion for five days.
"We are approaching the EU regarding the integration of Ukraine without delay through a new special procedure," Zelensky said in a video speech, cited by the French agency AFP.
"I'm sure it's right. I'm sure it's possible," said the President of Ukraine.
Zelensky had already asked the EU for Ukraine's immediate integration on Saturday.
Russia launched a military offensive in Ukraine early Thursday morning, with ground forces and bombing of targets in several cities, which has already killed civilians, including children, according to Kiev.
The UN reported several thousand people displaced to Poland, Hungary, Moldova and Romania.
Russian President Vladimir Putin said that the "special military operation" in Ukraine aims to demilitarize the neighboring country and that it was the only way for Russia to defend itself, with the Kremlin specifying that the offensive will last as long as necessary.
The attack was condemned by most of the international community and the European Union and the United States, among others, responded by sending weapons and ammunition to Ukraine and strengthening sanctions to further isolate Moscow.

translated_text:
The War
World
Turkey recognizes "war" and may block Russian ships
Lusa Agency
Feb 28, 2022
07:33
0
Comments
Russian warship passing through the Bosphorus Strait days before the war, on February 16th.¬† ¬†Photo¬†EPA/ERDEM SAHIN
Turkey officially recognized on Sunday "the state of war" between Russia and Ukraine, which authorizes it, under the Montreaux Convention, to limit the two belligerents' access to the Dardanelles Strait, which connects to the Black Sea.
"The situation in Ukraine has turned into war. Turkey will transparently implement all the provisions of the Montreux Convention," Turkish Foreign Minister Mevl√ºt Casuvoglu said in an interview with CNN.
Since the beginning of Russian aggression against Ukraine, the Ukrainian ambassador in Ankara, Vasyl Bodnar, has called on Turkey to close the Dardanelles and Bosphorus straits to Russian ships.
Although an ally of Kiev and a member of NATO, Turkey did not immediately respond to this request.
Ankara controls access to the Black Sea through the Montreux Treaty, signed in 1936, which guarantees the free movement of merchant ships in peacetime and gives it the right to block warships in the event of conflict, in particular if Turkey itself is threatened.
Mevl√ºt Casuvoglu had previously indicated that "experts [were] studying whether a state of war existed from a legal point of view".
In an interview published Friday in the Turkish daily Hurriyet, the minister explained that "Turkey applies the Montreux Treaty: measures can be taken against belligerents in a conflict in which Turkey does not participate."
"Turkey can prevent the transit of warships through the strait. But it must also allow the belligerents' ships to return to their bases if they so request. Our experts are studying whether a state of war exists from a legal point of view. If that is the case, the process will begin," he said.
At least six Russian warships and a submarine have passed through the Bosphorus and Dardanelles in the past two weeks, returning from the Mediterranean.
Russia launched a military offensive in Ukraine early Thursday morning, with ground forces and bombing of targets in several cities, which has already killed around 200 civilians, including children, according to Kiev. The UN reported nearly 370,000 people displaced to Poland, Hungary, Moldova and Romania.
Russian President Vladimir Putin said that the "special military operation" in Ukraine aims to demilitarize the neighboring country and that it was the only way for Russia to defend itself, with the Kremlin specifying that the offensive will last as long as necessary.
The attack was condemned by most of the international community and the European Union and the United States, among others, responded by sending weapons and ammunition to Ukraine and strengthening sanctions to further isolate Moscow.

translated_text:
"The
level of resource mobilization, everything is well underway. Delivery requires important logistics that Member States must organize, and it must be done quickly. But we are at war and I am not going to give any information that could serve the side we are facing. I am sure that Russia would be very happy to know where and how the help we are going to give to the Ukrainian army to defend itself will be passed, said Josep Borrell.
The High Representative of the European Union (EU) for Foreign and Security Policy was speaking at a press conference in Brussels, after a videoconference of defense ministers of the 27, held to discuss at a "more technical" level the implementation of the historic support package of 450 million in weapons for Ukraine agreed the day before by the foreign ministers.
In the same statements, Borrell recalled that Moscow has already warned that it will attack "any person or entity that transports this aid", which is why he declined to provide "any details that could be useful to them".
Borrell, who the day before had thanked Poland for offering itself as a logistical 'hub' for the transfer of material assistance to Ukraine, limited himself to saying that, "naturally", it "will pass through countries that have a border with Ukraine, that's no secret", and added that it was decided to create a cell, which will work in coordination with NATO, to monitor "Ukraine's requests and needs" and the routing of armament, which includes defensive material, namely anti-tank, and weapons and ammunition of all calibers.
The High Representative highlighted that defense ministers worked hard today "in coordinating efforts to ensure maximum effectiveness" not only in the mobilization and delivery of weapons acquired with funding of 450 million euros, but also those supplied to the Ukrainian armed forces by several Member States on a bilateral basis.
Borrell revealed that Ukraine has also requested more support in terms of military information, and the EU is already mobilizing its satellite center, based in Madrid, to "work in this direction".
The head of European diplomacy also indicated that an assessment of the evolution of the military situation on the ground was made, based on information collected by several Member States, and the conclusion is that "Russia's military campaign is becoming increasingly brutal".
But, he stressed, that "the Ukrainian armed forces are fighting with courage" and "whoever said that the fall of Kiev was a matter of hours" was wrong, as the capital continues to resist, as do Mariupol and Kharkiv.
However, the High Representative recognized that "it is vital" to support the Ukrainian armed forces in the face of an aggressor with many more military assets.
"They need ammunition, defensive weapons of any type, and we will provide them," he said, reiterating that Sunday's decision by the EU, supported "by everyone, all Member States", to provide military assistance to a third country targeted by aggression is historic and marks a new chapter in European construction.
On Sunday, in what was their fourth meeting in the space of a week, the 27 Foreign Ministers approved a 450 million euro package to finance the supply of lethal weapons to the Ukrainian army, which is fighting against the Russian invasion, in a decision that marks a historic turning point in the EU.
Russia launched a military offensive in Ukraine early Thursday morning, with ground forces and bombing of targets in several cities, which has already killed more than 350 civilians, including children, according to Kiev.
The UN reported more than 100,000 displaced people and almost 500,000 refugees in Poland, Hungary, Moldova and Romania.
Russian President Vladimir Putin said that the "special military operation" in Ukraine aims to demilitarize the neighboring country and that it was the only way for Russia to defend itself, with the Kremlin specifying that the offensive will last as long as necessary.
The attack was condemned by most of the international community and the European Union and the United States, among others, responded by sending weapons and ammunition to Ukraine and strengthening sanctions to further isolate Moscow.

Russian businessman Mikhail Fridman, owner of the LetterOne group, which owns the Minipre√ßo stores (a Dia group business in Portugal), is on the European Union's sanctions list. The information is released this Monday by the Spanish newspaper
El
Country
.
Related
Belarus ready for Moscow-Kiev talks
DIA Group says it is not affected by sanctions on Russian shareholder Mikhail Fridman
Minipre√ßo wins Flavor of the Year 2022 with 14 private label products
Born in western Ukraine in 1964, Fridman will not be able to enter any European Union country and his will be frozen. The Russian businessman and the Luxembourg-based LetterOne group will not be able to sell their 77.7% stake in the Spanish-based retail group. The Russian businessman will also not be able to profit from the group's activities.
The European Union considers that Fridman "materially and financially supported and also benefited from decisions regarding the annexation of Crimea [by Russia in 2014]". The document also claims that the businessman "also supported policies that undermine or threaten the territorial integrity, sovereignty and independence of Ukraine".
The sanction was made public after the Russian businessman called for an end to the armed conflict, according to a letter sent last weekend to employees of the LetterOne group.

"I was born in Western Ukraine and lived there until I was 17. My parents are Ukrainian citizens and live in Lviv, my favorite city. However, I have also spent much of my life as a citizen of Russia, building and growing businesses. I am deeply connected to the Ukrainian and Russian people and see the current conflict as a tragedy for both. Although a solution seems terribly far away, I can only join those who are fervently calling for an end to the bloodshed, and I am sure that that my partners share my opinion."
According to the magazine
Forbes
, Mikhail Fridman is the 128th richest person in the world, with a fortune valued at 11.4 billion dollars (10.12 billion dollars). In addition to the LetterOne group, Fridman is one of the founders of Alfa bank, also the target of European Union sanctions.

translated_text:
The War
World
Moscow refuses to reveal positions leading to negotiations with Kiev
Lusa Agency
Feb 28, 2022
11:42
0
Comments
PHOTO¬†EPA/SERGEY GUNEEV / SPUTNIK / KREMLIN POOL
Russia today refused to reveal the position that will lead to negotiations with Ukraine on the war it started in the neighboring country, justifying that "they must be conducted in silence".
"I will not announce the positions we have. Negotiations must be conducted in silence", said Kremlin spokesman (Presidency), Dmitri Peskov, in his daily meeting with the press, cited by the French agency AFP.
"Let the negotiators sit down," he added.
Talks between the two sides are taking place today, in an unspecified location near Ukraine's border with Belarus, a country allied with Moscow.
The Ukrainian Presidency said today that it will demand an immediate ceasefire and the withdrawal of Russian troops from Ukraine.
The Kiev delegation includes Defense Minister Oleksiy Reznikov, presidential advisor Mikhail Podolyak, Servant of the People party leader David Arakhamia, and Deputy Foreign Minister Nikolay Tochitsky, among others, according to Ukrainian news agency Urkinform.
The Russian delegation is led by presidential advisor Vladimir Medinsky and includes officials from the Ministries of Foreign Affairs and Defense, according to the state agency TASS.
Medinsky said that Russia is available for an agreement that is in the interests of both parties.
The Ukrainian Presidency announced on Sunday that it agreed to participate in the talks after mediation by Belarusian President Alexander Lukashenko.
The Ukrainian Presidency said Lukashenko promised that "all planes, helicopters and missiles parked on Belarusian territory will remain on the ground during the trip, talks and return of the Ukrainian delegation."
The talks take place on the fifth day of fighting in Ukraine, which has already caused hundreds of deaths and hundreds of thousands of refugees.
In the meeting with journalists, the Kremlin spokesman denied that the Russian military had targeted civilian areas, despite abundant evidence that residential buildings, schools and hospitals had been hit since the invasion began in the early hours of Thursday.
Dmitri Peskov claimed that the civilian casualties resulted from members of right-wing Ukrainian nationalist groups using civilians as shields and placing military equipment in populated areas.
Peskov's claims could not be independently confirmed and contradict statements by Ukrainian authorities, who accused Russian troops of attacks on civilian targets.
Peskov also said that Vladimir Putin is working on an economic response to the heavy Western sanctions imposed on Russia after the invasion of Ukraine.
"The President is in the Kremlin, he is dealing with the economy," Peskov said.
"The sanctions are heavy, they are problematic (...), but Russia has all the potential to compensate for the damage," he added.
The European Union (EU) and several countries have imposed harsh economic sanctions against Russian interests, including banking and aviation, in addition to targeting leaders such as President Vladimir Putin himself and his head of diplomacy, Sergei Lavrov.
The invasion was ordered by Putin, after weeks of high tension due to the concentration of tens of thousands of Russian troops on the border with the neighboring country.

Photo¬†EPA/SERGEY DOLZHENKO
Ukraine's Interior Ministry said on Sunday that 352 Ukrainian civilians were killed during the Russian invasion, including 14 children.
Ukrainian authorities also reported that at least 1,684 injuries were reported, including 116 children.
The Ministry's statement did not indicate the number of casualties among the Ukrainian armed forces.
Russia has stated that troops are targeting only Ukrainian military facilities and has said that the Ukrainian civilian population is not in danger.
Moscow has not released any information on troop casualties.
Russia launched a military offensive in Ukraine early Thursday morning, with ground forces and bombing of targets in several cities. The UN reported nearly 370,000 people displaced to Poland, Hungary, Moldova and Romania.
Russian President Vladimir Putin said that the "special military operation" in Ukraine aims to demilitarize the neighboring country and that it was the only way for Russia to defend itself, with the Kremlin specifying that the offensive will last as long as necessary.
The attack was condemned by most of the international community and the European Union and the United States, among others, responded by sending weapons and ammunition to Ukraine and strengthening sanctions to further isolate Moscow.

translated_text:
"I will not announce the positions we have. Negotiations must be conducted in silence", said Kremlin spokesman (Presidency), Dmitri Peskov, in his daily meeting with the press, cited by the French agency AFP.
"Let the negotiators sit down," he added.
Talks between the two sides are taking place today, in an unspecified location near Ukraine's border with Belarus, a country allied with Moscow.
The Ukrainian Presidency said today that it will demand an immediate ceasefire and the withdrawal of Russian troops from Ukraine.
The Kiev delegation includes Defense Minister Oleksiy Reznikov, presidential advisor Mikhail Podolyak, Servant of the People party leader David Arakhamia, and Deputy Foreign Minister Nikolay Tochitsky, among others, according to Ukrainian news agency Urkinform.
The Russian delegation is led by presidential advisor Vladimir Medinsky and includes officials from the Ministries of Foreign Affairs and Defense, according to the state agency TASS.
Medinsky said that Russia is available for an agreement that is in the interests of both parties.
The Ukrainian Presidency announced on Sunday that it agreed to participate in the talks after mediation by Belarusian President Alexander Lukashenko.
The Ukrainian Presidency said Lukashenko promised that "all planes, helicopters and missiles parked on Belarusian territory will remain on the ground during the trip, talks and return of the Ukrainian delegation."
The talks take place on the fifth day of fighting in Ukraine, which has already caused hundreds of deaths and hundreds of thousands of refugees.
In the meeting with journalists, the Kremlin spokesman denied that the Russian military had targeted civilian areas, despite abundant evidence that residential buildings, schools and hospitals had been hit since the invasion began in the early hours of Thursday.
Dmitri Peskov claimed that the civilian casualties resulted from members of right-wing Ukrainian nationalist groups using civilians as shields and placing military equipment in populated areas.
Peskov's claims could not be independently confirmed and contradict statements by Ukrainian authorities, who accused Russian troops of attacks on civilian targets.
Peskov also said that Vladimir Putin is working on an economic response to the heavy Western sanctions imposed on Russia after the invasion of Ukraine.
"The President is in the Kremlin, he is dealing with the economy," Peskov said.
"The sanctions are heavy, they are problematic (...), but Russia has all the potential to compensate for the damage," he added.
The European Union (EU) and several countries have imposed harsh economic sanctions against Russian interests, including banking and aviation, in addition to targeting leaders such as President Vladimir Putin himself and his head of diplomacy, Sergei Lavrov.
The invasion was ordered by Putin, after weeks of high tension due to the concentration of tens of thousands of Russian troops on the border with the neighboring country.

translated_text:
A
This information was provided by the French Minister for Energy Transition, Barbara Pompili, on the sidelines of an extraordinary Council meeting on the energy situation in Europe following the crisis in Ukraine, in Brussels, on which occasion she revealed to journalists that the EU will "work on this connection for Ukraine".
"Today, [the European grid] is no longer connected to the Russian electricity grid [so] there is no concern about the days to come, as it works in isolated mode, but Kiev made this request to be connected to the European grid," added the official, speaking on behalf of the French presidency of the Council of the EU.
Furthermore, "we will also discuss the country's fuel supplies", said Barbara Pompili.
This synchronization of electrical networks would facilitate exchanges between countries and make it easier to overcome electricity supply problems for Ukraine.
The position comes after, this afternoon, the European Network of Transmission System Operators (ENTSO-E) announced that it had received an "urgent request" from the Ukrainian electrical operator "for an emergency synchronization of the electrical system [...] with the electrical system of Continental Europe".
The area covered by ENTSO-E includes a total of 35 EU and partner countries.
Ukraine was synchronized with the Russian power grid until the invasion of Moscow last week.
Also speaking on the sidelines of the Energy Council, the European supervising commissioner, Kadri Simson, said she hoped that ministers would agree to Ukraine's request "as soon as possible".
The Russian invasion of Ukraine has caused a sharp increase in the price of gas in the EU and in global oil prices, an increase that appears in the context of an already existing spike in energy prices, given the crisis in the sector.
Last Thursday, meeting at an extraordinary summit in Brussels, EU leaders called for action at all levels and invited the Commission to propose emergency measures, particularly for the energy sector, which is why today's meeting of responsible ministers came about.
At today's meeting, EU ministers will also review the impact on energy markets of Western sanctions against Russia, such as limits on access to financing and the export of hydrocarbons.
Russia is responsible for more than 40% of the EU's annual natural gas imports, but according to Brussels, the Union has sufficient reserves to face possible cuts, and is still trying to diversify its supply sources.
Russia launched a military offensive in Ukraine early Thursday morning, with ground forces and bombing of targets in several cities, an attack that was condemned by most of the international community and led to heavy sanctions.

Turkey will limit Russia's access to the Black Sea
Erdogan invoked articles of the 1936 international agreement that limit the passage of some Russian ships through Turkish straits.
DN

Facebook

The president of Turkey, Tayyip Erdogan, announced that he will implement a pact on maritime passage through its straits in order to avoid an escalation of war, according to Reuters.
Erdogan said Turkey cannot abandon its ties with Russia or Ukraine, having described Russia's invasion of Ukraine as a "war" on Sunday, allowing him to invoke articles of the 1936 international agreement that limit the passage of some Russian ships through Turkish straits.
The Turkish president criticized what he called the "indecisive" stance of the United States and Western powers regarding the invasion of Ukraine, saying the West's approach was a sign of a falling international order.
Close

and receive information first hand.

Erdogan said that Turkey will not give up its commitments to its partners, including NATO, but that it also cannot go back on "national interests" in its region, having repeated, even so, that he found the Russian invasion unacceptable.
Russia launched a military offensive in Ukraine early Thursday morning, with ground forces and bombing of targets in several cities, which has already killed more than 350 civilians, including children, according to Kiev. The UN reported almost 500,000 people displaced to Poland, Hungary, Moldova and Romania.
Russian President Vladimir Putin said that the "special military operation" in Ukraine aims to demilitarize the neighboring country and that it was the only way for Russia to defend itself, with the Kremlin specifying that the offensive will last as long as necessary.
The attack was condemned by most of the international community and the European Union and the United States, among others, responded by sending weapons and ammunition to Ukraine and strengthening sanctions to further isolate Moscow.

The President of Russia, Vladimir Putin, was today stripped by World Taekwondo of the honorary ninth dan black belt, which had been awarded to him in 2013.

The United States has banned all transactions with Russia's central bank with immediate effect, the US Treasury Department announced today.
This is a sanction of unprecedented severity taken in coordination with several of Washington's allies in response to Russia's invasion of Ukraine.
This decision has the effect of immobilizing all assets that Russia's central bank holds in the United States, and also prohibits any financial institution or North American company from carrying out transactions or operations with the central bank, says the statement released before the opening of markets, which limits Moscow's ability to defend its currency and sustain the economy.
Russia launched a military offensive in Ukraine early Thursday morning, with ground forces and bombing of targets in several cities, which has already killed around 200 civilians, including children, according to Kiev. At 2:45 pm (Lisbon time), the Dow Jones lost 1.21% to 33,646.12 points and the Nasdaq index, dominated by the technology sector, fell 0.76% to 12,590.71 points.
The broader S&P 500 index registered a drop of 1.06% to 4,338.02 points.
The New York stock exchange was trading with risk aversion, awaiting the negotiations that are taking place between Russian and Ukrainian delegations and in which the Kiev government will ask for a ceasefire.
Trading in the markets still registered high volatility, with the Vix index increasing 12% during the beginning of the session, initiated in the intricacies of the sanctions announced by Washington and other Western governments against the Russian financial system.
Investors looked for safe assets, such as gold, which was at $1,916 per ounce, and 10-year Treasury bonds, which were at 1.877%.
However, concern about the reduction in fuel supply boosted the price of a barrel of Texas oil by 4.2%, which was at $95.45.
Companies in the security sector, such as Lockheed Martin (3.60%) and Raytheon (2.23%), recorded high increases.
At the same time and in the final stretch of the session, the main European stock exchanges remained in 'red'.
The EuroStoxx 600 index lost 1.02% and London fell 1.31%, Paris 2.69%, Frankfurt 1.75%, Madrid 1.23% and Milan 2.65%.
On the Lisbon stock exchange, the PSI20 index reversed its opening trend and registered a slight increase, of 0.18% to 5,505.27 points, with nine listed up and 10 down. BCP led the declines and lost 5.39% to 0.16 euros and EDP Renov√°veis ‚Äã‚Äãrose 7.44% to 21.38 euros.
Russia launched a military offensive in Ukraine early Thursday morning, with ground forces and bombing of targets in several cities, which has already killed more than 350 civilians, including children, according to Kiev. The UN reported more than 100,000 displaced people and almost 500,000 refugees in Poland, Hungary, Moldova and Romania.
The attack was condemned by most of the international community and the European Union and the United States, among others, responded by sending weapons and ammunition to Ukraine and strengthening sanctions to further isolate Moscow.

Ainda assim, ao quinto dia de confrontos, a cidade de Kiev come√ßa a sentir mais dificuldades. As car√™ncias de alimenta√ß√£o, combust√≠vel e medicamentos come√ßam a asfixiar a capital do pa√≠s.
7h58 - Parlamento da Let√≥nia autoriza cidad√£os a combaterem na Ucr√¢nia
O Parlamento da Let√≥nia aprovou esta segunda-feira uma lei que permite aos cidad√£os let√µes combaterem ao lado dos ucranianos para defenderem o pa√≠s.
O pa√≠s b√°ltico faz fronteira com a R√∫ssia e fez parte da Uni√£o Sovi√©tica, tendo o seu territ√≥rio sido ocupado desde 1940. Tornou-se independente em 1991 e √© membro da UE e NATO desde 2004.
7h50 - R√∫ssia pretende chegar a acordo com a Ucr√¢nia nas conversa√ß√µes, diz negociador russo
Vladimir Medinsky, interlocutor de Moscovo nas negocia√ß√µes desta segunda-feira, adianta que a R√∫ssia est√° interessada em chegar a um acordo que seja do interesse de todas as partes. As negocia√ß√µes devem come√ßar pelas 12h00 locais (9h00 em Lisboa).
7h45 - Voo de repatriamento de portugueses sai de Bucareste esta tarde
Os cerca de 50 portugueses que sa√≠ram da Ucr√¢nia nos √∫ltimos dias em miss√µes organizadas pela embaixada portuguesa em Kiev ser√£o repatriados esta segunda-feira. O voo ir√° sair de Bucarestem, na Rom√©nia, hoje √†s 17h00, apurou a RTP.
7h34 - Ucr√¢nia desmente informa√ß√£o e garante que ex√©rcito russo n√£o controla central nuclear de Zaporizhzhya
A Energoatom,¬†empresa estatal nuclear da Ucr√¢nia,  negou nesta segunda-feira os relatos de que a R√∫ssia conrole a central nuclear de Zaporizhzhia, a maior da Europa.
7h30 - Ex√©rcito russo afirma que civis podem abandonar Kiev "de livre vontade"
O ex√©rcito russo adiantou esta segunda-feira que os civis na capital podem abandonar a cidade de livre vontade, acusando as autoridades ucranianas de usarem a popula√ß√£o como "escudo humano".
"Todos os civis na cidade podem deixar a capita ucraniana de livre vontade a partir da estrada Kiev-Vassylkiv", adiantou o porta-voz do Minist√©rio russo da Defesa.
7h23 - R√∫ssia diz que suas tropas tomam duas cidades no sudeste da Ucr√¢nia
As for√ßas russas dizem controlar a partir de agora as cidades de Berdyansk e Enerhodar, na regi√£o de Zaporizhzhya. O minist√©rio russo da Defesa adianta que controla tamb√©m a √°rea em volta da central nuclear de Zaporizhzhya.
7h11 - Vaticano diz-se pronto para "facilitar o di√°logo"
O secret√°rio de Estado do pa√≠s, cardeal Pietro Parolin, que fica apenas atr√°s do papa na hierarquia do Vaticano, mostrou-se dispon√≠vel para mediar o conflito e diz estar convencido de que "h√° sempre espa√ßo para negocia√ß√µes".
"Nunca √© demasiado tarde. Porque a √∫nica forma razo√°vel e construtiva de dirimir as diferen√ßas √© atrav√©s do di√°logo, como n√£o se cansa de repetir o Papa", afirmou o n√∫mero dois do Vaticano em entrevista a v√°rios jornais italianos.
Ponto de situa√ß√£o
- Neste quinto dia de conflito, est√° marcado para esta segunda-feira um encontro negocial que ir√° decorrer na fronteira entre a Bielorr√∫ssia e a Ucr√¢nia. O presidente ucraniano disse n√£o acreditar num resultado positivo das negocia√ß√µes, mas prometeu que ‚Äúvai tentar‚Äù;
- Numa conversa telef√≥nica no domigno √† noite com o primeiro-ministro brit√¢nico, Boris Johnson, o presidente ucraniano afirmou que as pr√≥ximas 24 horas ser√£o "decisivas" para o conflito.
- O presidente russo, Vladimir Putin, ordenou ao comando militar do seu
pa√≠s a coloca√ß√£o das for√ßas de dissuas√£o em alerta, o que engloba as
capacidades bal√≠sticas;
- Bruxelas aprovou um novo pacote de san√ß√µes a Moscovo. A UE vai financiar a compra de armas para a Ucr√¢nia e fechar o espa√ßo a√©reo a avi√µes russos. Os ministros dos Neg√≥cios Estrangeiros da UE deram aval a um pacote de 450 milh√µes de euros para financiar o fornecimento de armas letais ao ex√©rcito ucraniano;
- Militares ucranianos descreveram quarto dia de guerra como "dif√≠cil". A capital ucraniana permanece sob controlo das autoridades do pa√≠s, mas o presidente da C√¢mara de Kiev diz que a cidade est√° "cercada" por for√ßas russas. As imagens de sat√©lite da empresa Maxar mostram um grande n√∫mero de tropas terrestres russas em dire√ß√£o a Kiev;
- O Minist√©rio da Sa√∫de da Ucr√¢nia confirmou a morte de 352 civis, incluindo 14 crian√ßas, desde o in√≠cio da invas√£o russa da Ucr√¢nia;
- As Na√ß√µes Unidas confirmaram que a ofensiva russa j√° provocou 368 mil refugiados. A Europa calcula que este n√∫mero possa chegar aos sete milh√µes de pessoas;
- Mais de 17 pa√≠ses europeus, incluindo Portugal, decidiram vedar os respetivos espa√ßos a√©reos a voos russos.
- Realiza-se esta segunda-feira uma Assembleia Geral das Na√ß√µes Unidas extraordin√°ria para discutir o conflito na Ucr√¢nia. A reuni√£o foi aprovada e tenta contornar o veto russo no Conselho de Seguran√ßa.

Report
World
|
War in Ukraine
Russian offensive in Ukraine. The evolution of war to the minute
by RTP
Want to share this article?
cancel
Reuters
Here we follow all developments regarding the military offensive launched by Russia in Ukraine.
More updates
01h00 - State of play
- First Portuguese repatriation operation landed in Lisbon
The first flight of the repatriation operation for Portuguese, Portuguese-Ukrainians and family members landed at Humberto Delgado airport, in Lisbon. According to the Portuguese Minister of Foreign Affairs, due to the closure of airspace in Ukraine, ‚Äúthe first part of the journey had to be done by land‚Äù.
"The two groups [of Portuguese] crossed the Ukrainian border with Moldova and then headed to Romania, where they converged. From Romania, from Bucharest, it was possible to organize an air connection, and it is this flight that now ends", Augusto Santos Silva told journalists.
‚ÄúThere are 38 people on this flight‚Äù, and ‚Äúsome will need support‚Äù, warned Santos Silva. There are still 40 people trying to return to Portugal. The two Portuguese students who had been trying to enter Poland for three days have now managed to "cross the Ukrainian part of the border".
- President of Ukraine accuses Russia of war crimes
The president of Ukraine accuses Russia of committing war crimes and bombing Ukrainian cities, while the first round of peace negotiations took place this Monday.
In statements he made during the night, Volodymir Zelensky said he had no doubt that this was a form of pressure from Moscow.
- At least 11 dead in bombings in Kharkiv, says city governor
At least eleven people died in Russian bombings of residential areas in Kharkiv this Monday. Regional governor Oleg Sinegoubov states, however, that the number of victims is expected to be much higher.
- New round of negotiations will take place ‚Äúsoon‚Äù
"The parties have established a series of priorities and issues that require certain decisions" before a second round of talks, said Mikhailo Podoliak, one of the Ukrainian negotiators, cited by the AFP agency. His Russian counterpart, Vladimir Medinsky, said the new meeting would take place "soon" on the border between Poland and Belarus.
- Putin says Ukrainian neutrality and recognition of Crimea are fundamental to any agreement
In conversation with French President Emmanuel Macron, the Russian president said that an agreement with Ukraine would only be possible if Kiev was neutral, ‚Äúdenazified‚Äù and ‚Äúdemilitarized‚Äù and if Russian control over annexed Crimea was formally recognized. "Russia is open to dialogue with representatives of Ukraine and hopes that the (talks) will lead to the desired results," Putin told Macron.
- President of Ukraine signs formal application for membership of the European Union
Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky today signed the country's formal application for membership in the European Union. The Ukrainian Parliament speaks of a ‚Äúhistoric moment‚Äù. Ursula Von der Leyen defends Ukraine's entry into the European Union. In an interview with Euronews, the president of the European Commission says that, after years of cooperation, it is time for Ukraine to be part of the EU.
- ICC investigates Russia's alleged war crimes and crimes against humanity
The International Criminal Court will open an investigation into alleged war crimes by Russia on Ukrainian territory. The period to be investigated dates back to the Russian occupation of Crimea in 2014.
The Ukrainian president confirmed that he had initiated proceedings at the International Criminal Court in The Hague, rejecting Moscow's justification for invading Ukraine five days ago in order to prevent a genocide in the Donbass region.
With this process, Ukraine asks the ICC to order Russia to immediately end military operations in Ukraine.
- Foreigners who want to fight for Ukraine do not need a visa
Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky signed a temporary decree that exempts all foreigners who are willing to join the Ukrainian International Defense Legion and fight against Russian forces from visa requirements.
The Ukrainian Defense Minister directly appealed to Russian soldiers fighting in Ukraine to lay down their arms, guaranteeing them full amnesty and monetary compensation.
For security reasons, the United States expelled 12 Russian diplomats from North American territory. They have to leave the United States by next Monday.
Russia launched a military offensive in Ukraine early Thursday morning, with ground forces and bombing of targets in several cities, which has already killed more than 350 civilians, including children, according to Kiev. The UN reported more than 100,000 displaced people and almost 500,000 refugees in Poland, Hungary, Moldova and Romania.
00:30 - Ukrainian president accuses Russia of war crimes
The Ukrainian president accuses Russia of committing war crimes and bombing Ukrainian cities, while the first round of peace negotiations took place this Monday. In statements he made during the night, Volodymir Zelensky said he had no doubt that this was a form of pressure from Moscow.
00:15 - Paulo Fonseca praises the struggle of the Ukrainian people
The former Shaktar Donetsk and FC Porto coach described what the repatriation trip was like, how he experienced the first days of the attack and the emotions of having left friends in Ukraine who are fighting against the Russian army.
00H00 - First repatriation flight arrived at Lisbon airport
Thirty-eight Portuguese, Profit-Ukrainians and Ukrainians landed at Humberto Delgado airport in Lisbon, including Paulo Fonseca and other members of the Shaktar Donetsk team.
Another 40 Portuguese continue to try to leave Ukraine.
11:32 pm ‚Äì Ukrainian ambassador to the United States denounces use of vacuum pump
Russia used a thermobaric bomb, also called a vacuum bomb, this Monday, warned the Ukrainian ambassador to the USA, Oksana Markarova.
"They used the vacuum pump today, which is actually prohibited by the Geneva Convention," Markarova said after briefing members of the US Congress. "The devastation that Russia is trying to inflict on Ukraine is great", highlighted the diplomat.
11:23 pm ‚Äì Zelensky asks Russia to close ports and airports
In a video message, Volodimir Zelenskiy said that Russia had launched 56 rocket attacks and fired 113 cruise missiles at Ukraine in the last five days.
Ukraine's president also called for the closure of "all ports" and "airports in the world" to Russian vessels and aircraft.¬†"Entry to this State must be closed in all ports, all channels and all airports in the world", highlighted the Ukrainian head of state in a video published on the social network Facebook.
Zelensky called for "considering a total closure of the skies to Russian missiles, planes and helicopters."
"This evil, armed with missiles, bombs and artillery, must be stopped immediately and destroyed economically, to show that humanity is capable of defending itself", he highlighted.
In the same video message, the Ukrainian President asked Russia "not to waste time" in Ukraine, assuring that Russian bombing will not make Kiev accept Moscow's terms for a truce.
10:51 pm ‚Äì First Portuguese repatriation operation about to end
You are about to complete the first repatriation operation of Portuguese, Portuguese-Ukrainians and family members.
According to the Portuguese Minister of Foreign Affairs, due to the closure of airspace in Ukraine, ‚Äúthe first part of the journey had to be done by land‚Äù.
"The two groups [of Portuguese] crossed the Ukrainian border with Moldova and then headed to Romania, where they converged. From Romania, from Bucharest, it was possible to organize an air connection, and it is this flight that now ends", Augusto Santos Silva told journalists.
The MNE stated that ‚Äúthere are 38 people on this flight‚Äù, and ‚Äúsome will need support‚Äù. For this reason, the relevant services are located at the airport, including the SEF, the High Commission for Migrations and Social Security.
According to Augusto Santos Silva, around 40 people of Portuguese and Portuguese descent remain in Ukraine, including journalists, who will soon need support from the Portuguese Government to leave the country.
10:38 pm ‚Äì There are millions of Ukrainians on their way to the borders to escape the war
The Russian invasion is causing millions of Ukrainians to leave and move towards the borders. RTP has been following the journey of a family from the outskirts of Kiev, who has been trying to reach Poland for three days. One of many stories of those who cross paths on the roads of Ukraine.
10:19 pm ‚Äì Portuguese people of African origin remain stranded on the border between Ukraine and Poland
There are young Portuguese people who, despite having all their documents, are being stopped at the border between Ukraine and Poland. Two Portuguese medical students have been trying to leave for three days. They told RTP that they are being blocked because, at the border, the authorities discriminate against Africans and Asians.
10:14 pm - Romania prepared to receive 5 million Ukrainians
Romania is prepared to receive five million Ukrainian refugees. With a 600-kilometer border with Ukraine, the border posts open doors to those fleeing the war. It is estimated that around 67 thousand people have already crossed the borders, but the vast majority continue their journey to other destinations in Europe.
10:00 pm ‚Äì Romania is accepting Ukrainian refugees
Bucharest is available to receive around 500 thousand Ukrainians and this Monday alone more than 1,800 people arrived, 500 more people than on Sunday. The Romanian Government is "mobilizing" and facilitating the entry of refugees from Ukraine.
9:36 pm ‚Äì Portuguese are donating food, clothing and medicine
In Portugal, a wave of solidarity was generated towards the Ukrainian people. Thousands of people are donating food, clothing and medicine. Several trucks leave Portugal this Monday, heading to Lviv, near the border with Poland.
9:26 pm ‚Äì ICC will investigate alleged ‚Äúwar crimes‚Äù and ‚Äúcrimes against humanity‚Äù
The Prosecutor General of the International Criminal Court (ICC) today announced the opening "as soon as possible" of an investigation into alleged "war crimes" and "crimes against humanity" in the conflict that has ravaged Ukraine since 2014.
"I am convinced that there is a reasonable basis to believe that alleged war crimes and crimes against humanity have been committed in Ukraine" since 2014, said the prosecutor general of the international body based in The Hague (Netherlands), Karim Khan.
9:14 pm ‚Äì Ukrainians arrive in Lisbon and reunite with family members
Some of the Ukrainians who fled the war are arriving in Portugal. This Monday, once again, at Lisbon airport, moved Ukrainian families met again. On the other hand, many young Ukrainians now want to return to defend the country where they were born.
9:07 pm ‚Äì Slovenia supports Kiev‚Äôs accelerated entry into the EU
The Slovenian Government today expressed its full support for Ukraine's entry into the European Union, following an accelerated procedure, as requested by Kiev in the context of the Russian invasion.
"You have our full support", wrote Slovenian Prime Minister Janez Jansa on the social network Twitter, in response to a message in which his Ukrainian counterpart, Denys Shmyhal, assured that "the time has come to stamp on paper" that Ukrainians are an "inalienable part" of the European community.
Shmyhal indicated that his country applied to join the EU through a "special process", while Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky requested that approval of the process be "immediate".
8:56 pm ‚Äì Biden reassures Americans about Moscow‚Äôs nuclear threats
President Joe Biden sought to reassure the American people about the threat of the use of nuclear weapons by the Russians.
8:52 pm ‚Äì RTP Correspondents. Russian-Ukrainian negotiations started with parties very far apart
Negotiations between Russia and Ukraine did not make any progress in this first meeting between the parties.
8:44 pm ‚Äì Sent RTP. The inhabitants' priority is to reach the border
More than paying attention to what is happening in negotiations with the Russians, the concern of Ukrainians in the city of Lviv is getting to the border and leaving the country.
8:38 pm ‚Äì Sent RTP. Kiev remains under attack
The sirens sounded again this Monday, but during the day there was some calm in Kiev, which led many residents to try to leave the city.
8:34 pm ‚Äì Kiev residents try to leave the city
After 38 hours of extreme curfew, Kiev residents are now trying to leave the city. The railway station was left in a chaotic situation with the desperation of those who wanted to leave the city. But there are also those who are returning to defend the capital.
8:25 pm ‚Äì Three cities were targeted on the fifth day of the Russian offensive in Ukraine
This Monday marks the fifth day of the Russian offensive in Ukraine. Three cities were targeted, including the outskirts of the capital Kiev.
In Karkiv, at least 11 people died and dozens were injured. The Ukrainian authorities claim to have killed more than five thousand Russian soldiers so far.
Moscow admits casualties but continues without revealing numbers.
8:20 pm ‚Äì Ukrainians and Russians have not reached any agreement
The Russian president says he agrees to stop attacks on civilians and open humanitarian corridors in Ukraine. The promise was made to Emmanuel Macron by Putin after the first negotiations in Belarus.
Ukrainians and Russians were, however, unable to reach any agreement in today's talks. The Ukrainian president took the opportunity to formalize his request for membership in the European Union.
8:10 pm ‚Äì Four oligarchs express opposition to the war in Ukraine
Dissenting voices are beginning to be heard among Russian billionaires against Vladimir Putin's offensive in Ukraine, both inside and outside the country. In the last few hours, four of them, one of whom is of Ukrainian origin, expressed without mincing words their opposition to the war or the economic chaos that threatens them.
One of them, Evgeny Lebedev, the Russian-British businessman son of a former KGB operative and made lord by Prime Minister Boris Johnson, wrote an open letter to Vladimir Putin published this Monday in one of his newspapers.
In another British newspaper, Lubov Chernikhin, married to a former Putin finance minister and ex-banker, applauded all efforts by the West to resist the Kremlin and Putin and called for sanctions ‚Äúas heavy as possible‚Äù against the Russian regime and those who support it.
8:00 pm ‚Äì Price of milling wheat reaches a record of 322.5 euros per ton
The price of milling wheat for delivery in March reached a record high of 322.5 euros per ton, a value boosted by the conflict between Ukraine and Russia.
The blockade of Ukrainian ports, taking into account that Kiev is the fifth largest exporter of wheat in the world, is one of the reasons that explains the evolution recorded, according to an Inter-Corte expert to Agence France Presse (AFP).
7:55 pm ‚Äì Twelve members of the Russian diplomatic mission to the UN ordered to leave the US
Twelve members of the Russian diplomatic mission to the UN were ordered today to leave the United States by the end of March, announced Russia's ambassador to the United Nations, Vassily Nebenzia.
7:43 pm - Portuguese government guarantees "comfortable reserves" of gas and fuel for more than 90 days
The Portuguese Minister of the Environment, Jo√£o Pedro Matos Fernandes, said today that Portugal has "very comfortable reserves" of gas, as well as "public reserves of 90 days" of fuel, in view of possible constraints due to the Russian invasion of Ukraine.
"Portugal does not depend at all on the gas pipeline that comes from Russia, all it uses is LNG, which arrives in Sines and is re-gasified and used in our country. Three days ago, we had gas reserves at 80% and today the number is certainly higher", so "we have very comfortable reserves", declared Jo√£o Pedro Matos Fernandes.
"If we move on to diesel, gasoline and crude oil, there are public reserves of 90 days of supply, in addition to that of companies", he stated.
"It is rather a question of price [...], but it is not immediate" and of "instability of prices themselves", he admitted.
7:40 pm ‚Äì Pentagon says Russia‚Äôs nuclear posture remains despite the threat
The United States said today that it had not detected any "concrete" change in Russia's nuclear posture since Russian President Vladimir Putin put his deterrent forces on high alert, in the context of the invasion of Ukraine.
"We are always monitoring and watching as closely as possible" and "we have not seen anything concrete [in Russia's nuclear posture] as a consequence of its decision. At least not yet," a senior Pentagon official told reporters.
Reaffirming that Russia has "never" been threatened by NATO, the Pentagon admits that it is "difficult to know what is behind" Putin's order, but considers that "the mere fact of evoking" or "threatening" the "use of nuclear forces", being "useless", represents at the same time "a significant escalation".
The same source also assured that, at this stage, the Belarusian military does not appear to have entered Ukraine to reinforce Russian forces.
7:36 pm ‚Äì Order of Nurses available for ‚Äúpro bono‚Äù aid mission in Ukraine
Members of the governing bodies of the Order of Nurses are available to join a "pro bono" aid mission in Ukraine.
The president, Ana Rita Cavaco, interviewed by Antena 1, explains that the objective is to help with the rescue, provide care and bring refugees to Portugal.
The president says that the Order of Nurses announced its availability to join a possible mission with the Ministry of Foreign Affairs.
7:28 pm ‚Äì Russia threatens countries that supply ‚Äúlethal weapons‚Äù to Ukraine
The Russian Foreign Ministry warned today that anyone supplying lethal weapons to Ukraine will be held accountable if they are used against the Russian military in that country.
Moscow also warned that the measures taken by the European Union against Russia will deserve a ‚Äúharsh response‚Äù.
7:20 pm ‚Äì Alarms ring again in the city of Lviv
Alarms sounded again in the Ukrainian city of Lviv. On loudspeakers, authorities ordered the population to gather.
Lviv has been the epicenter of the mass flight of Ukrainian citizens. To make the situation at train stations more controlled, teams of volunteers are providing support to those displaced by war, essentially bringing food.
The process of transporting these people to the border is being speeded up as much as possible, but the huge queues of cars are making efforts difficult.
There are reports of people taking 70 hours to cross the border, at a time when heavy snowfall made the journey even more difficult.
RTP's special envoy to Lviv, Jos√© Rodrigues dos Santos, is following the latest developments.
7:12 pm ‚Äì Germany sends warplanes and maritime control to the Baltic Sea area
Germany is sending warplanes and maritime patrol aircraft for a reconnaissance mission in the Baltic Sea area, the German NATO mission announced today on Twitter.
Early in the morning, Germany had sent six new warships, four of them to the Baltic Sea.
7:06 pm ‚Äì African Union calls for an end to ‚Äúshockingly racist‚Äù discrimination at borders
The African Union today classified it as "shockingly racist" that African citizens are prevented from fleeing the conflict in Ukraine, calling on all countries to respect international law and support those fleeing war, regardless of their race.
"Reports that Africans are being singled out for unacceptable unequal treatment would be shockingly racist and in violation of international law," said the president of Senegal and acting president of the African Union (AU), Macky Sall, and the president of the AU Commission, Moussa Faki Mahamat, in a statement.
The two leaders therefore call on "all countries to respect international law and show the same empathy and support to all people fleeing war, regardless of their racial identity."
6:51 pm ‚Äì Spain will send more troops to the border with Russia to protect allies
Spain decided to send more troops to the borders of its NATO allies with Russia, at a time when it began to apply sanctions agreed by the EU, criticized by the socialists' far-left partners in the Government.
The Spanish Minister of Defense, Margarita Robles, announced this reinforcement of the Spanish deployment in the conflict zone, although without detailing the number of troops or material that will be deployed to the Russian border.
"NATO's position is to reinforce the borders of allied countries, and Spain will undoubtedly be there", assured the government official, quoted by the Efe news agency.
6:35 pm ‚Äì New negotiations without guaranteed success
The first round of negotiations between Russia and Ukraine lasted about five hours. In today's conversations, the two sides found some points on which they could approach each other.
Success is not, however, guaranteed, given that both Kiev and Moscow have divergent demands.
RTP's correspondent in Russia, Evgueni Mouravitch, is following all developments.
18:05 ‚Äì Alex Hook, the Ukrainian soldier who posts videos on TikTok for his daughter
Alex Hook is a Ukrainian soldier who posts videos on the TikTok platform so his four-year-old daughter can follow him from a distance. Videos of his choreography have already gone viral on social media.
