5:59 pm ‚Äì Ursula von der Leyen supports Ukraine‚Äôs membership of the EU
Ursula Von der Leyen defends Ukraine's entry into the European Union. In an interview with Euronews, the president of the European Commission says that, after years of cooperation, it is time for Ukraine to be part of the EU.
5:55 pm ‚Äì FIFA and UEFA suspend Russian clubs and teams from all competitions
Russian football clubs and teams were suspended this Monday from all competitions, by joint decision of UEFA and FIFA, due to the country's military offensive in Ukraine.
"Following the initial decisions adopted by the FIFA Council and the UEFA Executive Committee, which provided for the adoption of additional measures, FIFA and UEFA today jointly decided that all Russian teams, whether national teams or clubs, should be suspended from participating in FIFA and UEFA competitions until further notice", reads the statement from the two bodies that govern world and European football.
"Football is totally united and in total solidarity with the people affected in Ukraine. The two presidents hope that the situation in Ukraine will improve significantly and quickly, so that football can once again be a vector of unity and peace among people", concludes the statement from the structures chaired by Gianni Infantino and Aleksander Ceferin.
5:47 pm ‚Äì PAR predicts a large number of refugees due to family connections in Portugal
The Refugee Support Platform (PAR) warned today that Portugal is expected to receive a "vastly higher number" of refugees from Ukraine compared to the last relocation programs and urged the government to clarify reception procedures.
5:40 pm ‚Äì United Kingdom announces new sanctions and condemns ‚Äúbarbaric‚Äù bombings
The UK will approve new powers to stop Russian banks making payments in pounds and freeze assets of three new institutions, while condemning the "barbaric" bombings in Ukraine.
In a statement in Parliament, Foreign Minister Liz Truss announced that Sovcombank, Otkritie FC Bank and VEB.RF will be covered by British sanctions and that she is working on a total asset freeze on all Russian banks.
Restrictions on payments, he stressed, "will harm Russia's ability to trade with the rest of the world" as more than 50% of Russian trade is done in dollars or pounds sterling.
The Government, he explained, is trying to "isolate all Russian companies from access to UK capital markets" and "prevent the Russian state from financing sovereign debt here".
Truss also stressed that British authorities are identifying homes, yachts and private jets of Russian oligarchs in the United Kingdom to be seized under new economic crime legislation to be presented in Parliament.
5:19 pm ‚Äì New round of negotiations will take place ‚Äúsoon‚Äù
"The parties have established a series of priorities and issues that require certain decisions" before a second round of talks, said Mikhailo Podoliak, one of the Ukrainian negotiators, cited by the AFP agency.
His Russian counterpart, Vladimir Medinsky, said the new meeting would take place "soon" on the border between Poland and Belarus.
4:58 pm ‚Äì Russian Ambassador to the UN: ‚ÄúUkrainian provocations have not stopped yet‚Äù
Vasily Nebenzya spoke this Friday at the United Nations General Assembly and considered that the ‚ÄúUkrainian provocations have not yet stopped‚Äù.
4:45 pm ‚Äì ‚ÄúSaving Ukraine is saving democracy‚Äù, says Ukraine‚Äôs ambassador to the UN
Sergiy Kyslytsya compares the Russian offensive to what happened in World War II. For the ambassador, ‚Äúone of the most recent examples of human suffering and war crimes‚Äù is the bombing, still today, of the Ukrainian city of Kharkiv.
4:33 pm ‚Äì Moscow and Kiev prepare ‚Äúsecond round‚Äù of negotiations, Russia advances
Russia and Ukraine are planning a ‚Äúsecond round‚Äù of negotiations, a Ukrainian negotiator told France Presse.
However, there is still no date set for the new meeting.
TASS, the Russian news agency, said that today's talks on the Belarusian border between the two parties have already ended.
4:25 pm ‚Äì FIFA suspends Russia from international championships
FIFA has suspended Russian teams from participating in international football championships until further notice, Reuters reported.
Russia was supposed to face Poland on March 24, which is no longer expected to happen.
4:21 pm ‚Äì President of Ukraine signs formal application for membership of the European Union
Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky today signed the country's formal application for membership in the European Union. The Ukrainian Parliament speaks of a ‚Äúhistoric moment‚Äù.
President
@ZelenskyyUa
has signed application for the membership of
#Ukraine
in the European Union.
This is a historic moment!
pic.twitter.com/rmzdgIwArc
‚Äî Verkhovna Rada of Ukraine (@ua_parliament)
February 28, 2022
4:16 pm ‚Äì EU arms supply well underway, but under secrecy, says Borrell
The head of European diplomacy assured that the mobilization and delivery of weapons to Ukraine, discussed today by EU defense ministers, is well underway, but declined to give details, as "Russia would very much like" to know them.
"In terms of mobilizing resources, everything is well underway. The delivery requires important logistics that the Member States have to organize, and it has to be done quickly. But we are in a war and I am not going to give any information that could be of use to the side we are facing. I am sure that Russia would be very happy to know where and how the help we are going to give will pass" to the Ukrainian army to defend itself, said Josep Borrell.
In the same statements, Borrell recalled that Moscow has already warned that it will attack "any person or entity that transports this aid", which is why he declined to provide "any details that could be useful to them".
4:12 pm ‚Äì Russia has banned its residents from transferring money abroad
Furthermore, the Kremlin has decided that Russian exporters will be forced to convert 80 percent of their revenues into rubles, the Russian currency.
4:01 pm ‚Äì Putin says Ukrainian neutrality and recognition of Crimea are fundamental to any agreement
In conversation with French President Emmanuel Macron, the Russian president said that an agreement with Ukraine would only be possible if Kiev was neutral, ‚Äúdenazified‚Äù and ‚Äúdemilitarized‚Äù and if Russian control over annexed Crimea was formally recognized.
"Russia is open to dialogue with representatives of Ukraine and hopes that the (talks) will lead to the desired results," Putin told Macron.
Delegations from Russia and Ukraine continue to meet in the Belarusian city of Gomel, near the border with Ukraine. Kiev seeks an "immediate ceasefire" and the withdrawal of Russian forces.
3:43 pm ‚Äì Ant√≥nio Guterres tells the UN General Assembly that the idea of nuclear conflict is ‚Äúsimply inconceivable‚Äù
Ant√≥nio Guterres spoke a few minutes ago at the extraordinary session of the United Nations General Assembly, calling it a ‚Äúchilling development‚Äù that Russian nuclear forces are now on high alert.
The UN Secretary-General also said that the idea of ‚Äã‚Äãa nuclear conflict was ‚Äúsimply inconceivable‚Äù.
For Guterres, we are currently facing ‚Äúwhat could easily become the worst humanitarian and refugee crisis in Europe in decades‚Äù.
According to the secretary-general, the UN is already aware of serious damage to residential buildings, civil infrastructure and other non-military targets in Ukraine.
Ant√≥nio Guterres therefore asks all parties involved in the crisis in Ukraine to ensure safe and rapid humanitarian access to those who need it.
The official highlighted ‚Äúthree very concrete actions‚Äù implemented by the UN, the first of which is the provision of 20 million dollars from the emergency fund for contact lines in Donetsk, Luhansk and other parts of the country, ‚Äúwhich will allow us to help the most vulnerable to have shelter, water and healthcare as quickly as possible‚Äù.
Secondly, the UN has appointed a crisis mediator who will liaise with the Government and all relevant actors on the ground. ‚ÄúAt the same time, we are bringing together partners inside and outside the country to ensure that there are enough personnel‚Äù, he indicated.
Another response will be to support those seeking refuge outside Ukraine.
3:05 pm ‚Äì In conversation with Macron, Putin promises not to target the civilian population
According to the Elysee Palace, French President Emmanuel Macron spoke for 1h30 with his Russian counterpart, Vladimir Putin, asking him to stop attacks on civilians and to protect the main roads in Ukraine.
The Russian president confirmed his willingness to comply with these two requests, says the French presidency, which also remains in constant contact with the Ukrainian president, Volodymyr Zelensky. The two leaders, French and Ukrainian, spoke "several times in the last few hours", says Eliseu.
3:00 pm ‚Äì Russian-Ukrainian couple living in Portugal share days of anguish
Andrey Ivanishchev and Maria Ivanishcheva met in Mariupol almost ten years ago. They married in 2014 and lived in Portugal. In recent days, they have tried to maintain contact with the family who remains in Ukraine.
2:56 pm ‚Äì At least 11 dead in bombings in Kharkiv, says city governor
At least eleven people died in Russian bombings of residential areas in Kharkiv this Monday. Regional governor Oleg Sinegoubov states, however, that the number of victims is expected to be much higher.
2:20 pm ‚Äì US recommends that Americans in Russia ‚Äúimmediately‚Äù leave the country
‚ÄúU.S. citizens should consider leaving Russia immediately through commercial travel options still available,‚Äù the State Department advised in a statement.
.
The State Department said that commercial connections are rapidly decreasing as a result of international sanctions, which include the closure of many countries' airspace to Russian planes.
The decision also takes into account the withdrawal of non-essential employees from the US embassy in Moscow, a decision announced this Monday.
‚ÄúThe ability of the US administration to provide routine or emergency services to US citizens in Russia is extremely limited‚Äù, emphasizes the State Department.
2:14 pm ‚Äì Accusations of racism at the gates of Poland and Romania
Two Portuguese students of African origin have been stranded in Ukraine since Friday on the border with Poland. They are being prevented from leaving allegedly because they are black. There are reports and videos on social media of more cases of people in the same situation.
2:10 pm ‚Äì RTP report from the Romanian border of Sighetu
Romania is prepared to receive five million Ukrainian refugees. With a 600-kilometer border with Ukraine, the border posts open doors to those fleeing the war.
The RTP team, Ana Romeu and M√°rio Raposo, followed the departure of the Ukrainians arriving at the Romanian border of Sighetu.
2:07 pm ‚Äì Chaos at Lviv railway station
Lviv train station is the epicenter of the mass flight in Ukraine. Those displaced by war are looking for a train that will take them to the border of a country that belongs to NATO.
The chaos at the station continues into the night, as RTP's special envoys, Jos√© Rodrigues dos Santos and Filipe Valente, noted.
2:02 pm ‚Äì German MNE: ‚ÄúUkraine is part of the house of Europe‚Äù
In response to Kiev, which today called for the country's immediate accession to the European Union, German Foreign Minister Annalena Baerbock stated this Monday that accession is not something that can be done "in a few months", but that Ukraine is part of the "house of Europe" and is therefore welcome to the organization.
"And it's not just because we now wake up in a different world, the European Union has been a home with its doors always open," he said at a press conference.
The head of German diplomacy explained that possible accession is not intended to separate Ukraine from Russia, but rather to fulfill the desire of many Ukrainians.
2:00 pm ‚Äì US bans all transactions with Russian central bank
The United States has banned all transactions with Russia's central bank with immediate effect, the US Treasury Department announced today.
This is a sanction of unprecedented severity taken in coordination with several of Washington's allies in response to Russia's invasion of Ukraine.
This decision has the effect of immobilizing all assets that Russia's central bank holds in the United States, and also prohibits any financial institution or North American company from carrying out transactions or operations with the central bank, says the statement released before the opening of markets, which limits Moscow's ability to defend its currency and sustain the economy.
(Lusa agency)
1:53 pm - Russian MNE cancels visit to the UN in Geneva
The head of Russian diplomacy, Sergei Lavrov, canceled his visit scheduled for Tuesday to the UN in Geneva, due to "anti-Russia sanctions", Moscow's Permanent Representation in Geneva announced on Twitter.
"The visit of the Minister of Foreign Affairs to Geneva to participate in the Human Rights Council and the Conference on Disarmament has been cancelled", reads the tweet that mentions the flight bans by the European Union.

's visit to

1:36 pm ‚Äì Switzerland prepares sanctions against Moscow
The Swiss Government decided to break with an old tradition of neutral position by announcing sanctions against the Russians who are involved in the invasion of Ukraine, mainly resorting to freezing assets.
The president of the Swiss confederation, Ignazio Cassis, announced that the country will impose the same economic sanctions that the EU is adopting.
1:24 pm - Russia closes airspace to companies from 36 countries, including Portugal
Russia announced this Monday the restriction of flights by airlines from 36 countries in response to the closure of airspace by several countries to Russian planes.
"In response to the European states' ban on flights by civil aircraft operated by Russian air carriers and/or registered in Russia, a restriction on flights by air carriers from 36 states has been introduced," the Russian transport agency,¬†Rosaviatsia, said in a statement
quoted by TASS agency
.
The list includes, among other countries, Austria, Belgium, Hungary, Greece, Denmark, Spain, Canada, Cyprus, Luxembourg, Malta, the Netherlands, Norway, Finland, Croatia and Sweden.
1:18 pm - Repatriation flight for national citizens arrives at Humberto Delgado Airport at 11:10 pm
In a note sent to the media, the Ministry of Foreign Affairs advances the schedules for the support flight for the return of national citizens who left Ukraine via Moldova and Romania
The support flight for the return of Portuguese and Portuguese citizens is operated by TAP and departs Lisbon at 1:30 pm. Arrives in Bucharest at 5:40 pm (Lisbon time) and should return to Portugal this Monday at 11:10 pm.
1:17 pm - Set√∫bal available to welcome war refugees
The Set√∫bal City Council made itself available today to welcome refugees from the war in Ukraine, in a letter sent to the Minister of Foreign Affairs, Augusto Santos Silva, the municipality revealed.
"The Set√∫bal City Council informed the Ministry of Foreign Affairs today that it has the availability and logistical capacity to welcome refugees from the ongoing war in Ukraine into municipal facilities, as soon as necessary", reveals the Sadina municipality on the municipality's official Facebook page.
"The mayor of Set√∫bal, Andr√© Martins, informed the head of the Foreign Affairs department that the municipality he presides over is deeply concerned about the effects caused by Russia's military intervention in Ukraine, which is the victim of many hundreds of thousands of citizens of this country and the region who, in order to escape the ongoing armed conflict and protect their families, are forced to leave their homes", he adds.
The Chamber of Set√∫bal, with a communist majority, also states that the municipality's concern "must be translated into concrete actions" and that, for this reason, it decided to "make municipal facilities available to welcome any refugees from this war who arrive in the country in search of help".
Contacted by the Lusa agency, a source from the Office of the Presidency of the Chamber of Set√∫bal said that the municipality has also started contacts with an association from Eastern countries - EDINSTVO, Association of Immigrants from Eastern Countries.
(Lusa agency)
1:15 pm - Ambassador asks for Portugal's support in joining the EU and diplomatic court with Russia
The Ukrainian ambassador to Portugal asked for the Portuguese Government's support in the country's accession to the European Union and also to consider the possibility of breaking relations with Russia, thanking the sanctions and military assistance.
"The sanctions introduced by the European Union, including Portugal, are very effective in the area of ‚Äã‚Äãthe economy", said the Ukrainian ambassador to Portugal, Inna Ohnivets, also highlighting the ban on Russian companies in European airspace: "These measures affect Russia's economy and this may help Russia to consider that it is necessary to stop the war against Ukraine".
At a joint press conference with the Mayor of Lisbon, Carlos Moedas, to present a set of measures aimed at supporting Ukrainian families in the Portuguese capital, Inna Ohnivets asked for Portugal's support for the initiative announced by the President of Ukraine for the country's accession to the European Union.
"We would also like to ask, to consider, the possibility of breaking relations between Portugal and the Russian Federation. This measure is very harsh, but it is fair at this time, because we currently have the situation when the Russian occupiers kill. They are killing Ukrainians in our country, particularly children. 16 children have already died", declared the Ukrainian ambassador.
The Ukrainian diplomat thanked Portugal for its military assistance and provision of military materials, saying that "this is a strong signal" for the Ukrainian people.
"We fight not only for Ukraine, but also for the whole of Europe", stressed Inna Ohnivets, adding that the Ukrainian army "fights very well", but help is also needed from the European Union.
(Lusa agency)
1:00 pm ‚Äì Putin dubs the West an 'empire of lies' after sanctions imposed
Russian President Vladimir Putin dubbed the West an "empire of lies" when discussing the economy with senior officials on Monday following the imposition of sweeping sanctions against Moscow, the Kremlin said.
"(Prime Minister Mikhail Mishustin) and I discussed this topic, naturally keeping in mind the sanctions that the so-called Western community - as I called it in my speech, the 'empire of lies' - is now trying to implement against our country," Putin said.
12:50 pm ‚Äì Dozens of dead and hundreds injured after bombing in Kharkiv
Anton Herashchenko, an adviser to the Ukrainian interior minister, wrote on his Facebook page that Russian troops shelled residential areas with missiles in the city of Kharkiv in eastern Ukraine.
"Kharkiv has just been massively attacked by
rockets
. Dozens of civilians were killed and hundreds were injured,‚Äù he said.
12:35 pm ‚Äì EU Defense Ministers meet to coordinate arms shipments
EU defense ministers meet today via video conference to decide how to use the 500 million euros announced on Sunday to purchase material that will then be sent to Ukrainian troops
These 500 million euros are intended to provide defensive weapons but also large-caliber weapons, anti-tanks, fuel and other types of equipment that help repel aggression.
12:29 pm ‚Äì More than 400 Portuguese lawyers offer ‚Äúpro bono‚Äù help
According to the Bar Association, more than 400 Portuguese lawyers were available to offer "pro bono" legal help to Ukrainian citizens.
In a statement, the organization led by President Menezes Leit√£o said that the lawyers will work together with the National Association of Lawyers of Ukraine and the Embassy of Ukraine in Portugal.
A 'task-force' was created to guarantee a response to legal questions that the war in Ukraine may raise.
12:07 pm ‚Äì Amnesty International in Portugal organizes vigil
Amnesty International is promoting a vigil this Monday in
several cities from north to south of the country
. In Lisbon, the event is scheduled for 7pm at Jardim Roque Gameiro, in Cais do Sodr√©.
11:51 am ‚Äì Roman Abramovich is in Belarus to help with peace negotiations
Russian businessman Roman Abramovich, owner of Chelsea, accepted a Ukrainian request to help negotiate an end to the conflict between Russia and Ukraine, participating in the negotiations currently taking place in Belarus, his spokeswoman announced.
"I can confirm that Roman Abramovich was contacted by the Ukrainian side to help reach a peaceful resolution and that he has been trying to help since then," a spokeswoman said, quoted by Reuters
.
The information was also provided by RTP's correspondent in Moscow, Evgueni Mouravich.
11:41 am ‚Äì Agency website
russian
TASS news report displays anti-Putin message after computer attack
According to Reuters, the website of the Russian news agency TASS was the target of an attack this Monday. The page showed a message calling for an end to the invasion of Ukraine.
"We ask that you stop this madness, do not send your children and husbands to certain death. Putin is forcing us to lie and putting us in danger", the website read.
11:31 am ‚Äì Lisbon City Council announces support measures for Ukrainians
The president of Lisbon City Council, Carlos Moedas, announced
this Monday what will be the capital's efforts to
help refugees arriving in Lisbon, but also Ukrainians who
They are in Portugal and cannot return to the country due to the war.
To
Ukrainian citizens who are in Portugal and cannot return to
country, from today onwards they will be able to go to the municipal cafeteria in
Monsanto.
In a second phase, Carlos Moedas indicates that the center
temporary reception center will operate in a sports hall at the headquarters
of the Lisbon Municipal Police.
In a joint press conference with the Ukrainian ambassador, Inna Ohnivets, the mayor states that Lisbon is "an open city" and that he must lead by example.
For all Ukrainians who need help and for everyone who wants help, the municipality has a telephone line available from now on
800 910 111
and email address
sosucrania@cm-lisboa.pt
.
11:16 am ‚Äì More than half a million people have fled Ukraine, says the UN
According to the United Nations, more than 500,000 people have fled Ukraine to neighboring countries since the Russian invasion began last week. The information is provided by Filippo Grandi, UN High Commissioner for Refugees.
More than 500,000 refugees have now fled from Ukraine into neighboring countries.
‚Äî Filippo Grandi (@FilippoGrandi)
February 28, 2022
11:11 am ‚Äì Zelensky spoke on the phone with Lukashenko before negotiations with Russia
The Ukrainian president spoke on the phone with the Belarusian leader and accepted that talks between Kiev and Moscow would take place in the city of Gomel, in Belarus.
Volodymyr Zelensky is not confident in these negotiations, but says that Ukraine participates in them so that no citizen doubts the ongoing efforts to end the war.
10:43 am ‚Äì Kremlin says EU arms supply to Ukraine is ‚Äúdangerous‚Äù
The Kremlin this Monday accused the European Union of hostile behavior towards Russia, saying that the supply of weapons to Ukraine is "dangerous and destabilizing". This support proves that Russia was right in its efforts to demilitarize the neighboring country, says spokesman Dmitry Peskov.
10:36 am ‚Äì Ukrainian presidential advisor says talks with Russia have already begun
Negotiations between Ukraine and Russia have already begun in the city of Gomel, Belarus, Ukrainian presidential advisor Mykhailo Podolyak told Reuters.
The Ukrainian president's office said on Monday that it seeks an "immediate ceasefire" and the withdrawal of Russian forces from Ukraine.
The meeting is taking place in Gomel, close to the border with Ukraine. The delegations from both countries include members of the presidential cabinets and the Ministries of Defense and Foreign Affairs.
The request for negotiations was made on Sunday by the Kremlin. The president of Ukraine accepted the talks, but does not believe in a positive result.
10:13 am ‚Äì Portuguese woman accuses Polish border guards of racism. Young Portuguese people prevented from leaving Ukraine
Ana Maria Costa has a son in Ukraine who has been trying to leave the country since Friday night. Speaking to RTP, he explains that the young Portuguese citizen is with other colleagues who are unable to leave the country.
He accuses the Polish authorities of not letting them pass because they are of African descent. Discrimination also affects Asians, he tells RTP.
He says that several people are being blocked due to the color of their skin and that some refugees ‚Äúwere run away with batons‚Äù so that the ‚Äúwhite Ukrainian‚Äù refugees could pass
This mother also states that she has already contacted Lu√≠s Caba√ßo, Portuguese ambassador to Poland. The Portuguese representative has already confirmed with the Polish authorities that the young people are Portuguese citizens and asked that they be allowed to cross the border. But Polish border guards ‚Äúdon‚Äôt even look at the ambassador‚Äôs message‚Äù, he says.
9:51 am ‚Äì Zelensky will release prisoners with military experience who want to fight
The Ukrainian president announced this Monday that he will release prisoners who have military experience and who want to join the fight against Russian troops. The announcement was made through a video published on social media.
Volodymyr Zelensky also spoke to the Russian soldiers, who asked them to "lay down their weapons and get out of here".
"Don't believe your bosses, don't believe the propaganda. Save your lives," he said.
9:42 am ‚Äì Ruble plummets
The Russian ruble fell 40 percent this Monday, after the unprecedented international sanctions were announced against Moscow's financial system due to Vladimir Putin's invasion of Ukraine.
At the same time, the European Central Bank revealed that the European branch of Russia's Sberbank was "bankrupt or likely to go bankrupt" due to deposit withdrawals.
9:19 am ‚Äì Ukrainian president calls for immediate integration of the country into the European Union
Volodymyr Zelensky asked this Monday that the European Union allow Ukraine to join immediately, using a special procedure.
"Our goal is to be alongside all Europeans and, most importantly, to be equal. I'm sure it's fair. I'm sure we deserve it," said the Ukrainian president in a video published this Monday on social media.
9:13 am ‚Äì European stock markets in the red
The main European stock exchanges were trading lower this Monday, with oil priced above 100 dollars per barrel.
At around 8:25 am in Lisbon, the EuroStoxx 600 fell 1.29% to 447.69 points, Brent oil was priced at 101.42 dollars per barrel and the euro fell to 1.1174 dollars.
The stock exchanges in Paris, Frankfurt and Milan fell by 2.30%, 2.07% and 2.03%, as well as those in Madrid and London, which fell by 1.27% and 0.95%, respectively.
After opening lower, the Lisbon Stock Exchange maintained the trend, with the main index, the PSI20, dropping 0.27% to 5,480.66 points at around 8:25 am.
8:52 am ‚Äì Ukrainian delegation arrived at the border for negotiations with Russia
A Ukrainian delegation has just arrived at the border with Belarus for negotiations this Monday with Russian representatives. Kiev seeks to achieve an "immediate ceasefire" and the withdrawal of Russian forces, the Ukrainian presidency said in a statement.
This Ukrainian delegation includes Defense Minister Oleksii Reznijov and Presidential Advisor Mykhailo Podolyak.
8:48 am ‚Äì Night of intense fighting near Mariupol
The regional governor of the port city of Mariupol, Pavlo Kyrylenko, said this Monday that there had been fighting between Russian and Ukrainian troops in that city. However, there was no indication of any number of casualties or which forces had the advantage.
8:41 am ‚Äì Human Rights Council schedules urgent debate on the invasion of Ukraine
Russia's invasion of Ukraine will be the subject of urgent debate at the UN Human Rights Council on Thursday. Ukraine and several other countries demand an investigation into Moscow's violation of human rights.
The meeting was scheduled after voting and had 29 votes in favor, 13 abstentions and five against (including Russia and China).
8:37 am ‚Äì Ukrainian refugees continue to arrive at the Polish border
Thousands of Ukrainians fleeing armed conflicts continue to arrive in Hrebenne near the border with Poland. Antena 1's special envoy, Lu√≠s Peixoto, is in this location and reports on the environment there.
8:32 am ‚Äì Russian Ministry of Defense claims ‚Äúair supremacy‚Äù over Ukraine
The Russian military claims this Monday that it has taken control over Ukrainian airspace.
"Russian aviation has assumed air supremacy over the entire territory of Ukraine," Major General Igor Konashenkov, spokesman for the Russian Ministry of Defense, said in a statement.
8:14 am ‚Äì Calmer night in Kiev waiting for the negotiations. City faces shortages
A column of Russian troops continues to advance towards Kiev, but Ukrainian forces have managed to halt the advances. Still, last night was calmer in Kiev after the announcement of negotiations between Russia and Ukraine.
RTP's special envoy, C√¢ndida Pinto, highlights the differences in morale between Russian and Ukrainian soldiers: the former, unmotivated due to the lack of support from the population, the latter mobilized to defend the country.
Even so, on the fifth day of clashes, the city of Kiev begins to experience more difficulties. Lacks of food, fuel and medicine are beginning to suffocate the country's capital.
7:58 am ‚Äì Latvian Parliament authorizes citizens to fight in Ukraine
The Latvian Parliament approved this Monday a law that allows Latvian citizens to fight alongside Ukrainians to defend the country.
The Baltic country borders Russia and was part of the Soviet Union, its territory having been occupied since 1940. It became independent in 1991 and has been a member of the EU and NATO since 2004.
7:50 am ‚Äì Russia intends to reach an agreement with Ukraine in talks, says Russian negotiator
Vladimir Medinsky, Moscow's interlocutor in this Monday's negotiations, says that Russia is interested in reaching an agreement that is in the interests of all parties. Negotiations should start at 12:00 local time (9:00 in Lisbon).
7:45 am ‚Äì Portuguese repatriation flight leaves Bucharest this afternoon
The approximately 50 Portuguese who left Ukraine in recent days on missions organized by the Portuguese embassy in Kiev will be repatriated this Monday. The flight will leave Bucharest, Romania, today at 5pm, RTP learned.
7:34 am - Ukraine denies information and guarantees that the Russian army does not control the Zaporizhzhya nuclear plant
Energoatom, Ukraine's¬†state nuclear company, on Monday denied reports that Russia controls the Zaporizhzhia nuclear power plant, the largest in Europe.
7:30 am ‚Äì Russian army says civilians can leave Kiev ‚Äúof their own free will‚Äù
The Russian army said this Monday that civilians in the capital can leave the city of their own free will, accusing the Ukrainian authorities of using the population as a "human shield".
"All civilians in the city can leave the Ukrainian capital of their own free will from the Kiev-Vassylkiv road," said the spokesman for the Russian Ministry of Defense.
7:23 am ‚Äì Russia says its troops have taken two cities in southeastern Ukraine
Russian forces say they now control the cities of Berdyansk and Enerhodar, in the Zaporizhzhya region. The Russian Defense Ministry says it also controls the area around the Zaporizhzhya nuclear power plant.
7:11 am ‚Äì Vatican says it is ready to ‚Äúfacilitate dialogue‚Äù
The country's Secretary of State, Cardinal Pietro Parolin, who is second only to the Pope in the Vatican hierarchy, was available to mediate the conflict and said he was convinced that "there is always room for negotiations."
"It is never too late. Because the only reasonable and constructive way to resolve differences is through dialogue, as the Pope never tires of repeating", said the Vatican's number two in an interview with several Italian newspapers.
Status point
- On this fifth day of conflict, a negotiating meeting is scheduled for this Monday to take place on the border between Belarus and Ukraine. The Ukrainian president said he did not believe in a positive outcome of the negotiations, but promised that he ‚Äúwill try‚Äù;
- In a telephone conversation on Sunday night with British Prime Minister Boris Johnson, the Ukrainian president stated that the next 24 hours will be "decisive" for the conflict.
- Russian President Vladimir Putin ordered his military command
country to place deterrence forces on alert, which encompasses
ballistic capabilities;
- Brussels approved a new package of sanctions against Moscow. The EU will finance the purchase of weapons for Ukraine and close its airspace to Russian planes. EU foreign ministers approved a ‚Ç¨450 million package to finance the supply of lethal weapons to the Ukrainian army;
- Ukrainian military described fourth day of war as "difficult". The Ukrainian capital remains under control of the country's authorities, but the mayor of Kiev says the city is "surrounded" by Russian forces. Satellite images from the company Maxar show large numbers of Russian ground troops heading towards Kiev;
- The Ukrainian Ministry of Health confirmed the deaths of 352 civilians, including 14 children, since the start of the Russian invasion of Ukraine;
- The United Nations confirmed that the Russian offensive has already caused 368 thousand refugees. Europe estimates that this number could reach seven million people;
- More than 17 European countries, including Portugal, decided to close off their airspace to Russian flights.
- An extraordinary United Nations General Assembly is being held this Monday to discuss the conflict in Ukraine. The meeting was approved and attempts to bypass the Russian veto in the Security Council.

Ukraine. Number of refugees exceeds 500 thousand people
Feb 28, 2022 - 12:16 ‚Ä¢
Lusa
Poland, Hungary, Moldova and Romania are currently the main destinations for this flow of refugees.
A+
/
A-
Photo: Martin Divisek/EPA
The number of Ukrainians who fled the country due to the Russian invasion exceeds 500 thousand people, in addition to more than 100 thousand people internally displaced by the conflict, the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees (UNHCR) reported this Monday.
Poland, Hungary, Moldova and Romania are currently the main destinations for this flow of refugees, according to the UNHCR on its Twitter account.
Both UNHCR and the Ukrainian Government warned last week of the possibility that the number of refugees could rise to five million people, that is, almost a tenth of Ukraine's population.
Since the start of the Russian attacks last Thursday, the UN High Commissioner for Refugees, Filippo Grandi, has called on Ukraine's neighboring countries to ‚Äúkeep their borders open to those seeking safety and protection‚Äù.
UNHCR spokesperson in the United Kingdom, Laura Padoan, indicated, in a statement also released on Twitter, that the UN agency is verifying information that Ukrainians are being prevented from boarding trains to escape the Russian offensive.
According to the Ukrainian Government, since the beginning of the crisis in Crimea and Donbass in 2014, 1.5 million internally displaced people have been registered in the country.
Russia launched a military offensive in Ukraine early Thursday morning, with ground forces and bombing of targets in several cities, which has already caused around 200 deaths, including civilians, and more than 1,100 injuries, on Ukrainian territory, according to Kiev.
The attack was condemned by most of the international community and led to emergency meetings of several governments, including the Portuguese, and the North Atlantic Treaty Organization (NATO), EU and UN Security Council, with mass sanctions being approved against Russia.

Roman Abramovich is mediating negotiations between Ukraine and Russia
Chelsea
28-02-2022 11:25
By
Writing
By
Writing
Chelsea owner Roman Abramovich accepted Kiev's request to mediate the meeting between Ukrainians and Russians on the border with Belarus, according to The Jewish News this Monday.
The 55-year-old Russian billionaire's advisor confirmed to the Israeli newspaper that Ukraine had asked Abramovich to help mediate the talks.
‚ÄúI confirm that¬†Roman Abramovich was contacted by the Ukrainians to support a peace commitment and that he has been making efforts in this direction since then,‚Äù John Man told the British newspaper¬†The Guardian.
The invitation to Abramovich came from Ukrainian director¬†Alexander Rodnyansky, who confirmed that he was actively looking for Russians who could help ‚Äúfind a peaceful solution‚Äù to the war on Ukrainian soil.

A
Belarus may be preparing to join the Russians in invading Ukraine. According to the Ukrainian newspaper The Kyiv Independent, a message has been circulating in diplomatic circles since yesterday, the 27th, that Belarusian air forces are preparing an invasion of Ukraine.
Belarusian opposition journalists, who were not identified, are allegedly the source of this information.
According to these sources, cited by The Kyiv Independent, Belarusian special forces boarded planes yesterday to strengthen the invasion in Kiev or Zhytomyr.
It should be remembered that the Belarusian regime, presided over by Alexander Lukashenko, is highly repressive, having already led journalists to flee the country to escape the dictator's 'claws'. For this reason, the information is difficult to confirm.
On Telegram there are reports of the movement of two military transport planes that departed from an airfield in western Belarus.
It should be noted that Belarus approved the nuclear neutrality referendum that allows, for example, the installation of Russian nuclear weapons in the country.
An advisor to Ukraine's Interior Minister, Anton Herashchenko, revealed yesterday that Iskander missiles were launched this Sunday against northern Ukraine from Belarus.
The missiles reportedly hit the airport in the city of Zhytomyr. ‚ÄúThis is what was hit by the Iskanders launched from Belarus at around 5 pm [3 pm in Lisbon]... Russian and Belarusian fascists attacked Zhytomyr airport,‚Äù revealed Herashchenko on the Telegram application.
Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky will be in negotiations between Kiev and Moscow today. These will take place on the border between Belarus and Ukraine, after the Belarusian counterpart assured him ‚Äúthat all planes, helicopters and missiles parked on Belarusian territory remain on the ground during the trip, talks and the return of the Ukrainian delegation‚Äù.

translated_text:
The War
World
Singapore announces sanctions against Russia
Lusa Agency
Feb 28, 2022
09:11
0
Comments
Photo¬†obimw/Shutterstock.com
The Government of Singapore announced today that it will impose sanctions against Russia due to the "unprecedented severity" of the invasion of Ukraine, an unusual measure for a country that tends to be neutral in global affairs.
The measures will include controlling exports of weapons that could be used against Ukraine, blocking some Russian banks and certain financial transactions with Russia, Singapore's Foreign Minister Vivian Balakrishnan said today, anticipating that more details about these sanctions will be revealed soon.
"There are times when it is necessary to take sides, even if it is against one or more powers, as we are doing now", said the minister today during a speech in Parliament, without explicitly naming any country.
Singapore has a strong economic dependence on China - a country that has strengthened ties with Russia in recent years - which has been its main trading partner for almost a decade.
The minister stressed that the measures "will have a cost and implications" for businesspeople and citizens of Singapore, which is home to numerous banks from around the world and multinationals.
Russia launched a military offensive in Ukraine early Thursday morning, with ground forces and bombing of targets in several cities, which has already killed at least 352 civilians, including children, according to Kiev. The UN reported nearly 370,000 people displaced to Poland, Hungary, Moldova and Romania.
Russian President Vladimir Putin said that the "special military operation" in Ukraine aims to demilitarize the neighboring country and that it was the only way for Russia to defend itself, with the Kremlin specifying that the offensive will last as long as necessary.
The attack was condemned by most of the international community and the European Union and the United States, among others, responded by sending weapons and ammunition to Ukraine and strengthening sanctions to further isolate Moscow.

The War
World
At least 11 killed in Russian attack on Kharkiv neighborhood
Lusa Agency
Feb 28, 2022
15:11
0
Comments
At least 11 people died and hundreds were injured today in a Russian missile attack on residential neighborhoods in Kharkiv, Ukraine's second largest city, the Ukrainian government reported.
"Kharkiv. A merciless and senseless attack on a residential neighborhood with missiles! Corpses in the streets," wrote Anton Guerashenko, an advisor to Ukraine's Interior Ministry, on the Telegram messaging service, where he posted videos with images of the attack.
"The Russian enemy is shelling residential areas", also informed Oleg Sinegubov, regional governor in Kharkiv, adding that as the shelling is still "ongoing", rescue services cannot be called.
In one of the videos circulating on social media, bodies of the fatal victims and injured can be seen on the streets of the neighborhoods.
In another, lasting 30 seconds, images appear of around 15 missiles hitting a sector of the city, located in northeastern Ukraine.
The attack comes at a time when, at the other end of the country, on the Ukrainian-Belarusian border, delegations from Ukraine and Russia are meeting to negotiate for the first time since Russia began its invasion of Ukraine last Thursday.
Russia's offensive in Ukraine, with ground forces and bombing of targets in several cities, has already killed more than 350 civilians, including children, according to Kiev. The UN reported more than 100,000 displaced people and almost 500,000 refugees in Poland, Hungary, Moldova and Romania.
Russian President Vladimir Putin said that the "special military operation" in Ukraine aims to demilitarize the neighboring country and that it was the only way for Russia to defend itself, with the Kremlin specifying that the offensive will last as long as necessary.
The attack was condemned by most of the international community and the European Union and the United States, among others, responded by sending weapons and ammunition to Ukraine and strengthening sanctions to further isolate Moscow.

Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky considers that "the next 24 hours" will be "crucial" for Ukraine, he said in a conversation with British Prime Minister Boris Johnson.
The prediction was made in a telephone conversation on Sunday night, in which the head of the British Government, according to a spokesman, told Zelensky that he would do everything possible to "ensure that defensive aid from the United Kingdom and allies reaches Ukraine".
"The Prime Minister praised the courage of the Ukrainian people after the Russian invasion and praised President Zelensky's leadership in the face of such adversity. The resistance of the Ukrainian people was heroic,"
said the same source.

A meeting between delegations from Ukraine and Russia is scheduled for this Monday, where they are expected to negotiate a possible cessation of hostilities.
There has been 'no significant change' in Russia's nuclear deterrence strategy, says UK
This morning, British Defense Minister Ben Wallace assured that there had been no "significant change" in Russia's nuclear deterrence strategy, despite the threat by Russian President Vladimir Putin.
"We have looked at his position. There is no significant change," Ben Wallace told LBC radio, believing it was yet another way the Russian president was "seeking to impress".
Russia launched a military offensive in Ukraine early Thursday morning, with ground forces and bombing of targets in several cities, which has already killed at least 352 civilians, including children, according to Kiev. The UN reported nearly 370,000 people displaced to Poland, Hungary, Moldova and Romania.
Russian President Vladimir Putin said that the "special military operation" in Ukraine aims to demilitarize the neighboring country and that it was the only way for Russia to defend itself, with the Kremlin specifying that the offensive will last as long as necessary.
The attack was condemned by most of the international community and the European Union and the United States, among others, responded by sending weapons and ammunition to Ukraine and strengthening sanctions to further isolate Moscow.

Russia announced today that it will restrict flights by airlines from 36 countries, in response to the closure of Russian aircraft from the airspace of dozens of states following Moscow's invasion of Ukraine.
"In response to the ban by European states on flights of civil aircraft operated by Russian air carriers and/or registered in Russia, a restriction on flights by air carriers from 36 states has been introduced," announced the Russian air transport agency Rosaviatsia.
Among the States involved are all European Union countries, the United Kingdom and Canada.
According to Rosaviatsia, flights by airlines from these countries can still be carried out as long as they obtain a "special authorization" issued by the Russian authorities.
On Sunday, the European Union and other countries, including Canada, announced the closure of¬†their airspace to all Russian aircraft.
Russia launched a military offensive in Ukraine early Thursday morning, with ground forces and bombing of targets in several cities, which has already killed more than 350 civilians, including children, according to Kiev. The UN reported almost 500,000 people displaced to Poland, Hungary, Moldova and Romania.
Russian President Vladimir Putin said that the "special military operation" in Ukraine aims to demilitarize the neighboring country and that it was the only way for Russia to defend itself, with the Kremlin specifying that the offensive will last as long as necessary.
The attack was condemned by most of the international community and the European Union and the United States, among others, responded by sending weapons and ammunition to Ukraine and strengthening sanctions to further isolate Moscow.

A
Meta will restrict access to Russian media outlets RT and Sputnik News in the European Union (EU) on their Facebook and Instagram platforms, it was revealed today.
Nick Clegg, vice-president of Global Affairs at Meta, said on his Twitter page that the technology company had received several calls from the EU itself and several governments to control disinformation about the conflict in Ukraine, particularly regarding the Russian media outlets RT and Sputnik News.
‚ÄúGiven the exceptional nature of the current situation, we will restrict access to RT and Sputnik News in the EU at this time‚Äù, clarified the person in charge, assuring that the company will continue ‚Äúto work with Governments on this matter‚Äù.
We have received requests from a number of Governments and the EU to take further steps in relation to Russian state controlled media. Given the exceptional nature of the current situation, we will be restricting access to RT and Sputnik across the EU at this time.
‚Äî Nick Clegg (@nickclegg)
February 28, 2022
Twitter also announced that
will label the content of Russian state media websites
, given its disinformation strategy to condition public opinion regarding the invasion of Ukraine.
This Monday, Meta stated that pro-Russian groups are orchestrating several disinformation campaigns on social media with fake profiles or hacked accounts to portray Ukraine as a pawn in the hands of the West, having
closed false accounts and blocked the sharing of Internet addresses linked to websites that spread false information.
The network was identified by Meta as being linked to individuals in Russia and Ukraine, as well as the news organizations NewsFront and SouthFront in Crimea, the Ukrainian peninsula annexed by Moscow in 2014.
According to the United States, the NewsFront and SouthFront organizations are disinformation points that receive orders from the Russian secret services and are among more than a dozen entities sanctioned by Washington for trying to influence the 2020 US presidential elections "at the direction of the leadership" of Moscow.

translated_text:
World
|
War in Ukraine
EU arms supply well underway, but under secrecy
by Lusa
Want to share this article?
cancel
The head of European diplomacy assured that the mobilization and delivery of weapons to Ukraine, discussed today by EU defense ministers, is well underway, but declined to give details, as "Russia would very much like" to know them.
SEE MORE
"In terms of mobilizing resources, everything is well underway. The delivery requires important logistics that the Member States have to organize, and it has to be done quickly. But we are in a war and I am not going to give any information that could be of use to the side we are facing. I am sure that Russia would be very happy to know where and how the help we are going to give will pass" to the Ukrainian army to defend itself, said Josep Borrell.
The High Representative of the European Union (EU) for Foreign and Security Policy was speaking at a press conference in Brussels, after a videoconference of defense ministers of the 27, held to discuss at a "more technical" level the implementation of the historic support package of 450 million in weapons for Ukraine agreed the day before by the foreign ministers.
In the same statements, Borrell recalled that Moscow has already warned that it will attack "any person or entity that transports this aid", which is why he declined to provide "any details that could be useful to them".
Borrell, who the day before had thanked Poland for offering itself as a logistical 'hub' for the transfer of material assistance to Ukraine, limited himself to saying that, "naturally", it "will pass through countries that border with Ukraine, that's no secret", and added that it was decided to create a cell, which will work in coordination with NATO, to monitor "Ukraine's requests and needs" and the routing of armament, which includes defensive material, namely anti-tanks, and weapons and ammunition of all calibers.
The High Representative highlighted that defense ministers worked hard today "in coordinating efforts to ensure maximum effectiveness" not only in the mobilization and delivery of weapons acquired with funding of 450 million euros, but also those supplied to the Ukrainian armed forces by several Member States on a bilateral basis.
Borrell revealed that Ukraine has also requested more support in terms of military information, and the EU is already mobilizing its satellite center, based in Madrid, to "work in this direction".
The head of European diplomacy also indicated that an assessment of the evolution of the military situation on the ground was made, based on information collected by several Member States, and the conclusion is that "Russia's military campaign is becoming increasingly brutal".
But, he stressed, that "the Ukrainian armed forces are fighting with courage" and "whoever said that the fall of Kiev was a matter of hours" was wrong, as the capital continues to resist, as do Mariupol and Kharkiv.
However, the High Representative recognized that "it is vital" to support the Ukrainian armed forces in the face of an aggressor with many more military assets.
"They need ammunition, defensive weapons of any type, and we will provide them," he said, reiterating that Sunday's decision by the EU, supported "by everyone, all Member States", to provide military assistance to a third country targeted by aggression is historic and marks a new chapter in European construction.
On Sunday, in what was their fourth meeting in the space of a week, the 27 Foreign Ministers approved a 450 million euro package to finance the supply of lethal weapons to the Ukrainian army, which is fighting against the Russian invasion, in a decision that marks a historic turning point in the EU.
Russia launched a military offensive in Ukraine early Thursday morning, with ground forces and bombing of targets in several cities, which has already killed more than 350 civilians, including children, according to Kiev.
The UN reported more than 100,000 displaced people and almost 500,000 refugees in Poland, Hungary, Moldova and Romania.
Russian President Vladimir Putin said that the "special military operation" in Ukraine aims to demilitarize the neighboring country and that it was the only way for Russia to defend itself, with the Kremlin specifying that the offensive will last as long as necessary.
The attack was condemned by most of the international community and the European Union and the United States, among others, responded by sending weapons and ammunition to Ukraine and strengthening sanctions to further isolate Moscow.

translated_text:
The War
World
Thousands ask to join foreign legion in fight against Russia
Lusa Agency
Feb 28, 2022
17:09
0
Comments
Photo EPA
Thousands of people have submitted applications to join the "International Legion" of volunteers to fight against Russia in Ukraine, Ukrainian authorities said.
"We have already received thousands of requests from foreigners who want to join the resistance to the Russian occupiers and protect the security of the world from the regime of [Russian President Vladimir] Putin," wrote Deputy Defense Minister Hanna Maliar in a post on the social network Twitter.
Ukrainian President Volodymir Zelensky on Sunday called on citizens of foreign countries friendly to Ukraine to come to the country to join the fight against Russian aggression.
Zelensky indicated that anyone who wants to join "the defense of security in Europe and the world" can go to Ukraine and fight "side by side with the Ukrainians against the invaders of the 21st century."
According to the rules of military service in the Armed Forces, foreign citizens can voluntarily join units such as territorial defense forces.
Russia launched a military offensive in Ukraine early Thursday morning, with ground forces and bombing of targets in several cities, which has already killed more than 350 civilians, including children, according to Kiev. The UN reported more than 100,000 displaced people and almost 500,000 refugees in Poland, Hungary, Moldova and Romania.
Russian President Vladimir Putin said that the "special military operation" in Ukraine aims to demilitarize the neighboring country and that it was the only way for Russia to defend itself, with the Kremlin specifying that the offensive will last as long as necessary.
The attack was condemned by most of the international community and the European Union and the United States, among others, responded by sending weapons and ammunition to Ukraine and strengthening sanctions to further isolate Moscow.

The War
World
Boris Johnson says Zelensky believes 'next 24 hours' will be crucial
Lusa Agency
Feb 28, 2022
09:47
0
Comments
Photo¬†EPA/Simon Dawson/10 DOWNING STREET
Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky considers that "the next 24 hours" will be "crucial" for Ukraine, he said in a conversation with British Prime Minister Boris Johnson.
The prediction was made in a telephone conversation on Sunday night, in which the head of the British Government, according to a spokesman, told Zelensky that he would do everything possible to "ensure that defensive aid from the United Kingdom and allies reaches Ukraine".
"The Prime Minister praised the courage of the Ukrainian people after the Russian invasion and praised President Zelensky's leadership in the face of such adversity. The resistance of the Ukrainian people was heroic," said the same source.
Today a meeting is scheduled between delegations from Ukraine and Russia, where they are expected to negotiate a possible cessation of hostilities.
This morning, British Defense Minister Ben Wallace assured that there had been no "significant change" in Russia's nuclear deterrence strategy, despite the threat by Russian President Vladimir Putin.
"We have looked at his position. There is no significant change," Ben Wallace told LBC radio, believing it was yet another way the Russian president was "seeking to impress".
Russia launched a military offensive in Ukraine early Thursday morning, with ground forces and bombing of targets in several cities, which has already killed at least 352 civilians, including children, according to Kiev. The UN reported nearly 370,000 people displaced to Poland, Hungary, Moldova and Romania.
Russian President Vladimir Putin said that the "special military operation" in Ukraine aims to demilitarize the neighboring country and that it was the only way for Russia to defend itself, with the Kremlin specifying that the offensive will last as long as necessary.
The attack was condemned by most of the international community and the European Union and the United States, among others, responded by sending weapons and ammunition to Ukraine and strengthening sanctions to further isolate Moscow.

translated_text:
Home
International
Borrell: "EU arms supply well underway, but under secrecy"
"We are at war and I am not going to give any information that could serve the side we are facing" said the head of European diplomacy, but assured that the delivery of weapons to Ukraine is "well underway".
¬©¬†EPA/STEPHANIE LECOCQ
DN/Lusa
28¬†February¬†2022¬†‚Äî¬†16:38
Facebook
Twitter
Comment
Share
Topics
War in Ukraine
Russia
European Union (EU)
josep borrell
International
Related
international
Ukraine. Membership of the European Union? "We have to deal with more practical things"
minister of defense
Cravinho says that Putin and his regime underestimated the EU's ability to unite
The head of European diplomacy assured that the mobilization and delivery of weapons to Ukraine, discussed this Monday by EU defense ministers, is well underway, but declined to give details, as "Russia would very much like" to know them.
"In terms of mobilizing resources, everything is well underway. The delivery requires important logistics that the Member States have to organize, and it has to be done quickly. But we are in a war and I am not going to give any information that could be of use to the side we are facing. I am sure that Russia would be very happy to know where and how the help we are going to give will pass" to the Ukrainian army to defend itself, said Josep Borrell.
The High Representative of the European Union (EU) for Foreign and Security Policy was speaking at a press conference in Brussels, after a videoconference of defense ministers of the 27, held to discuss at a "more technical" level the implementation of the historic support package of 450 million in weapons for Ukraine agreed the day before by the foreign ministers.
Close
Subscribe to newsletters
News Diary
and receive information first hand.
Subscribe
In the same statements,
Borrell recalled that Moscow has already warned that it will attack "any person or entity that transports this aid", which is why he declined to provide "any details that could be useful to them"
.
Borrell, who the day before had thanked Poland for offering itself as a logistical 'hub' for the transfer of material assistance to Ukraine, limited himself to saying that, "naturally", it "will pass through countries that have a border with Ukraine, that's no secret", and added that it was decided to create a cell, which will work in coordination with NATO, to monitor "Ukraine's requests and needs" and the routing of armament, which includes defensive material, namely anti-tank, and weapons and ammunition of all calibers.
The High Representative highlighted that defense ministers worked hard today "in coordinating efforts to ensure maximum effectiveness" not only in the mobilization and delivery of weapons acquired with funding of 450 million euros, but also those supplied to the Ukrainian armed forces by several Member States on a bilateral basis.
Borrell revealed that Ukraine has also requested more support in terms of military information, and the EU is already mobilizing its satellite center, based in Madrid, to "work in this direction".
The head of European diplomacy also indicated that an assessment of the evolution of the military situation on the ground was made, based on information collected by several Member States, and the conclusion is that "Russia's military campaign is becoming increasingly brutal".
But, he stressed, that "the Ukrainian armed forces are fighting with courage" and "whoever said that the fall of Kiev was a matter of hours" was wrong, as the capital continues to resist, as do Mariupol and Kharkiv.
However, the High Representative recognized that "it is vital" to support the Ukrainian armed forces in the face of an aggressor with many more military assets.
"They need ammunition, defensive weapons of any type, and we will provide them," he said, reiterating that Sunday's decision by the EU, supported "by everyone, all Member States", to provide military assistance to a third country targeted by aggression is historic and marks a new chapter in European construction.
On Sunday, in what was their fourth meeting in the space of a week, the 27 Foreign Ministers approved a 450 million euro package to finance the supply of lethal weapons to the Ukrainian army, which is fighting against the Russian invasion, in a decision that marks a historic turning point in the EU.
Russia launched a military offensive in Ukraine early Thursday morning, with ground forces and bombing of targets in several cities, which has already killed more than 350 civilians, including children, according to Kiev.
The UN reported more than 100,000 displaced people and almost 500,000 refugees in Poland, Hungary, Moldova and Romania.
Russian President Vladimir Putin said that the "special military operation" in Ukraine aims to demilitarize the neighboring country and that it was the only way for Russia to defend itself, with the Kremlin specifying that the offensive will last as long as necessary.
The attack was condemned by most of the international community and the European Union and the United States, among others, responded by sending weapons and ammunition to Ukraine and strengthening sanctions to further isolate Moscow.

The War
World
Vladimir Putin loses honorary World Taekwondo black belt
Lusa Agency
Feb 28, 2022
14:51
0
Comments
The President of Russia, Vladimir Putin, was today stripped by World Taekwondo of the honorary ninth dan black belt, which had been awarded to him in 2013.
"We strongly condemn the brutal attacks on innocent lives in Ukraine, which go against World Taekwondo's vision that 'peace is more precious than victory', as well as the values of respect and tolerance", explained the sport's international federation.
World Taekwondo also informed that it will accept the suggestion of the International Olympic Committee (IOC) to omit the flag and anthem of Russia and its ally Belarus in all competitions.
In the same vein, neither nation will be able to organize international competitions.
"Our thoughts are with the people of Ukraine and we hope for a peaceful and immediate end to this war," the organization added.
In addition to World Taekwondo, the International Judo Federation also stripped Putin, over the weekend, of the eighth dan of his favorite sport, as well as the honorary vice-presidency he had held since 2008.
Russia launched a military offensive in Ukraine early Thursday morning, with ground forces and bombing of targets in several cities, which has already killed more than 350 civilians, including children, according to Kiev. The UN reported more than 100,000 displaced people and almost 500,000 refugees in Poland, Hungary, Moldova and Romania.
Russian President Vladimir Putin said that the "special military operation" in Ukraine aims to demilitarize the neighboring country and that it was the only way for Russia to defend itself, with the Kremlin specifying that the offensive will last as long as necessary.
The attack was condemned by most of the international community and the European Union and the United States, among others, responded by sending weapons and ammunition to Ukraine and strengthening sanctions to further isolate Moscow.

The European Commissioner for Crisis Management, Janez Lenarcic, said this Sunday that the European Union must prepare for a humanitarian crisis of "historic proportions" in Ukraine, which could lead to more than seven million people being displaced.
"We are witnessing what could become the biggest humanitarian crisis on our continent for several years (...). We must prepare for a crisis of historic proportions", warned Janez Lenarcic, after a meeting of European interior ministers in Brussels.
Citing United Nations estimates, the European Commissioner said that, if the war in Ukraine worsens, there will be "more than seven million displaced people" in the country.
The United Nations counts nearly 370,000 refugees in Poland, Hungary, Moldova and Romania since the conflict began on Thursday.
According to forecasts cited by Janez Lenarcic, around 18 million people will be affected "at a humanitarian level" in Ukraine and neighboring states, with up to four million people fleeing the country, becoming refugees.
Russia launched a military offensive in Ukraine early Thursday morning, with ground forces and bombing of targets in several cities, which has already caused around 200 civilian deaths and more than 1,100 injuries on Ukrainian territory, according to Kiev.
Russian President Vladimir Putin stated that the "special military operation" in Ukraine aims to demilitarize the neighboring country and that it was the only way for Russia to defend itself, with the Kremlin stating that the offensive will last as long as necessary.
PUB
The attack was condemned by most of the international community and led to emergency meetings of several governments, including the Portuguese, the North Atlantic Treaty Organization (NATO), the European Union and the UN Security Council, with mass sanctions being approved against Russia.

The United States said today that it had not detected any "concrete" change in Russia's nuclear posture since Russian President Vladimir Putin put his deterrent forces on high alert, in the context of the invasion of Ukraine.
"We are always monitoring and watching as closely as possible" and "we have not seen anything concrete [in the nuclear posture maintained by Russia] ???????as a consequence of your decision. At least not yet," a senior Pentagon official told reporters.
Reaffirming that Russia has "never" been threatened by NATO, the Pentagon admits that it is "difficult to know what is behind" Putin's order, but considers that "the mere fact of evoking" or "threatening" the "use of nuclear forces", being "useless", represents at the same time "a significant escalation".
The same source also assured that, at this stage, the Belarusian military does not appear to have entered Ukraine to reinforce Russian forces.
"We have not seen any indication that Belarusian soldiers have been placed in battle order to enter Ukraine, and there is no indication that they have already entered or are in the process of entering Ukraine," he said.
"As far as we know, the forces that entered Ukraine are all Russian", and Moscow now has "almost 75%" of the combat forces it had gathered in recent months along the border on Ukrainian territory, he¬†added.
Russia launched a military offensive in Ukraine early Thursday morning, with ground forces and bombing of targets in several cities, which has already killed more than 350 civilians, including children, according to Kiev. The UN reported almost 500,000 people displaced to Poland, Hungary, Moldova and Romania.
Russian President Vladimir Putin said that the "special military operation" in Ukraine aims to demilitarize the neighboring country and that it was the only way for Russia to defend itself, with the Kremlin specifying that the offensive will last as long as necessary.
The attack was condemned by most of the international community and the European Union and the United States, among others, responded by sending weapons and ammunition to Ukraine and strengthening sanctions to further isolate Moscow.

Topics
Handball
Modalities
With this sanction, Russian side Chekhovskiye Medvedi, Benfica's opponents in the European Handball League, are automatically prevented from competing in group B
The European Handball Federation (EHF) today decided to suspend with "immediate effect" clubs and teams from Russia and Belarus, in light of the Russian military invasion of Ukraine.
Related
Handball.
Alfredo Quintana left a year ago: "He will continue to come to the pavilion"
Handball.
War in Ukraine: Champions game between FC Porto and HC¬†Motor canceled
With this sanction, the Russians from Chekhovskiye Medvedi, Benfica's opponents in the European Handball League, are automatically prevented from competing in group B, in which the "reds" are runners-up, with 13 points, the same as GOG (Denmark).
"With immediate effect, the national teams of Russia and Belarus, as well as Russian and Belarusian clubs competing in European handball competitions, are suspended. This is valid until further notice and refers to all current competitions at club and national team level", the statement read, following an extraordinary meeting of the body.
In addition to affecting Russian clubs and teams, "Russian and Belarusian referees and officials will also not be appointed for future matches until further notice", as well as members of the Russian and Belarusian federation, who will not be called to meetings and activities.
The EHF justifies that these measures, among others, had to "be introduced with immediate effect, as the war in Ukraine continues to intensify, compromising the organization's principles of cooperation at European level and the spirit of justice".
In the coming days, there will be a restructuring of the various competitions at club and national team level, following existing sporting principles and regulations, as indicated in the note.
Russia launched a military offensive in Ukraine early Thursday morning, with ground forces and bombing of targets in several cities, which has already killed more than 350 civilians, including children, according to Kiev. The UN reported more than 100,000 displaced people and almost 500,000 refugees in Poland, Hungary, Moldova and Romania.
Russian President Vladimir Putin said that the "special military operation" in Ukraine aims to demilitarize the neighboring country and that it was the only way for Russia to defend itself, with the Kremlin specifying that the offensive will last as long as necessary.
The attack was condemned by most of the international community and the European Union and the United States, among others, responded by sending weapons and ammunition to Ukraine and strengthening sanctions to further isolate Moscow.

US President Joe Biden

The President of the United States will hold a telephone conversation this Monday with allies and partners to discuss "the developments" of the Russian attack against Ukraine and "coordinate a united response", declared the White House.
The statement did not specify the identity of the participants, other than Joe Biden, in these talks, which will take place at 4:15 pm GMT (same time in Lisbon),
on the same day that the UN General Assembly will begin debating a resolution condemning Moscow's invasion of Ukraine
.
On Sunday, the G7 countries - Canada, France, Germany, Italy, Japan, the United Kingdom and the United States - warned that they would take "further measures", in addition to the sanctions already announced, if Russia does not stop military operations.

The head of North American diplomacy, Antony Blinken, assured that all G7 members were "fully aligned" against the Russian attack.
Also on Sunday,

in an escalation of the conflict that Washington considered "totally unacceptable".
Russia launched a military offensive in Ukraine early Thursday morning, with ground forces and bombing of targets in several cities, which has already killed at least 352 civilians, including children, according to Kiev. The UN reported nearly 370,000 people displaced to Poland, Hungary, Moldova and Romania.
Russian President Vladimir Putin said that the "special military operation" in Ukraine aimed to demilitarize the neighboring country and that it was the only way for Russia to defend itself, with the Kremlin stating that the offensive would last as long as necessary.
The attack was condemned by most of the international community and the European Union and the United States, among others, responded by sending weapons and ammunition to Ukraine and strengthening sanctions to further isolate Moscow.

UEFA ends sponsorship agreement with Gazprom
by Lusa
Want to share this article?
cancel
Reuters
UEFA terminated its sponsorship contract with Gazprom, a Russian state-owned energy production and distribution company, on the fifth day of Russia's invasion of Ukraine, European football's governing body announced today.
SEE MORE
"UEFA decided today to end the partnership with Gazprom in all competitions. The decision takes immediate effect and covers all existing agreements, including the Champions League, European national team competitions and Euro2024", says the brief statement published on the official UEFA website.
Gazprom, the world's largest natural gas exporter, whose majority share capital is held by the Russian State, was one of UEFA's main sponsors, in an agreement that began a decade ago, in 2012.
Today, the historic German club Schalke 04 also announced that it had terminated its contract with the Russian company, with which it had a sponsorship agreement since 2007.
Russia launched a military offensive in Ukraine early Thursday morning, with ground forces and bombing of targets in several cities, which has already killed more than 350 civilians, including children, according to Kiev. The UN reported more than 100,000 displaced people and almost 500,000 refugees in Poland, Hungary, Moldova and Romania.
Russian President Vladimir Putin said that the "special military operation" in Ukraine aims to demilitarize the neighboring country and that it was the only way for Russia to defend itself, with the Kremlin specifying that the offensive will last as long as necessary.
The attack was condemned by most of the international community and the European Union and the United States, among others, responded by sending weapons and ammunition to Ukraine and strengthening sanctions to further isolate Moscow.

The War

UEFA ends sponsorship agreement with Gazprom
Lusa Agency
Feb 28, 2022
18:39
0
Comments
UEFA terminated its sponsorship contract with Gazprom, a Russian state-owned energy production and distribution company, on the fifth day of Russia's invasion of Ukraine, European football's governing body announced today.
"UEFA decided today to end the partnership with Gazprom in all competitions. The decision takes immediate effect and covers all existing agreements, including the Champions League, European national team competitions and Euro2024", says the brief statement published on the official UEFA website.
Gazprom, the world's largest natural gas exporter, whose majority share capital is held by the Russian State, was one of UEFA's main sponsors, in an agreement that began a decade ago, in 2012.
Today, the historic German club Schalke 04 also announced that it had terminated its contract with the Russian company, with which it had a sponsorship agreement since 2007.
Russia launched a military offensive in Ukraine early Thursday morning, with ground forces and bombing of targets in several cities, which has already killed more than 350 civilians, including children, according to Kiev. The UN reported more than 100,000 displaced people and almost 500,000 refugees in Poland, Hungary, Moldova and Romania.
Russian President Vladimir Putin said that the "special military operation" in Ukraine aims to demilitarize the neighboring country and that it was the only way for Russia to defend itself, with the Kremlin specifying that the offensive will last as long as necessary.
The attack was condemned by most of the international community and the European Union and the United States, among others, responded by sending weapons and ammunition to Ukraine and strengthening sanctions to further isolate Moscow.

Norwegian group Equinor stops investing in Russia
Equinor, which is 67% owned by the Norwegian State, had 1.2 billion dollars (around one billion euros) of assets in Russia at the end of 2021, where it has had a partnership, since 2012, with the oil group Rosneft.
Oil production in Angola
¬©¬†Rodger BOSCH / AFP
Dinheiro Vivo/Lusa
28¬†February,¬†2022¬†‚Ä¢¬†08:37
Share
this article

Comment
Norwegian energy giant Equinor announced this Monday that it will stop investing in Russia and withdraw from joint ventures in the country, in response to the invasion of Ukraine by the Russian military.
Related
Ukraine: Oil company BP announces that it will abandon Russian Rosneft
Oil and gas production resumes in Norway, after forced end of strike
Response to sanctions: Russia's central bank doubles interest rate
Equinor, which is 67% owned by the Norwegian State, had 1.2 billion dollars (around one billion euros) of assets in Russia at the end of 2021, where it has had a partnership, since 2012, with the oil group Rosneft.
"In the current situation, we consider our position to be unsustainable," said the Norwegian company's executive chairman, Anders Opedal, in a statement.
"We will cease all new investment in our Russian operations and begin the process of divestment from our joint ventures in a manner consistent with our values," he added.
Close
