Subscribe
Thank you very much for your registration.
On Sunday, the largest British oil company BP announced that it would divest from Rosneft, in which it holds 19.75%.
Like BP, Equinor said the decision to divest would force it to take action.
The Norwegian company produces around 25,000 barrels of oil equivalent per day in Russia, a fraction of total production of around two million barrels of oil equivalent per day.
"We are all deeply disturbed by the invasion of Ukraine, which constitutes a terrible setback for the world, and we think of all those who suffer because of the military operation," Opedal said.
Norway is not a member of the EU, but has applied the same sanctions as the EU against Russia since the start of the Ukraine crisis.
On Sunday, the Norwegian Government also announced that the country's sovereign wealth fund, the largest in the world, would completely divest from Russia, where it had 2.5 billion euros in shares and bonds at the end of 2021.
Russia launched a military offensive in Ukraine early Thursday morning, with ground forces and bombing of targets in several cities, which has already killed at least 352 civilians, including children, according to Kiev. The UN reported nearly 370,000 people displaced to Poland, Hungary, Moldova and Romania.
Russian President Vladimir Putin said that the "special military operation" in Ukraine aims to demilitarize the neighboring country and that it was the only way for Russia to defend itself, with the Kremlin specifying that the offensive will last as long as necessary.
The attack was condemned by most of the international community and the European Union and the United States, among others, responded by sending weapons and ammunition to Ukraine and strengthening sanctions to further isolate Moscow.

"In light of Belarus's apparent involvement in this aggression, we will adopt sanctions against President Lukashenko and other individuals and organizations, as well as measures to restrict exports," said Kishida, after speaking by phone with Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky.
"To improve the feasibility of the financial sanctions taken by the international community against Russia, we have decided to impose sanctions aimed at restricting transactions with the Russian central bank," the Japanese prime minister added.
In collaboration with its G7 partners, Kishida's government has already announced several sanctions against Moscow, which mainly target financial entities and semiconductor exports to Russia.
In addition to the $100 million in loans already offered to Ukraine, Kishida announced on Sunday that Tokyo would provide an additional $100 million in emergency humanitarian aid.

"Thank you! A truly global anti-war coalition works," he added.

translated_text:
The War
Country
Ukrainians with "burning hearts" gather for peace in the Azores
Lusa Agency
Feb 28, 2022
22:26
0
Comments
Shutterstock photo
Around 700 people gather "for peace" in downtown Ponta Delgada, in the Azores, as a sign of solidarity with the Ukrainians, who are "with their hearts burning".
Under the baton of Ukrainian musicians from the Ponta Delgada Regional Conservatory, in an atmosphere of emotion in which dozens of Ukrainians were present, Natasha Zagoruy, married, 47 years old, who has lived in Ponta Delgada for 16 years, under the flow of tears says: "my heart is burning a lot".
The Ukrainian has been in contact with her family in Ukraine via the internet and other available means, but this does not reassure her, as she is in a "constant state of alert" regarding the possibility of her family being directly confronted with the Russian offensive in the country.
"On the third day, when it was known that Kiev was going to be bombed very heavily, I spent the whole night in front of the television, with our saints, praying with Our Lady of F√°tima", says Natasha Zagoruy, who says that her family members are managing to remain calm, avoiding panic, despite their anxiety.
Oleksandr Dushivsky and his wife have lived in Ponta Delgada for more than 20 years and have remained in contact with their family, who "did not expect that Russia would enter Ukrainian land", with those in the family considering that it was just psychological pressure.
Oleksandr's wife interrupts her husband's emotional moment to mention that what Putin wants is for Ukraine to "be at his feet".
The young Oleksandra Okhrytm, aged 27, who has been in the Azores for six months, where she met her boyfriend, also Ukrainian, is "heartbroken", and all those who are dying in this conflict are members of her family, who "at this moment are far from the most dangerous area", having daily contact with her.
Maria Cristina Borges, president of the Association of Immigrants of the Azores (AIPA), where several members are Ukrainians, considers that "it makes no sense that in the 21st century we are experiencing problems like these", calling for dialogue.
AIPA and other institutions, through Ponta Delgada City Council, in partnership with firefighters, are mobilizing resources to welcome refugees, and the municipality has already created a support line.
A group of Azoreans has now created a support group on social media with the aim of encouraging owners of local accommodation and tourism spaces to make them available to Ukrainians who decide to join their family members in the Azores.
Chanting slogans such as "for peace and not war", the hundreds of people who gathered in downtown Ponta Delgada held signs inviting Putin to leave Ukraine and calling for an end to the conflict.
Russia launched a military offensive in Ukraine early Thursday morning, with ground forces and bombing of targets in several cities, which has already killed more than 350 civilians, including children, according to Kiev. The UN reported more than 100,000 displaced people and almost 500,000 refugees in Poland, Hungary, Moldova and Romania.
Russian President Vladimir Putin said that the "special military operation" in Ukraine aims to demilitarize the neighboring country and that it was the only way for Russia to defend itself, with the Kremlin specifying that the offensive will last as long as necessary.

Ukraine
Boris says Putin seeks to divert attention with nuclear force on alert
Boris Johnson joined the Ukrainian community at the Holy Family Cathedral in London
Photo:¬†Jamie Lorriman / POOL / AFP
27¬†February¬†2022
JN/Agencies
27¬†February¬†2022¬†at¬†11:23 pm

Boris says Putin seeks to divert attention with nuclear force on alert
Comment

JN/Agencies
27¬†February¬†2022¬†at¬†11:23 pm
Facebook
Twitter
Share
Comment
British Prime Minister Boris Johnson considered this Sunday that Russian President Vladimir Putin is trying to distract attention from the strong resistance on the ground by Ukrainians to Russian troops by putting nuclear forces on alert.
"I think it's a distraction from the reality of what's happening in Ukraine," Johnson said, after meeting members of the Ukrainian community in London.
"These are innocent people facing completely unprovoked aggression, and what is actually happening is that they are perhaps defending themselves with more resistance than the Kremlin imagined," he added.
The President of Russia, Vladimir Putin, ordered Russian deterrence forces, which may include a nuclear component, to be placed on high alert due to "aggressive statements" from the West.
"I order the Minister of Defense and the Chief of Staff to put the deterrent force of the Russian army on special combat alert," Putin said in a televised meeting with his military chiefs, cited by the France-Presse agency.
Russia launched a military offensive in Ukraine early Thursday morning, with ground forces and bombing of targets in several cities, which has already killed around 200 civilians, including children, according to Kiev. The UN reported nearly 370,000 refugees in Poland, Hungary, Moldova and Romania.
Russian President Vladimir Putin said that the "special military operation" in Ukraine aims to demilitarize the neighboring country and that it was the only way for Russia to defend itself, with the Kremlin specifying that the offensive will last as long as necessary.
PUB
The attack was condemned by most of the international community and the European Union and the United States, among others, responded by sending weapons and ammunition to Ukraine and strengthening sanctions to further isolate Moscow.

translated_text:
The War
World
Oil company BP announces that it will abandon Russian Rosneft
Lusa Agency
Feb 28, 2022
05:08
0
Comments
British oil company BP announced today that it will leave Russian giant Rosneft, in which it holds a 19.75% stake, following Russia's invasion of Ukraine.
In a statement, cited by the France-Presse agency, the oil group specified that managing director Bernard Looney had resigned from Rosneft's board of directors, "with immediate effect", as had another director appointed by BP.
"Russia's attack on Ukraine is an act of aggression that has tragic consequences across the region," said BP Chairman Helge Lund.
According to the official, "BP has operated in Russia for more than 30 years (...), but this military action represents a fundamental change", leading "BP's board of directors to conclude, after a thorough process, that our involvement in Rosneft, a state-owned company, simply could not continue".
Like BP, Russian oil giant Rosneft is also listed in London. The presence among its shareholders of BP since 2013, which held the second largest stake after the Russian State, was regularly criticized in the United Kingdom.
Following this withdrawal, BP indicated that the group would make a provision in its accounts for the first quarter of 2022, which will be published in May.
Russia launched a military offensive in Ukraine early Thursday morning, with ground forces and bombing of targets in several cities, which has already caused around 200 deaths, including civilians, and more than 1,100 injuries, on Ukrainian territory, according to Kiev. The UN reported nearly 370,000 people displaced to Poland, Hungary, Moldova and Romania.

The ruble today fell by almost 30% against the US dollar, Asian stocks fell and the price of a barrel of US benchmark oil, West Texas Intermediate (WTI), increased by more than 5%.
The Russian currency lost 27% against the dollar, Bloomberg News reported, after international powers imposed new, tougher sanctions on Moscow for its invasion of Ukraine.
Asian share prices fell on stock exchanges in Tokyo, Hong Kong and Shanghai.
The price of a barrel of WTI crude rose more than 5% in the first transactions, also today, highlighting the nervousness of the markets in the face of a likely energy crisis, following the conflict in Ukraine.
Russia launched a military offensive in Ukraine early Thursday morning, with ground forces and bombing of targets in several cities, which has already killed at least 352 civilians, including children, according to Kiev. The UN reported nearly 370,000 people displaced to Poland, Hungary, Moldova and Romania.
Russian President Vladimir Putin said that the "special military operation" in Ukraine aims to demilitarize the neighboring country and that it was the only way for Russia to defend itself, with the Kremlin specifying that the offensive will last as long as necessary.
The attack was condemned by most of the international community and the European Union and the United States, among others, responded by sending weapons and ammunition to Ukraine and strengthening sanctions to further isolate Moscow.

The Moscow Stock Exchange will not operate on Wednesday, as it will on Monday, due to the impact of Western sanctions against Russian banks, sovereign debt and the Central Bank of Russia, the monetary entity said in a statement today.
The Central Bank of Russia, which had previously said it would decide on the reopening of the exchange in the early hours of Wednesday, made the decision today, after the ruble suffered a historic drop of almost 30% in the Forex market.
In the early hours of the morning, the ruble fell on the Forex market against the dollar and the euro by almost 30%.
By mid-afternoon, the currency had slowed its depreciation to around 23% for both the dollar and euro, falling to 103.16 rubles per dollar and as low as 115.7 rubles per euro, but was still at record lows.

The UN reported more than 100,000 displaced people and almost 500,000 refugees in Poland, Hungary, Moldova and Romania.
Russian President Vladimir Putin said that the "special military operation" in Ukraine aims to demilitarize the neighboring country and that it was the only way for Russia to defend itself, with the Kremlin specifying that the offensive will last as long as necessary.
The attack was condemned by most of the international community and the European Union and the United States, among others, responded by sending weapons and ammunition to Ukraine and strengthening sanctions to further isolate Moscow.

translated_text:
The War
World
EU arms supply well underway, but under secrecy
Lusa Agency
Feb 28, 2022
16:25
0
Comments
The head of European diplomacy assured that the mobilization and delivery of weapons to Ukraine, discussed today by EU defense ministers, is well underway, but declined to give details, as "Russia would very much like" to know them.
"In terms of mobilizing resources, everything is well underway. The delivery requires important logistics that the Member States have to organize, and it has to be done quickly. But we are in a war and I am not going to give any information that could be of use to the side we are facing. I am sure that Russia would be very happy to know where and how the help we are going to give will pass" to the Ukrainian army to defend itself, said Josep Borrell.
The High Representative of the European Union (EU) for Foreign and Security Policy was speaking at a press conference in Brussels, after a videoconference of defense ministers of the 27, held to discuss at a "more technical" level the implementation of the historic support package of 450 million in weapons for Ukraine agreed the day before by the foreign ministers.
In the same statements, Borrell recalled that Moscow has already warned that it will attack "any person or entity that transports this aid", which is why he declined to provide "any details that could be useful to them".
Borrell, who the day before had thanked Poland for offering itself as a logistical 'hub' for the transfer of material assistance to Ukraine, limited himself to saying that, "naturally", it "will pass through countries that have a border with Ukraine, that's no secret", and added that it was decided to create a cell, which will work in coordination with NATO, to monitor "Ukraine's requests and needs" and the routing of armament, which includes defensive material, namely anti-tank, and weapons and ammunition of all calibers.
The High Representative highlighted that defense ministers worked hard today "in coordinating efforts to ensure maximum effectiveness" not only in the mobilization and delivery of weapons acquired with funding of 450 million euros, but also those supplied to the Ukrainian armed forces by several Member States on a bilateral basis.
Borrell revealed that Ukraine has also requested more support in terms of military information, and the EU is already mobilizing its satellite center, based in Madrid, to "work in this direction".
The head of European diplomacy also indicated that an assessment of the evolution of the military situation on the ground was made, based on information collected by several Member States, and the conclusion is that "Russia's military campaign is becoming increasingly brutal".
But, he stressed, that "the Ukrainian armed forces are fighting with courage" and "whoever said that the fall of Kiev was a matter of hours" was wrong, as the capital continues to resist, as do Mariupol and Kharkiv.
However, the High Representative recognized that "it is vital" to support the Ukrainian armed forces in the face of an aggressor with many more military assets.
"They need ammunition, defensive weapons of any type, and we will provide them," he said, reiterating that Sunday's decision by the EU, supported "by everyone, all Member States", to provide military assistance to a third country targeted by aggression is historic and marks a new chapter in European construction.
On Sunday, in what was their fourth meeting in the space of a week, the 27 Foreign Ministers approved a 450 million euro package to finance the supply of lethal weapons to the Ukrainian army, which is fighting against the Russian invasion, in a decision that marks a historic turning point in the EU.
Russia launched a military offensive in Ukraine early Thursday morning, with ground forces and bombing of targets in several cities, which has already killed more than 350 civilians, including children, according to Kiev.
The UN reported more than 100,000 displaced people and almost 500,000 refugees in Poland, Hungary, Moldova and Romania.
Russian President Vladimir Putin said that the "special military operation" in Ukraine aims to demilitarize the neighboring country and that it was the only way for Russia to defend itself, with the Kremlin specifying that the offensive will last as long as necessary.
The attack was condemned by most of the international community and the European Union and the United States, among others, responded by sending weapons and ammunition to Ukraine and strengthening sanctions to further isolate Moscow.
Josep Borrell

Equinor, which is 67% owned by the Norwegian State, had 1.2 billion dollars (around one billion euros) of assets in Russia at the end of 2021, where it has had a partnership, since 2012, with the oil group Rosneft.
"In the current situation, we consider our position to be unsustainable," said the Norwegian company's executive chairman, Anders Opedal, in a statement.
"We will cease all new investment in our Russian operations and begin the process of divestment from our joint ventures in a manner consistent with our values," he added.
On Sunday, the largest British oil company BP announced that it would divest from Rosneft, in which it holds 19.75%.
Like BP, Equinor said the decision to divest would force it to take action.
The Norwegian company produces around 25,000 barrels of oil equivalent per day in Russia, a fraction of total production of around two million barrels of oil equivalent per day.
"We are all deeply disturbed by the invasion of Ukraine, which constitutes a terrible setback for the world, and we think of all those who suffer because of the military operation," Opedal said.
Norway is not a member of the EU, but has applied the same sanctions as the EU against Russia since the start of the Ukraine crisis.
On Sunday, the Norwegian Government also announced that the country's sovereign wealth fund, the largest in the world, would completely divest from Russia, where it had 2.5 billion euros in shares and bonds at the end of 2021.
Russia launched a military offensive in Ukraine early Thursday morning, with ground forces and bombing of targets in several cities, which has already killed at least 352 civilians, including children, according to Kiev. The UN reported nearly 370,000 people displaced to Poland, Hungary, Moldova and Romania.
Russian President Vladimir Putin said that the "special military operation" in Ukraine aims to demilitarize the neighboring country and that it was the only way for Russia to defend itself, with the Kremlin specifying that the offensive will last as long as necessary.
The attack was condemned by most of the international community and the European Union and the United States, among others, responded by sending weapons and ammunition to Ukraine and strengthening sanctions to further isolate Moscow.

O
International Criminal Court, in the Dutch city of The Hague, will open an investigation into the alleged war crimes committed by Russia against Ukraine, following the invasions that have lasted five days,
advances The Guardian
.
Initially, Lithuania reportedly asked the aforementioned body to open an investigation that would look into potential war crimes arising from the Russian invasion of Ukrainian territory.
Following this initiative, Karim Khan, prosecutor at the International Criminal Court, is expected to open an investigation in the coming days. This is after Khan issued a statement last Friday recalling that Ukraine had given the court authority to investigate war crimes since 2014.
Now, the prosecutor has maintained that his office "remains fully committed to preventing atrocity crimes and ensuring that anyone responsible for such crimes is held accountable."
The Kiev government is also preparing a lawsuit against Moscow, following the violent attacks that have been indiscriminately targeting military and civilian targets on Ukrainian territory. The same will soon be presented to the International Criminal Court.
This is after Ukraine also took Russia to the International Court of Justice (ICJ), because the country had launched an invasion under the pretext of false allegations that a genocide was taking place on Ukrainian territory, perpetrated against Russian speakers residing in the country.

Japan will adopt sanctions against Belarusian President Alexander Lukashenko and the Russian central bank, Japanese Prime Minister Fumio Kishida announced today, in reaction to the Russian invasion of Ukraine.
"In light of Belarus's apparent involvement in this aggression, we will adopt sanctions against President Lukashenko and other individuals and organizations, as well as measures to restrict exports," said Kishida, after speaking by phone with Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky.
"To improve the feasibility of the financial sanctions taken by the international community against Russia, we have decided to impose sanctions aimed at restricting transactions with the Russian central bank," the Japanese prime minister added.
In collaboration with its G7 partners, Kishida's government has already announced several sanctions against Moscow, which mainly target financial entities and semiconductor exports to Russia.
In addition to the $100 million in loans already offered to Ukraine, Kishida announced on Sunday that Tokyo would provide an additional $100 million in emergency humanitarian aid.
Zelensky welcomed Japan's decision to adopt "strong sanctions".
"Thank you! A truly global anti-war coalition works," he added.
Russia launched a military offensive in Ukraine last Thursday, with ground forces and bombing of targets in several cities, which has already caused around 200 deaths, including civilians, and more than 1,100 injuries, on Ukrainian territory, according to Kiev. The UN reported nearly 370,000 people displaced to Poland, Hungary, Moldova and Romania.
The operation was condemned by most of the international community and led to emergency meetings between several governments, including the Portuguese, and the North Atlantic Treaty Organization (NATO), the EU and the UN Security Council, with mass sanctions being approved against Russia.

Comments
British Prime Minister Boris Johnson said today that Russian President Vladimir Putin was trying to distract attention from the strong Ukrainian resistance to Russian troops on the ground by putting nuclear forces on alert.
"I think it's a distraction from the reality of what's happening in Ukraine," Johnson said, after meeting members of the Ukrainian community in London.
"These are innocent people facing completely unprovoked aggression, and what is actually happening is that they are perhaps defending themselves with more resistance than the Kremlin imagined," he added.
The President of Russia, Vladimir Putin, today ordered Russian deterrence forces, which may include a nuclear component, to be placed on high alert due to "aggressive statements" from the West.
"I order the Minister of Defense and the Chief of Staff to put the deterrent force of the Russian army on special combat alert," Putin said in a televised meeting with his military chiefs, cited by the France-Presse agency.
Russia launched a military offensive in Ukraine early Thursday morning, with ground forces and bombing of targets in several cities, which has already killed around 200 civilians, including children, according to Kiev. The UN reported nearly 370,000 refugees in Poland, Hungary, Moldova and Romania.
Russian President Vladimir Putin said that the "special military operation" in Ukraine aims to demilitarize the neighboring country and that it was the only way for Russia to defend itself, with the Kremlin specifying that the offensive will last as long as necessary.
The attack was condemned by most of the international community and the European Union and the United States, among others, responded by sending weapons and ammunition to Ukraine and strengthening sanctions to further isolate Moscow.

The War
World
Boris Johnson visits Poland and Estonia
Lusa Agency
Feb 28, 2022
22:29
0
Comments
Photo EPA
British Prime Minister Boris Johnson will travel to Poland and Estonia on Tuesday, two European countries affected by the crisis in Ukraine, and will visit British troops deployed in Eastern Europe, it was announced today.
In Poland, where tens of thousands of Ukrainian refugees have arrived, Johnson will offer diplomatic and financial support, having planned a meeting with his Polish counterpart, Mateusz Morawiecki.
In Estonia he will meet with the Estonian Prime Minister, Kaja Kallas, and the President, Alar Karis.
The British leader will also be with the Secretary General of NATO, Jens Stoltenberg, also traveling to Estonia, with whom he will visit the British troops deployed in that country, in Tapa, close to the border with Russia.
"We share values ‚Äã‚Äãthat are more important than ever to preserve as the humanitarian situation worsens," said the head of the British Government before leaving, quoted in a statement.
Together with allies, Boris Johnson promised to continue to exert "maximum pressure on the Putin regime" to ensure that the Russian President "feels the consequences of his actions in Ukraine".
Russia launched a military offensive in Ukraine early Thursday morning, with ground forces and bombing of targets in several cities, which has already killed more than 350 civilians, including children, according to Kiev.
The UN reported more than 100,000 displaced people and almost 500,000 refugees in Poland, Hungary, Moldova and Romania.
Russian President Vladimir Putin said that the "special military operation" in Ukraine aims to demilitarize the neighboring country and that it was the only way for Russia to defend itself, with the Kremlin specifying that the offensive will last as long as necessary.
The attack was condemned by most of the international community and the European Union and the United States, among others, responded by sending weapons and ammunition to Ukraine and strengthening sanctions to further isolate Moscow.

28¬†February¬†2022¬†at¬†17:49
Topics
Basketball
Modalities
This measure involves CSKA Moscow, UNICS Kazan and Zenit Saint Petersburg in the Euroleague, as well as Lokomotiv Kuban Krasnodar in the Eurocup.
Russian basketball clubs were excluded from the main European competitions this Monday due to the invasion of Ukraine, the Euroleague (ECA) decided.
Related
Basketball.
Queta: from the first contact with the basket to the American dream: "When they got the idea in my head..."
International.
FIFA and UEFA suspend Russian clubs and national team from international competitions
This measure involves CSKA Moscow, UNICS Kazan and Zenit Saint Petersburg in the Euroleague, as well as Lokomotiv Kuban Krasnodar in the Eurocup.
The Euroleague reported that it will "continuously monitor the evolution of the situation" in Ukraine and assumes that, if it is not positive, all results so far with teams from Vladimir Putin's country will be annulled.
"The Euroleague and its clubs reiterate their firm commitment to peace, against any act of violence or war, and will continue to use their voice to promote respect, inclusion and diversity, values ‚Äã‚Äãthat are the basis of the organization and its teams", concludes the organization.
In a first reaction, the Euroleague basketball executive board had announced a ban on games on Russian soil.
Also read
International
Szczesny: "I refuse to be on a pitch, wear my country's colors and listen to the Russian anthem"
Poland's Guardian spoke after his team had already officially announced that they would not be playing in what would be the semi-final to qualify for the next World Cup.
Russia launched a military offensive in Ukraine early Thursday morning, with ground forces and bombing of targets in several cities, which has already killed more than 350 civilians, including children, according to Kiev. The UN reported almost 500,000 people displaced to Poland, Hungary, Moldova and Romania.
Russian President Vladimir Putin said that the "special military operation" in Ukraine aims to demilitarize the neighboring country and that it was the only way for Russia to defend itself, with the Kremlin specifying that the offensive will last as long as necessary.
The attack was condemned by most of the international community and the European Union and the United States, among others, responded by sending weapons and ammunition to Ukraine and strengthening sanctions to further isolate Moscow.

International

After the meeting with Braga in the Europa League play-off, Yuriy Vernydub had demonstrated his desire to return to his country and his full availability to help with whatever was necessary.

The War
Sport
EHF suspends with "immediate effect" clubs and national teams from Russia and Belarus
Lusa Agency
Feb 28, 2022
21:57
0
Comments
Shutterstock photo
The European Handball Federation (EHF) today decided to suspend with "immediate effect" clubs and teams from Russia and Belarus, in light of the Russian military invasion of Ukraine.
With this sanction, the Russians from Chekhovskiye Medvedi, Benfica's opponents in the European Handball League, are automatically prevented from competing in group B, in which the 'reds' are second placed, with 13 points, the same as GOG (Denmark).
"With immediate effect, the national teams of Russia and Belarus, as well as Russian and Belarusian clubs competing in European handball competitions, are suspended. This is valid until further notice and refers to all current competitions at club and national team level", the statement read, following an extraordinary meeting of the body.
In addition to affecting Russian clubs and teams, "Russian and Belarusian referees and officials will also not be appointed for future matches until further notice", as well as members of the Russian and Belarusian federation, who will not be called to meetings and activities.
The EHF justifies that these measures, among others, had to "be introduced with immediate effect, as the war in Ukraine continues to intensify, compromising the organization's principles of cooperation at European level and the spirit of justice".
In the coming days, there will be a restructuring of the various competitions at club and national team level, following existing sporting principles and regulations, as indicated in the note.
Russia launched a military offensive in Ukraine early Thursday morning, with ground forces and bombing of targets in several cities, which has already killed more than 350 civilians, including children, according to Kiev. The UN reported more than 100,000 displaced people and almost 500,000 refugees in Poland, Hungary, Moldova and Romania.
Russian President Vladimir Putin said that the "special military operation" in Ukraine aims to demilitarize the neighboring country and that it was the only way for Russia to defend itself, with the Kremlin specifying that the offensive will last as long as necessary.
The attack was condemned by most of the international community and the European Union and the United States, among others, responded by sending weapons and ammunition to Ukraine and strengthening sanctions to further isolate Moscow.

Lubmin in September
One morning in September 2018, a colossal ship, the Audacia, approached Lubmin, on the coast of the Baltic. He carried with him a glittering cargo, tons of steel pipelines that gleamed in the autumn sun; On the back, in bold letters, were inscribed brief words, Nord Stream 2.
Months earlier, in January 2018, Secretary of State Rex Tillerson declared that America and Poland were opposed to the project with that name, which was also opposed by the then President of Ukraine, Petro Poroshenko, by the Polish Prime Minister, Mateusz Morawiecki, by President Donald Trump, by the President of the European Council, Donald Tusk, by the then British Foreign Minister, Boris Johnson, by the Prime Ministers of Italy and Hungary, Matteo Renzi and Viktor Orb√°n.
Even before, much earlier, in March 2016, nine European leaders - the prime ministers of the Czech Republic, Croatia, Estonia, Hungary, Latvia, Poland, Romania and Slovakia, and the president of Lithuania - had written an incisive letter to the president of the European Commission, Jean-Claude Juncker, warning him that Nord Stream 2 would have "geopolitical consequences destabilizing in Europe".
Since it was launched in 1997, the Nord Stream project has been the subject of intense controversy. The largest subsea gas pipeline in the world, with a length of 1,222 kilometers, Nord Stream 1 connects Vyborg, Russia, to Lubmin, on the Baltic coasts. In addition to serious environmental concerns, firstly because it induces the consumption of a non-renewable and highly polluting energy source, with a powerful carbon impact (each pair of Nord Stream pipelines can generate emissions of 110 million tons of CO2/year), directly contradicting the decarbonization and combating climate change agenda established in the Paris Agreement, the Russian-German gas pipeline raises problems of various kinds, affecting marine life in a vast geographical area and stirring up the bottom of a sea where, during For decades, a little bit of everything was being dumped: unexploded mines, soldiers' bodies, carcasses of ships and submarines from the Second World War, waste and toxic materials, chemical weapons, tons of dangerous waste.
Among the many ironies of this story, one of the greatest lies in the fact that Lubmin, the port of arrival of the Nord Stream and the Audacia, is a land particularly plagued by floods and rising ocean water levels. It was submerged in the horrible floods of All Saints' Day in the distant year 1304, but now, with climate change, everything is even worse: at the end of 2020, it was flooded again and, according to climatologists, throughout the 20th century the water level rose by 15 centimeters on the German Baltic coast. By a strange coincidence, or perhaps not, the Nord Stream terminal is just a few meters from the dikes and barriers with which Lubmin desperately tries to protect itself from the advance of the seas. With the Russian-German gas pipeline, the scenario will worsen, just remember that gas is a very strong emitter of methane and that methane has a greenhouse effect 28 times greater than CO2. The irony is even greater - and crueler - if we remember that the main industry in Lubmin, located in the former territory of the GDR, was a gigantic nuclear power plant, which had to be closed in 1990 because it did not meet minimum safety requirements and whose demolition costs are currently astronomical, proven proof that, yesterday as today, blindness and greed in environmental and energy matters end up paying for themselves very dearly, with the bill generally handed over to subsequent generations. It is there, in Lubmin, an atomic cemetery threatened by global warming, where gas from Siberia, extracted in fields where thousands of Josef Stalin's victims once died, flows. The world is a strange place.
Despite being asked to do so, the company responsible for building Nord Stream refused to even consider the land alternatives proposed by Finland, Poland, Lithuania and Latvia. For many of these countries, notably Ukraine, the abandonment of current onshore gas pipelines implies a considerable drop in revenue, in the order of 1.5 billion dollars a year, in addition to a significant loss of geopolitical importance and an increase in their exposure to the eternal threat from Russia. A few months ago, on August 23 last year, the President of Ukraine, Volodomir Zelensky, warned Chancellor Angela Merkel that Nord Stream 2 was a "dangerous geopolitical weapon", a fact that did not prevent the project from continuing, despite Zelensky's warning, who at the time of writing is under siege and in danger of losing his life in Kiev, while former Chancellor Merkel's office issues a press release deploring the "war of aggression" waged by Russia and such a "profound rupture in the history of Europe".
Nord Stream 2 was strongly opposed by Donald Trump, a president who is still suspected of having been corrupted by the Russians, and who now praises the military "genius" of Vladimir Putin. The threat of sanctions from the USA motivated, in turn, a strong reaction from Europe: in June 2017, Germany and Austria criticized the United States Senate for discussing and trying to approve, without success, sanctions on companies involved in the Russian-German gas pipeline. Austrian Chancellor Christian Kerr and German Foreign Minister Sigmar Gabriel said that the supply of energy to Europe only concerned Europeans. Among the attacks on Washington, the then Finance Minister, Olaf Scholz, current Chancellor of Germany, stood out, who stated at the time that America's attitude was a "serious interference in the internal affairs of Germany and Europe", with a European Union spokesman lamenting the "imposition of sanctions on EU companies that carry out legitimate businesses".
And, in fact, the partnership with Russia provided many businesses, perhaps not all of them legitimate, to giants such as the Finnish oil company Neste, the German companies Ruhrgas, Wintershall, BASF, E.ON or Europipe, the Italian Snamprogetti, a subsidiary of Eni, the Japanese Sumitomo Heavy Industries, the British Royal Dutch Shell and Rolls Royce plc, the Danish companies Rohde Nielsen A/S, √òrsted A/S and Ramb√∏ll, the Dutch companies Gasunie, Royal Van Oord and Royal Boskalis Westminster N.V., French company Engie, Austrian company OMV, American company Dresser-Rand Group, Swiss company Allseas S.A., Malaysian company Wasco Energy, among many others.
The costs of Nord Stream 2, estimated at 9.5 billion euros, are shared equally between, on the one hand, Uniper, Wintershall Dea, OMV and Royal Dutch Shell and, on the other, Gazprom. The financial engineering of the gas pipeline is very complex, but involves loans from more than 26 commercial banks, and interventions from Cr√©dit Agricole and Soci√©t√© G√©n√©rale, UniCredit, Deutsche Bank, Royal Bank of Scotland (ABN Amro), Dresdner Kleinwort (Commerzbank), with legal assistance from the North American law firm White & Case, based in New York, and the British firm Clifford Chance.
Nord Stream 1 was inaugurated in November 2011 by Chancellor Angela Merkel, then Russian President Dmitri Medvedev, and Dutch and French Prime Ministers Mark Rutte and Fran√ßois Fillon (Fillon recently resigned from his position as administrator of the oil company Zarubeshneft and Sibur, Russia's largest petrochemical company, to which he had been appointed last December). The ceremony symbolically took place in Lubmin, where expensive demolition work is still taking place today on a nuclear power plant from the times of communist Germany.
It was also there that, in May 2018, construction of Nord Stream 2 began. Shortly afterwards, on a September morning, Audacia arrived, loaded with pipelines. Despite American resistance, from Trump and also from Biden, Washington would change its position and, in May 2021, Merkel and Joe Biden reached an agreement on the gas pipeline. In June, Secretary of State Antony Blinken considered the project "inevitable", dismissing the appeal made in Rome last December by Polish Prime Minister Mateusz Morawiecki, who urged the new German Chancellor "not to give in to pressure from Russia and not to allow Nord Stream 2 to be used as an instrument of blackmail in relation to Ukraine, of blackmail against Poland and of blackmail against Europe".
Gazprom, hidden giant
As a hidden giant, Gazprom is at the epicenter of the current Ukraine crisis. In a remarkable book just published,
Crimes Climatiques - Enqu√™te sur les multinationales qui br√ªlent notre plan√®te
(La D√©couverte, 2022), Portuguese-descendant journalist Micka√´l Correia describes Gazprom as a "fossil ogre" and one of the "largest climate polluters on the planet", such is the amount of CO2 that, over decades, it has released into the atmosphere.
Their modus operandi is, at times, unique. In February 2009, the Swedish Public Prosecutor's Office opened an investigation into a center at the University of Gotland, and it was discovered that Nord Stream had made a strange donation of five million Swedish kronor (around half a million euros) to one of the researchers at that center, who had expressed reservations about the construction of Nord Stream, claiming that it would jeopardize the habitats of many Baltic birds. On the other hand, a report prepared in 2018 by the European Parliament's Environmental Group, entitled
Revolving Doors and the Fossil Fuel Industry
, analyzed the "revolving doors" between politics and energy companies, highlighting the obscure action of Gazprom/Nord Stream in these swampy areas. Even in the Nordic countries, considered a model of transparency, the panorama is frightening: in Sweden, Nord Stream hired the services of Ulrica Schenstr√∂m, former Secretary of State in Prime Minister Fredrik Reinfeldt's office between 2006 and 2007, who had to resign after a newspaper revealed photographs of her hugging and kissing, in a Stockholm restaurant, one of the country's best-known political journalists. For the staff of the gas pipeline consortium, a prominent figure from the Social Democratic Party was also Dan Svanelli, press advisor to successive leaders of that party. In Finland, it went even further and Nord Stream managed to hire the services of a former prime minister, Paavo Lipponen, a consultant for the company since 2008, with the scandal being worsened by the fact that, in complete shamelessness, the hiring was announced while the Russian invasion of South Ossetia was taking place. Lipponen resigned from all public positions, abandoned his office in parliament, wrote an article criticizing Europe's extreme dependence on Russian gas, but the controversy marked him forever: Poland vetoed his candidacy to be responsible for EU external relations and, in 2012, when he ran for the Finnish presidential election, he obtained a measly 6.7% of the vote, the lowest vote ever for the Social Democrats in those elections. Finland also did not benefit from its former PM's membership in Nord Stream: at the time of writing, the spokeswoman for the Russian Ministry of Foreign Affairs dissuaded any Finnish plans to join NATO, saying that, if this were to happen, the country would suffer "serious political and military repercussions".
Austria has been one of the ardent supporters of Nord Stream and, it seems, even tried to block the suspension of the project's entry into operation, imposed recently by the German Chancellor, following the barbaric invasion of Ukraine. The action of Hans J√∂rg Shelling has certainly contributed to this, who, as Finance Minister, from 2014 to 2107, oversaw the Austrian State's 31.5% stake in the energy company OMV, one of the five foreign investors in Nord Stream 2. It turns out that, just three months after leaving the Finance portfolio, Shelling was hired as a consultant for Nord Stream 2, a position he still holds. Not happy, in 2019 he also joined the staff of the energy company OMV, a position he had to leave shortly afterwards, due to a gross violation of the "disgust period" imposed on Austrian politicians. Even so, and as mentioned, she continues to work for Nord Stream 2, the same goes for Marion Scheller, who since 2013 headed the energy policy department of the German Ministry of Economy, leaving that key position in 2016 to join Nord Stream's staff, as "senior advisor for government relations", a euphemism for lobbying actions.
Among the 88 "revolving door" cases uncovered in the 2018 report by the European Parliament's ecologists, the most scandalous and grotesque of all is that of Gerhard Schr√∂der, who, as Chancellor of Germany, between 1998 and 2005 (in a coalition with The Greens, remember), was the biggest Western supporter of the gas pipeline project with Russia. In October 2005, a few weeks before resigning, Schr√∂der's government guaranteed a loan worth one billion euros to Nord Stream. And, shortly after resigning, Schr√∂der was appointed chairman of the supervisory board of Nord Stream AG, becoming a member of its board of directors in 2016; in 2017, he would be appointed by Vladimir Putin to the board of directors of Rosneft, the largest Russian oil company, a fact all the more scandalous given that, at the time, Rosneft was being targeted by economic sanctions from the West due to the Ukraine crisis. His alignment with Moscow has been constant and flawless: in 2007, Schroeder sided with the Kremlin in a dispute with Estonia over a war memorial; in August 2008, he blamed the West for the Russian invasion of South Ossetia; in 2014, he relativized Moscow's conquest of Crimea, comparing it to NATO's intervention in Kosovo. To top it all off, he celebrated his 70th birthday at the Yusupov Palace, in Saint Petersburg, in the company of Vladimir Putin. Now, there is a lot of pressure to leave Nord Stream, but at the moment nothing has happened.
In America, Nord Stream paid five million dollars to Vincent Roberti and one million dollars to Walker Roberts, from the lobbying firm BCR Group, to influence the US Congress in favor of the Russian-German gas pipeline. It is not known what they did, but it is known that in Congress the necessary number of votes was not reached for the sanctions to be approved. The most serious case, however, concerns the executive director of Nord Stream 2, Matthias Warnig, a former Stasi officer, who many say had directly collaborated and became friends with Vladimir Putin when he worked for the KGB in Germany. His membership in the GDR's secret services is factual and uncontroversial, even recognized by himself, but, regarding his relationship with Putin, Warnig says that he only met him in 1991, when the current Russian leader was heading international relations for the municipality of Saint Petersburg. It is, nevertheless, ancient knowledge, which allowed, for example, the Dresdner Bank to establish itself in St. Petersburg in 1991, thanks to the intercession of Warnig who, naturally, would be appointed chairman of the board of directors of the Russian branch of Dresdner. In 2012, Warnig was appointed chairman of the supervisory committee of Rusal, the second largest aluminum company in the world, having to resign in 2018, when Trump imposed severe sanctions on that company. In any case, and in summary, it is this figure with strong and old links to Vladimir Putin who holds and continues to hold the position of CEO of Nord Stream AG, on whose board of directors sit, in addition to several members of Gazprom, Gerhard Schr√∂der, Hans-Ulrich Engel, CEO of BASF, the French Isabelle Kocher, from Engie (formerly GDF Suez), or Johannes Teyssen and Marc Spieker, from the German E.ON.
And now?
In August 2018, the magazine
The Economist
called Nord Stream 2 "the most controversial energy project in the world", saying it would "isolate Ukraine" (sic) and warning of Europe's growing dependence on Russian gas. There may be many explanations, historical and geopolitical, cultural and strategic, for Russia's invasion of Ukraine. But if it is possible to point out one reason why Vladimir Putin has advanced the way he has, that reason is just one: gas. With Europe's extreme dependence on energy from Russia, Moscow knows that any Western "sanctions", no matter how harsh they may be, can never exceed certain limits, under penalty of the Kremlin closing Nord Stream 1 and cutting off gas supplies to Europe. Therefore, Ukraine's destiny was already plotted and written a long time ago, even before Russian troops moved to the border. The dr√¥le de guerre that was witnessed for days, weeks, with a more than late reaction time and the first measures were only taken when the Russians were already inside Ukraine, clearly shows the fear and immense fragility of an EU at the mercy of gas coming from Siberia and the moods of a man with an "aluminum gaze", as Anna Arutunyan described him in The Putin Mystique. With the Russians installed in Kiev, no one thought, nor could they, of ending the supplies coming from Nord Stream 1, while Switzerland, the sewer of the world, the authorities soon invoked neutrality to say business as usual in matters of protection and secrecy for the accounts of Russian companies, oligarchs and mafiosi. In fact, it is in Zug, Switzerland, that the headquarters of Nord Stream AG are located, a company whose executive president, it is worth remembering, was a former political police officer in communist Germany. That alone, without anything else, should have been enough to open the eyes of Europe or, better yet, Germany. But neither that, nor the brutal occupation of Georgia, nor the annexation of Crimea, nor the massacre in Syria, nor the scandals involving former politicians (the German Schr√∂der, the Finnish Lipponen, the Austrian Shelling), nor the hundreds of bloody clashes in the Donbass over the years, nor the 15 thousand deaths in Ukraine, nor the threats from America, nor the criticisms of environmentalists, nor the warnings from Ukraine, Poland (in 2006, a Polish minister compared Nord Stream to the Molotov-Ribbentrop pact), from Estonia, Hungary, Latvia, Romania, Slovakia and Lithuania, nothing, in short, deterred Germany, Austria and France from this suicidal - and homicidal - project. For these countries - and it must be said - Ukraine's sovereignty, the freedom and well-being of its people, security and democracy in Europe were worth less, much less, than the gas coming from the Siberian steppes. In 2019, Gazprom's CEO publicly congratulated himself on having distributed the highest dividends in the company's history: in just one year, the company's market capitalization had grown by 87%. The invoice came now, and we paid for it.
Over the years, without trying to have its own common defense and security policy, comfortably sheltering itself under the protective shield of NATO and the USA (while attacking the American "interference" in Nord Stream), the European Union did not manage to diversify its energy sources and make a serious bet on renewables, thereby putting its future and the future of millions of citizens at risk, placed at the mercy of an unscrupulous dictator and a corrupt regime, vulnerable to climate catastrophe. imminent and already underway.
Among other disasters, the EU was unable to understand that Vladimir Putin's current Russia is no longer even a State, but a game of mirrors, a theater of shadows that plays with the concepts and distinctions of the past (capitalism vs. communism, West vs. East) to establish a regime that is mixed and confused in everything and in which, on the one hand, the most extreme extremes of savage capitalism are combined, in the form of a kleptocracy of oligarchs, and, on the other, of State authoritarianism embodied in an unscrupulous tyrant. Despite the lack of freedom, the death of opponents, the violations of human rights, the barbaric persecutions, it was with him that the German Chancellor sat down, negotiated, and fine-tuned the terms of a disastrous and criminal energy partnership from all points of view, economic and political, geostrategic, environmental. In the East, the aggressor is Putin, but on our side, the Ukraine catastrophe has a name and a face, Angela Merkel.
Due to blindness, pure unconsciousness, greed for profit and aberrant indifference to the fate of Ukraine and neighboring states, Europe's energy was treated as a commercial issue, when it is essentially a political and geostrategic problem. Now, it is not the same thing to buy gas from a commercial democracy, like the USA, or from a dictatorship that wants to destroy us, like Russia. From then on, the fate of an entire nation, written long ago in the stars, was decided. Without risking predictions, what will happen in the near future will be, at best, a shift to the west of the border of insecurity, until now placed in Ukraine, but from now on located in Poland, Slovakia, Moldova and Hungary, all countries that, not by chance, alerted in due time to the Nord Stream tragedy. This, of course, will be opened at the appropriate time, when European public opinion calms down, with the classic argument that "there is no alternative" and that the investments made, in the order of billions, cannot be lost. Nord Stream 2, it is worth remembering, was ready to be launched, shining like new, it was not stopped mid-course, with work to be completed.
Putin will be affected, without a doubt, and will eventually be swallowed up by China, but it is naive to think that he did not weigh up to the millimeter the pros and cons of this adventure in the West, knowing in advance that Europe is trapped by the gas bill: around 41% of the gas consumed in the EU-27 comes from Russia and there are countries, such as Hungary and the Czech Republic, where this dependence reaches almost 100%. Now, Ursula von der Leyen seems to have woken up from a lethargy of months or years, and the Union's leaders, forgetting what they were saying a while ago about American "interference" in the matter (last year!), are talking idly about the need to diversify their energy sources. Afternoon they chirped.
On the other hand, the current phase of "European unity", with grandiloquent declarations for media consumption, will soon pass, being replaced by a deep-seated, and more than justified, resentment of the countries of the Far East towards Germany, but also towards France and, by extension, towards the entire Union. The tensions already experienced between Poland and Belarus will tend to worsen and the authoritarian nationalism of Warsaw and Budapest has gained here a new breath and a powerful arsenal propaganda due to the "betrayal" of Berlin and Brussels. Europe was united for a moment against the threat from Russia, but in the long term the potential for the EU's disintegration is enormous, with serious risks of new "Brexits" in the East. By targeting Kiev, Putin wanted, above all, to hit Brussels, and he succeeded.
Chapeau
.

The War
Country
Municipality of Oliveira do Hospital available to receive refugees
Lusa Agency
Feb 28, 2022
03:03
0
Comments
The municipality of Oliveira do Hospital today expressed its willingness to welcome refugees from Ukraine, after the military invasion of Russia.
"In the face of calls from international institutions, we cannot remain insensitive and we have a duty to show solidarity with the Ukrainian people, who are currently experiencing one of the saddest moments in their history", said the president of the Municipal Council of Oliveira do Hospital, Jos√© Francisco Rolo, quoted in a press release.
The mayor added that the municipality is in a position to "provide a life opportunity for Ukrainian citizens who want to live in a safe place".
Jos√© Francisco Rolo, who "strongly condemns Russia's military action in Ukraine", also stated that the municipality will immediately communicate to the Government and the Ukrainian Embassy in Portugal the reception program that is being prepared, with a view to actively collaborating in humanitarian aid to the Ukrainian people, through the sending of goods considered essential.
In the same note, the chamber informs that it will also "open its doors" to Ukrainian citizens residing in Oliveira do Hospital, who have family members in Ukraine and who may need help.
"We are a supportive people, who like to help citizens in times of greatest difficulty and, within our possibilities, we will do everything we can to make a contribution to helping a people who are experiencing moments of great suffering, as a result of the atrocity of a war that causes us great indignation", says the mayor.
Russia launched a military offensive in Ukraine early Thursday morning, with ground forces and bombing of targets in several cities, which has already caused at least 198 deaths, including civilians, and more than 1,100 injuries, on Ukrainian territory, according to Kiev. The UN reported 150,000 displaced people to Poland, Hungary, Moldova and Romania.
Russian President Vladimir Putin said that the "special military operation" in Ukraine aims to demilitarize the neighboring country and that it was the only way for Russia to defend itself, with the Kremlin specifying that the offensive will last as long as necessary.
The attack was condemned by most of the international community and led to emergency meetings of several governments, including the Portuguese, and the North Atlantic Treaty Organization (NATO), EU and UN Security Council, with mass sanctions being approved against Russia.

Photo EPA
Supporters of Alexey¬†Navalny, the currently imprisoned Russian opposition leader, today called for "civil disobedience" by the Russian population in protest against the invasion of Ukraine¬†ordered by Russian President Vladimir Putin.
"We must show that we do not support this bloody war. We call for civil disobedience from all Russians," said opponents Iv√°n Zhdanov and Leonid V√≥lkov, currently in exile, in a video published on Navalny's account on the social network¬†Telegram.
"Putin declared war on Ukraine. Furthermore, he threatens the entire world with nuclear weapons and tries to make everyone believe that it was Russia that attacked Ukraine - that is, us. But this is not the case," said the opponents.
Zhdanov and Volkov called on the military "not to carry out criminal orders."
"If you work for the State and can refuse, refuse. If you have acquaintances who believe in the propaganda, talk to them and convince them. If you are¬†ready to express yourself on social media, express yourself,¬†protest, leave", they appealed.
The Russian President calls the invasion of Ukraine a¬†‚Äúspecial military operation‚Äù and the Kremlin-controlled press replicates this expression, as well as Putin‚Äôs arguments.
Meanwhile, in Russia, protests against the war in Ukraine continue and cases of police abuse are mounting.
According to the OVD-info portal, an organization specializing in monitoring prisons and defending detainees, Russian police have made a total of 6,416 arrests since February 24.
This Monday, police arrested at least 387 protesters in 13 Russian cities, the majority (202) in Moscow, while in Saint Petersburg 164 people were arrested.
Russia launched a military offensive in Ukraine early Thursday morning, with ground forces and bombing of targets in several cities, which has already killed more than 350 civilians, including children, according to Kiev. The UN reported more than 100,000 displaced people and almost 500,000 refugees in¬†Poland, Hungary, Moldova and Romania.
Russian President Vladimir Putin said that the "special military operation" in Ukraine aims to demilitarize the neighboring country and that it was the only way for Russia to defend itself, with the Kremlin specifying that the offensive will last as long as necessary.
The attack was condemned by most of the international community and the European Union and the United States, among others, responded by sending weapons and ammunition to Ukraine and strengthening sanctions to further isolate Moscow.

Basketball Euroleague removes Russian clubs from its competitions
Lusa Agency
Feb 28, 2022
18:06
0
Comments
Shutterstock photo
Russian basketball clubs were excluded from the main European competitions today due to the invasion of Ukraine, the Euroleague (ECA) decided today.
This measure involves CSKA Moscow, UNICS Kazan and Zenit Saint Petersburg in the Euroleague, as well as Lokomotiv Kuban Krasnodar in the Eurocup.
The Euroleague reported that it will "continuously monitor the evolution of the situation" in Ukraine and assumes that, if it is not positive, all results so far with teams from Vladimir Putin's country will be annulled.
"The Euroleague and its clubs reiterate their firm commitment to peace, against any act of violence or war, and will continue to use their voice to promote respect, inclusion and diversity, values ‚Äã‚Äãthat are the basis of the organization and its teams", concludes the organization.
In a first reaction, the Euroleague basketball executive board had announced a ban on games on Russian soil.
Russia launched a military offensive in Ukraine early Thursday morning, with ground forces and bombing of targets in several cities, which has already killed more than 350 civilians, including children, according to Kiev. The UN reported almost 500,000 people displaced to Poland, Hungary, Moldova and Romania.
Russian President Vladimir Putin said that the "special military operation" in Ukraine aims to demilitarize the neighboring country and that it was the only way for Russia to defend itself, with the Kremlin specifying that the offensive will last as long as necessary.
The attack was condemned by most of the international community and the European Union and the United States, among others, responded by sending weapons and ammunition to Ukraine and strengthening sanctions to further isolate Moscow.

Lusa Agency
Text

i
MIKHAIL PALINCHAK/EPA
MIKHAIL PALINCHAK/EPA
Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky decided to release prisoners with military experience to join the fight against Russian forces, who launched an offensive against Ukraine five days ago.
"Anyone who can join the fight against the occupiers should do so. The decision was not easy, from a moral point of view, but useful from the point of view of our protection", declared the Ukrainian President.
"Under martial law, participants in hostilities, Ukrainians with combat experience, will be released and will be able to atone for their guilt in the most dangerous places of war. The key now is defense," Zelensky said.
‚ÄúWhen I ran for President, I said that each one of us is President, because
We are all responsible for our State
. For our beautiful Ukraine. And now,
each of us became a fighter
‚Äú, he highlighted earlier in a video message before the start of Russian-Ukrainian negotiations on the Ukrainian border with Belarus.
PUB
‚Ä¢ CONTINUE READING BELOW
Zelensky, speaking in Ukrainian, stated that in just four days of the Russian invasion, sixteen Ukrainian children were killed in Russian shelling and another 45 were injured.
Russia launched a military offensive in Ukraine early Thursday morning, with ground forces and bombing of targets in several cities, which has already killed around 200 civilians, including children, according to Kiev. The UN reported nearly 370,000 people displaced to Poland, Hungary, Moldova and Romania.
Russian President Vladimir Putin said that the ‚Äúspecial military operation‚Äù in Ukraine aims to demilitarize the neighboring country and that it was the only way for Russia to defend itself, with the Kremlin stating that the offensive will last as long as necessary.
The attack was condemned by most of the international community and the European Union and the United States, among others, responded by sending weapons and ammunition to Ukraine and strengthening sanctions to further isolate Moscow.

translated_text:
A
Resolution, presented by the United States of America and Albania, was approved by 11 countries. Russia voted against, the United Arab Emirates, China and India abstained.
Although Russia voted against it, no veto could be triggered in this session by one of the five permanent members of the Security Council, including Russia, according to a procedure established in 1950 and entitled "The union for the maintenance of peace".
On Friday, Russia was able to veto a resolution by the United States and Albania that condemned the Russian invasion and demanded the immediate withdrawal of troops from Ukraine.
The resolution adopted today justifies the convening of the extraordinary session of the General Assembly with the "lack of unanimity" on Friday of the permanent members of the Security Council, which "prevented it from exercising its primary responsibility for the maintenance of international peace and security".
The extraordinary session of the UN General Assembly will be opened by the president of this body, Abdulla Shahid, and the UN Secretary-General, Ant√≥nio Guterres.
On Monday, at the request of France, there will be a new emergency meeting of the Security Council, the fifth in a week, this time to address the humanitarian crisis caused in Europe by the conflict.
France wants a resolution to be adopted demanding "an end to hostilities and the protection of civilians", as well as "unrestricted humanitarian access".
Today, the position on this resolution by Russia, which can use its right of veto, was not yet known.
Russia launched a military offensive in Ukraine early Thursday morning, with ground forces and bombing of targets in several cities, which has already killed around 200 civilians, including children, according to Kiev. The UN reported nearly 370,000 people displaced to Poland, Hungary, Moldova and Romania.
Russian President Vladimir Putin said that the "special military operation" in Ukraine aims to demilitarize the neighboring country and that it was the only way for Russia to defend itself, with the Kremlin specifying that the offensive will last as long as necessary.
The attack was condemned by most of the international community and the European Union and the United States, among others, responded by sending weapons and ammunition to Ukraine and strengthening sanctions to further isolate Moscow.

The attack was condemned by most of the international community and the European Union and the United States, among others, responded by sending weapons and ammunition to Ukraine and strengthening sanctions to further isolate Moscow.

Russian stock market does not reopen Wednesday due to impact of sanctions
Lusa Agency
Feb 28, 2022
19:46
0
Comments
Photo EPA
The Moscow Stock Exchange will also not operate on Wednesday, as it does today, due to the impact of Western sanctions against Russian banks, sovereign debt and the Central Bank of Russia, the monetary entity said in a statement today.
The Central Bank of Russia, which had previously said it would decide on the reopening of the exchange in the early hours of Wednesday, made the decision today, after the ruble suffered a historic drop of almost 30% in the Forex market.
In the early hours of the morning, the ruble fell on the Forex market against the dollar and the euro by almost 30%.
By mid-afternoon, the currency had slowed its depreciation to around 23% for both the dollar and euro, falling to 103.16 rubles per dollar and as low as 115.7 rubles per euro, but was still at record lows.
The Moscow Stock Exchange did not open today, following a decision by the central bank, which feared a sharp fall in shares.
Russia launched a military offensive in Ukraine early Thursday morning, with ground forces and bombing of targets in several cities, which has already killed more than 350 civilians, including children, according to Kiev. The UN reported more than 100,000 displaced people and almost 500,000 refugees in Poland, Hungary, Moldova and Romania.
Russian President Vladimir Putin said that the "special military operation" in Ukraine aims to demilitarize the neighboring country and that it was the only way for Russia to defend itself, with the Kremlin specifying that the offensive will last as long as necessary.
The attack was condemned by most of the international community and the European Union and the United States, among others, responded by sending weapons and ammunition to Ukraine and strengthening sanctions to further isolate Moscow.

translated_text:
O
Irish Foreign Minister, Simon Coveney, admitted the possibility of sending Russian diplomats out, in response to a wave of protests from citizens and most opposition parties, who are calling for the expulsion of the Russian ambassador in Dublin, Yury Filatov.
"I completely understand your feelings and discontent, but I am Foreign Minister and I also have to think about the interests of Irish citizens in Russia and Ukraine," said Coveney.
The head of Irish diplomacy insisted that "some kind of diplomatic channel" and model of communication with Moscow must be maintained to protect the "humanitarian interests of these people", regardless of "what happens in the coming days or weeks".
"That doesn't mean we won't expel diplomats and, in fact, perhaps we will... But I don't think it's smart to expel the Russian ambassador and lose Russia's presence in Ireland which allows us to have a direct line to Moscow," explained Coveney.
The minister also said that his country intends to act in line with other European Union partners, who are meeting today to study a coordinated response to the issue of Russian diplomats.
Russia launched a military offensive in Ukraine last Thursday, with ground forces and bombing of targets in several cities, which has already caused around 200 deaths, including civilians, and more than 1,100 injuries, on Ukrainian territory, according to Kiev. The UN reported nearly 370,000 people displaced to Poland, Hungary, Moldova and Romania.
The operation was condemned by most of the international community and led to emergency meetings between several governments, including the Portuguese, and the North Atlantic Treaty Organization (NATO), the EU and the UN Security Council, with mass sanctions being approved against Russia.

translated_text:
The War
World
UN Security Council convenes General Assembly for Monday
Lusa Agency
Feb 27, 2022
23:56
0
Comments
The United Nations Security Council today adopted a resolution calling for an extraordinary emergency session of the UN General Assembly for Monday, so that its members can comment on the war in Ukraine.
The resolution, presented by the United States of America and Albania, was approved by 11 countries. Russia voted against, the United Arab Emirates, China and India abstained.
Although Russia voted against it, no veto could be triggered in this session by one of the five permanent members of the Security Council, including Russia, according to a procedure established in 1950 and entitled "The union for the maintenance of peace".
On Friday, Russia was able to veto a resolution by the United States and Albania that condemned the Russian invasion and demanded the immediate withdrawal of troops from Ukraine.
The resolution adopted today justifies the convening of the extraordinary session of the General Assembly with the "lack of unanimity" on Friday of the permanent members of the Security Council, which "prevented it from exercising its primary responsibility for the maintenance of international peace and security".
The extraordinary session of the UN General Assembly will be opened by the president of this body, Abdulla Shahid, and the UN Secretary-General, Ant√≥nio Guterres.
On Monday, at the request of France, there will be a new emergency meeting of the Security Council, the fifth in a week, this time to address the humanitarian crisis caused in Europe by the conflict.
France wants a resolution to be adopted demanding "an end to hostilities and the protection of civilians", as well as "unrestricted humanitarian access".
Today, the position on this resolution by Russia, which can use its right of veto, was not yet known.
Russia launched a military offensive in Ukraine early Thursday morning, with ground forces and bombing of targets in several cities, which has already killed around 200 civilians, including children, according to Kiev. The UN reported nearly 370,000 people displaced to Poland, Hungary, Moldova and Romania.
Russian President Vladimir Putin said that the "special military operation" in Ukraine aims to demilitarize the neighboring country and that it was the only way for Russia to defend itself, with the Kremlin specifying that the offensive will last as long as necessary.
The attack was condemned by most of the international community and the European Union and the United States, among others, responded by sending weapons and ammunition to Ukraine and strengthening sanctions to further isolate Moscow.

translated_text:
The War
World
Monaco applies sanctions to Russia like those approved by the EU
Lusa Agency
Feb 28, 2022
19:27
0
Comments
Photo EPA
The principality of Monaco announced today that it will adhere to the European Union's sanctions against Russia and that it will adopt "without delay" the procedures to freeze the funds of personalities and apply the sanctions.
Following the example of Switzerland -- which today broke its traditional neutrality to "fully" apply EU sanctions against members of the Russian government with assets in their country --, the Prince of Monaco, Albert II, announced the adoption of the same sanctions "in accordance with his international commitments".
Monaco authorities have not specified who will be affected by this measure, although there are well-known figures such as businessman Dimitri Rybolovlev, owner of AS Monaco.
Albert II of Monaco "firmly" condemned the invasion of Ukraine, conveyed his solidarity with the Ukrainian people, "victims of military operations and bombings", and called for a ceasefire.
"The Principality of Monaco reaffirms its commitment to respecting international law, the sovereignty, integrity and independence of States. It considers that divergences and conflicts should only be resolved through dialogue and diplomacy", said the monarch in a statement.
Regarding humanitarian aid, the Principality is "willing" to support humanitarian organizations involved on the ground.
Russia launched a military offensive in Ukraine early Thursday morning, with ground forces and bombing of targets in several cities, which has already killed more than 350 civilians, including children, according to Kiev. The UN reported more than 100,000 displaced people and almost 500,000 refugees in Poland, Hungary, Moldova and Romania.
Russian President Vladimir Putin said that the "special military operation" in Ukraine aims to demilitarize the neighboring country and that it was the only way for Russia to defend itself, with the Kremlin specifying that the offensive will last as long as necessary.
The attack was condemned by most of the international community and the European Union and the United States, among others, responded by sending weapons and ammunition to Ukraine and strengthening sanctions to further isolate Moscow.

translated_text:
The War
World
EU Defense Ministers meeting to coordinate arms shipments
Lusa Agency
Feb 28, 2022
12:56
0
Comments
PHOTO¬†EPA/STEPHANIE LECOCQ
EU Defense Ministers are discussing today, via videoconference, how to coordinate and implement the historic decision taken the day before by the 27 to send weapons to help Ukraine face Russia's aggression.
At the entrance to the Council headquarters in Brussels, from where he directs the work via videoconference, the EU High Representative for Foreign and Security Policy, Josep Borrell, explained that the objective of today's videoconference at the level of defense ministers is "to coordinate well what the Member States are doing on their part and what is possible to do with the 450 million euro package" that the European bloc decided to allocate to the Ukrainian armed forces.
The head of European diplomacy pointed out that this financial package aims to acquire and supply "defensive weapons, high-caliber weapons, anti-tank equipment, everything that can repel aggression".
Regarding the situation on the ground, Josep Borrell commented that "the fighting is fierce", Kiev and other cities "are resisting and Russia is paying a high price in terms of casualties", but emphasized that the Ukrainian armed forces need help to face a stronger aggressor.
"We have to supply ammunition, weapons and anti-tank equipment, as well as fuel, for the tanks, for the planes, and all of this has to be coordinated", he reinforced.
Josep Borrell reiterated that the world has to act in the face of what is happening in Ukraine, otherwise "it will be the law of the jungle".
"The world cannot allow a powerful country to crush a neighbor using its military capabilities. If we allow it, it is the law of the jungle, the law of the strongest: 'I am stronger than you, I kill you, I impose my will on you'. It is the law of the jungle, and that, for us Europeans, is an existential threat. We will do everything we can to stop" Russian aggression, he declared.
On Sunday, the 27 Foreign Ministers approved a 450 million euro package to finance the supply of lethal weapons to the Ukrainian army, which is fighting against the Russian invasion, in a decision that marks a historic turning point in the EU.
Borrell explained at the time that the political agreement reached at the level of heads of diplomacy was the approval of armament financing, noting the convening of a meeting of defense ministers for today "to coordinate how to convert this assistance into material, and how to transport the material to the front line, for the Ukrainian armed forces fighting against the Russian invasion", he added.
The High Representative took the opportunity to "thank Poland, which offered to be a logistical hub for the transfer of this material assistance to Ukraine".
"I know that the term historical is often overused and abused, but this is certainly a historic moment, for two reasons: firstly, because it is the first time since the end of World War II that a military power invades another sovereign state, in violation of the international order; secondly, because Europeans have reacted in a way that has surprised many people, starting with the Russians," he said.
Russia launched a military offensive in Ukraine last Thursday, with ground forces and bombing of targets in several cities, which has already caused around 200 deaths, including civilians, and more than 1,100 injuries, on Ukrainian territory, according to Kiev. The UN reported nearly 370,000 people displaced to Poland, Hungary, Moldova and Romania.
Russian President Vladimir Putin said that the "special military operation" in Ukraine aims to demilitarize the neighboring country, with the Kremlin stating that the offensive will last as long as necessary.
The attack was condemned by most of the international community and led to emergency meetings of several governments, including the Portuguese, and the North Atlantic Treaty Organization (NATO), EU and UN Security Council, with mass sanctions being approved against Russia.

In Poland, where tens of thousands of Ukrainian refugees have arrived, Johnson will offer diplomatic and financial support, having planned a meeting with his Polish counterpart, Mateusz Morawiecki.
