Russian President Vladimir Putin said that the "special military operation" in Ukraine aims to demilitarize the neighboring country and that it was the only way for Russia to defend itself, with the Kremlin specifying that the offensive will last as long as necessary.
The attack was condemned by most of the international community and the European Union and the United States, among others, responded by sending weapons and ammunition to Ukraine and strengthening sanctions to further isolate Moscow.

There are thousands of Ukrainian refugees who have been fleeing the country since Thursday due to the military offensive launched by Russia in the early hours of February 24th.
The invasion sparked a new refugee crisis with more than 500,000 fleeing Ukraine since last Thursday.
In Korczowa, on the Polish border, chaos is evident.
The Zhyvaha family is one of those in¬† Korczowa after being forced to leave the country. They are sheltering, according to the French newspaper Le Monde, in a giant warehouse transformed into an improvised center for refugees from the Ukrainian war.
Vitali, 52, and Lena, 39, fled Boryspil, on the outskirts of Kiev, with their three daughters. The journey to the border took 36 hours.

‚ÄúWe managed to board a train that left Kiev at 8pm, it was full", says mother Lena. After a few hours of travel to Lviv, the lights go out to cross a confrontation zone. ‚ÄúWe were even prohibited from checking our phones, the train continued at a very low speed, while we saw and heard gunshots around us‚Äù, says the Ukrainian.
The scenery is Dantesque. Thousands gather at the border in hopes of finding a safe place.
Traffic jams are visible and, according to Le Monde, there are completely full buses that are invaded. In addition to all this, the cold at the border is immense.
In recent days temperatures have approached 0 degrees and the minimum temperatures were even negative. Today in Korczowa only three degrees maximum temperature is expected.
Since the start of Russia's invasion of Ukraine on February 24, more than 115,000 refugees have crossed the border into Poland, the Interior Ministry said Saturday. Anyone from Ukraine can enter, even those who do not have valid passports, officials said.

At the Medyka border checkpoint, in southeastern Poland, many people waited in line today to cross into Ukraine.
According to the Associated Press news agency, Ukrainians are returning to their country to defend it from the Russian offensive or to rescue their children.
On the other hand, according to the Polish border guard, more than 150,000 people have fled Ukraine and entered Poland since the conflict began.
At least one million Ukrainians work or study in Poland. Women, who work as nannies or companions for the elderly in several European Union countries, often leave their children in Ukraine in the care of grandparents or other relatives.
The Czech Republic, which borders Poland, plans to financially support Ukrainian families living in the country whose men decide to return to Ukraine to fight.

According to the Associated Press (AP), it was not clear, in this assessment of the last 24 hours, whether all the casualties were civilians.

translated_text:
A
Peace talks between Ukraine and Russia resumed this afternoon in Gomel, Belarus, after reports that they had ended. As Ukrainian presidential advisor Mykhailo Podolyak told Reuters, the meeting focuses on the ceasefire and the withdrawal of Russian troops from Ukraine. Indeed, on this fifth day of the Russian invasion, sanctions pile up for Vladimir Putin's regime and Ukrainian forces in Kiev continue to resist.
Portuguese citizens, who left Ukraine through Moldova and Romania, will return to Portugal today
, as indicated in a statement to which Not√≠cias ao Minuto had access. According to the Ministry of Foreign Affairs, the flight, operated by the airline TAP, will arrive in Bucharest at 5:40 pm (Lisbon time) and should land at Humberto Delgado Airport at 11:10 pm.
Remember that
more than 350 civilians died
since the beginning of the war, with yesterday being marked by the
maximum alert of Russian military deterrence forces.
Furthermore, more than
422 thousand people fled the invasion
Russia, to which there are more than 100,000 people internally displaced by the conflict, the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees (UNHCR) reported today.
Follow the latest developments on the conflict in Ukraine here BY THE MINUTE:
17h55 -
United Kingdom announces new sanctions and condemns ‚Äúbarbaric‚Äù bombings
The UK will
approve new powers to prevent Russian banks from making payments in pounds
and freezing assets of three new institutions, while condemning the "barbaric" bombings in Ukraine.
17h55 -
75% of Russian troops on the border have already entered Ukraine
A US Defense Department official said the country
did not report any "appreciable or notable muscular movements"
of Russian nuclear forces.
17h52 -
Russian invasion. Italy will supply weapons to Ukraine and aid to refugees
Italy said this Monday that
the country is willing to supply weapons to Ukraine and offer aid to refugees
who flee the country on a large scale due to the Russian invasion of their territory. The information was provided by the Reuters agency.
17h51 -
Putin and his regime underestimated the EU's ability to unite
The Defense Minister considered today that the Russian President and regime
"they will have underestimated" the EU's ability to unite
in the face of the conflict in Ukraine, citing reports from European officials about the "very significant impact" of sanctions on Russia.
17h44 -
Russia remains biased, says Ukrainian presidential adviser
After the first round of peace talks between Russia and Ukraine, Ukrainian presidential advisor Mikhailo Podolyak said that the Russian side remains "extremely biased when it comes to the destructive process it launched", highlighting that "binding ultimatums" have not yet been put on the table.
Negotiations are difficult. However, without any obligatory ultimatums already. Unfortunately, the Russian side is still extremely biased regarding the destructive processes it launched.
‚Äî –ú–∏—Ö–∞–π–ª–æ –ü–æ–¥–æ–ª—è–∫ (@Podolyak_M)
February 28, 2022
17h43 -
London media oligarch asks Putin to end war
Russian-born, UK-based oligarch and media mogul Evgeny Lebedev
used the pages of one of his newspapers to ask Russian President Vladimir Putin to end the invasion of Ukraine.
5:40 pm -
"Historic decision". Finland sends weapons to Ukraine
The Government of Finland announced today that
will send weapons to Ukraine
, following the Russian invasion, being a ‚Äúhistoric decision‚Äù.
Helsinki will send 1,500 rocket launchers, 2,500 firearms, 150,000 ammunition and 70,000 food packages, according to Defense Minister Antti Kaikkonen, cited by AFP.
17h11 -
Macron asks Putin for ceasefire, Russian leader demands "demilitarization"
French President Emmanuel Macron today asked Vladimir Putin for a
immediate ceasefire in Ukraine and security conditions for civilians to leave Kiev, while the Russian President demanded the "demilitarization" of the country
under Russian invasion.
Putin and Macron just spoke for 90 minutes.
Doesn't look Putin is ready to back down: he said a deal "is possible only if Russia‚Äôs legitimate security interests are unconditionally taken into account."
‚Äî max seddon (@maxseddon)
February 28, 2022
17h02 -
Sirens sound in Kiev after explosions
In the last few minutes explosions were heard again in Kiev, the Ukrainian capital, where it is currently 7pm. The sirens also sounded again.
Russian forces launch an attack on Kyiv soon after the Ukraine-Russia negotiations are over.
pic.twitter.com/8u4EYP8pkQ
‚Äî The Kyiv Independent (@KyivIndependent)
February 28, 2022
17h00 -
US embassy suspended in Minsk and departure from Moscow authorized
The US State Department announced today that it has
"suspended operations" at the United States embassy in Minsk
, in Belarus, and "authorized the voluntary departure" of non-essential staff and families from the diplomatic representation in Moscow.
16h59 -
Russia invites international players to join the Russian version of SWIFT
The President of the Central Bank of Russia, Elvira Nabiulina, today invited foreign financial market players to
join the SPFS
, the Russian system analogous to SWIFT, the international interbank communication system.
16h58 -
"Stop!": Former Eurovision winner flees Russian attack with her children
Former 2016 Eurovision winner Jamala, 38,
is one of more than 400,000 people who took refuge from the Russian attack on Ukraine.
The Ukrainian, who sang about the war in Ukraine in 1944, now finds herself fleeing a new invasion with her two children. Jamala had been trying to escape with her two children, one of them three years old, and her husband for five days, since the beginning of the invasion, and is now taking refuge in Romania.
16h57 -
Portuguese-Ukrainian solidarity fills a truck in Gaia and leaves for Poland
A truck with supplies gathered at the Cristo Rei Seminary, in Vila Nova de Gaia,
leaves today towards the Polish border with Ukraine
to help Ukrainian refugees and military personnel, a second could leave on Tuesday.
16h57 -
Russian social media sites display anti-Putin messages
The official websites of several Russian media outlets were targeted
computer attack
, this Monday, reveals Reuters. As a result, the pages in question now feature anti-war messages and calls for an end to the invasion carried out by Russia on Ukrainian territory.
16:33 -
Peace talks have already ended
Peace talks between Ukraine and Russia have been concluded, according to the Russian state agency RIA. The presidents will return to their respective countries, before a second round of talks.
The next meeting should take place in the next few days.
16:26 -
Borrell: EU arms supply well underway, but under secrecy
The head of European diplomacy assured that the mobilization and delivery of
armament to Ukraine, discussed today by EU defense ministers, is well underway,
but he declined to give details, as "Russia would very much like" to know them.
16h19 -
Hungary will not allow weapons to pass through its territory
Hungarian Foreign Minister Peter Szijjarto announced that the country will not allow lethal weapons to pass through its territory, nor will it send troops or weapons to Ukraine, according to Reuters.
"These deliveries could be the target of military offensives and we want to ensure Hungary's security. [...] We will not get involved in this war", quotes the news agency.
Ô∏è FM Szijj√°rt√≥: Government does not allow shipment of lethal weapons to pass through Hungary. We did agree to activating EU‚Äôs European Peace Facility, but we won‚Äôt take part in this on a national, bilateral basis.
#UkraineRussia
‚Äî Zoltan Kovacs (@zoltanspox)
February 28, 2022
16h18 -
Roman Abramovich involved in mediating the crisis at the request of Kiev
Russian businessman Roman Abramovich accepted a request from Ukraine to
help mediate peace talks with Russia
, a spokeswoman for the owner of English football club Chelsea said today.
16h18 -
Musician warns Russians: "Your children are being killed by Putin"
Svyatoslav Vakarchuk, a Ukrainian musician and composer, lead singer of the band Okean Elzy, published, this Monday, a video aimed at Russians where
calls on them to take to the streets to stop President Vladimir Putin.
16:17 -
Turn face. FIFA will expel Russia from international competitions
FIFA had issued a statement on Sunday in which it stated that Russia would remain in international competitions, but information from the last few hours reveals that
the Russians will be expelled from these tests.
16h11 -
Putin retaliates and applies "special economic measures" against the US and allies
Vladimir Putin signed a decree-law imposing
"special economic measures for the United States and the countries that joined it"
, advances Sputnik.
16h08 -
President Zelensky formally signs the application for membership of the European Union
The Ukrainian Parliament reported this afternoon that
Zelensky officially signed the application for membership of the European Union
. "It's a historic moment!", celebrated the organization, in a Twitter post.
President
@ZelenskyyUa
has signed application for the membership of
#Ukraine
in the European Union.
This is a historic moment!
pic.twitter.com/rmzdgIwArc
‚Äî Verkhovna Rada of Ukraine (@ua_parliament)
February 28, 2022
15:57 -
Ukrainian ambassador to the United Nations compares Vladimir Putin's regime to the Third Reich
During the general assembly of the United Nations (UN), which met in emergency, Sergiy Kyslytsya, Ukrainian ambassador to the entity, compared the actions of the Russian government to the actions of the Third Reich at the beginning of the Second World War.
"It's time to act. To help Ukraine, which is paying the highest price for its security and freedom, [but also] in the world. If Ukraine does not survive, international peace will not survive. If Ukraine does not survive, the UN will not survive. If Ukraine does not survive, we cannot be surprised if democracy fails next," he warned.
15:52 -
Ukrainian advisor warns of fake account of the country's forces on Telegram
Anton Gerashchenko, an advisor to the Ukrainian government, today warned of a fake armed forces account on Telegram, which allegedly announced the end of peace negotiations in Belarus - and which he blames on the "enemy".
3:50 pm -
Ukraine asks Apple to suspend services in Russia
Deputy Prime Minister of Ukraine Mykhailo Fedorov sent a letter to Apple CEO Tim Cook, where
asks the company to help ‚Äúprotect Ukraine‚Äù
and that Apple services be suspended on Russian territory.
15:48 -
Scotland also rejects playing with Russia and offers help
The Scottish Football Association (SFA) announced today that its national teams
reject playing against Russia at any level
, in protest against the military offensive against Ukraine, and offered help to the Ukrainian federation.
15:48 -
Switzerland will apply sanctions proposed by the EU against Russia
The president of Switzerland, Ignazio Cassis, announced this Monday that the
Switzerland will adopt sanctions imposed by the European Union
to penalize Russia for invading Ukrainian territory, reports The Associated Press.
15:47 -
Guterres: "Nothing justifies the use of nuclear weapons"
The Secretary-General of the United Nations (UN), Ant√≥nio Guterres, once again called for an end to the war in Ukraine, highlighting the "chilling" development surrounding Russia's use of nuclear weapons.
Addressing the UN general assembly, which met on emergency basis - something that happens very rarely, having met only ten times since 1950 - the Portuguese
called for a diplomatic path to end the Russian invasion
, reiterating the power of dialogue.
15:46 -
Around 100 healthcare professionals in solidarity with Ukraine in S. Jos√©
Around a hundred healthcare professionals from Centro Hospitalar Lisboa Central
today showed solidarity with the Ukrainian people in a demonstration
symbolic event at S√£o Jos√© Hospital in which there was a minute of silence and the Ukrainian anthem was sung.
3:35 pm -
Poland and Baltic countries dissatisfied with combating disinformation
The prime ministers of Poland, Lithuania, Latvia and Estonia sent a joint letter to the big North American technology companies asking for more
commitment to combating disinformation
- especially those originating in Russia.
3:35 pm -
Ukrainians sing to Russian troops: "Berdyansk is Ukraine, screw you"
On Monday morning, several hundred Ukrainians gathered at the
Berdyansk City Hall, occupied by the Russians, to protest.
According to Interior Ministry advisor Anton Herashchenko, the Ukrainians began by singing the anthem and more and more people began to arrive. Then the chant began: "Berdyansk is Ukraine! Russians, screw you."
15:34 -
Mozambican opposition condemns ‚Äúwar of invasion‚Äù, Frelimo in silence
Renamo, the main Mozambican opposition party, and MDM, the third party,
today condemned Russia's invasion of Ukraine
, criticizing the Mozambican Government's "silence" in relation to Moscow's military action.
15:33 -
Authorities accused of racial discrimination at Ukraine's borders
On social media, several
reports of black and Afro-descendant emigrants
- students or workers - allegedly being prevented from crossing the border or boarding trains bound for Romania and Poland, solely because of their skin color.
15:32 -
Shakhtar's Brazilian coach and players have already left Ukraine
Shakhtar Donetsk coach, Italian Roberto de Zerbi, and the club's Brazilian players
have already left Ukraine
, on the run following the invasion by Russia, reported today the leader of the Ukrainian football championship
15:13 -

here
.

They gathered at Pra√ßa do Com√©rcio this Sunday to protest against Russia's invasion. They welcomed the creation of a platform to bring together the support received.
The protests increased in tone when they announced the destruction of a Ukrainian commercial plane at Kiev airport, the Antonov AN-225, the largest ever, and that the Russian offensive continues.
Protest actions against Russia and support for Ukraine focus the efforts of the Ukrainian community at this time. There are family and friends who want to come, but they tell DN that the majority will stay, at least for now.
"My family wants to stay, they want to fight for their country
", says Olena Chubur, 41 years old, in Portugal for four years. And she understands, even if they live in a city near Kiev, where there are more clashes. Many of the older men justify that they are no longer old enough to leave the country and the young men are mobilized for war.
Olena Chubur, Sergey Vadouyka and Myron, family who have lived in Portugal for four years
¬©¬†Rita Chantre / Global Imagens
Close
Subscribe to newsletters
News Diary
and receive information first hand.
Subscribe
Olena is a hairdresser, her husband, S√©rgei Vadouyka, 42 years old, graduated in civil engineering, is unemployed. It is the son, Myron, aged 11, who translates the Portuguese words that his parents do not understand. They believe that Ukraine will emerge victorious, with the help of the international community and NATO.
Pavlo Sadokha, president of the Association of Ukrainians in Portugal, left by plane this Sunday for Poland. He will bring the van in which his parents, his 82-year-old mother and his 87-year-old father traveled, as well as his sister and two nephews. They lived in Lviv, a city close to the Polish border, and it took them three days to cross.
Pavlo Sodakha, president of the Association of Ukrainians in Portugal
¬©¬†Rita Chantre / Global Imagens
Pavlo also believes in victory.
"In previous armed conflicts in which Russia emerged victorious, the world did not react so intensely. The sanctions, the closure of airspace, the support, particularly in terms of weapons, are much greater. We know that the Russian armed forces surpass the Ukrainian ones, but international support, NATO, will help Ukraine to emerge victorious in this war."
Protests on several fronts
This Sunday's demonstration at Pra√ßa do Com√©rcio began in the early afternoon, following the various protest actions around the world. Lisbon received another front to the Russian embassy, ‚Äã‚Äãwhich was joined at the end by protesters from Pra√ßa do Com√©rcio. Porto and Faro also received slogans against Putin, whom they call "the new Hitler".
"We want to protect our country, our territory, we fight for peace, for freedom, for the truth. It is not Putin's truth, which justifies war because we do not have a democratic government. We are a democratic country, we elect those who govern us, unlike what happens in Russia. He says he is not killing civilians but people have already died in my city
e. We don't need them, we know how to govern ourselves", protests Tatiana Vereshchapre, who has been in Portugal for six years. His city is Sumy, one of the targets of the Russian attack. Tatiana was born in Ukraine, then part of the Soviet Union, speaks Russian and explains that this freedom was never taken away from her. Part of his family lives in Russia.
Lyudmyla Serbiyenko, Tatiana Vereshchapre, Victoria Teixeira and Magdalena konik
¬©¬†Rita Chantre / Global Imagens
Conversations with family members are had daily, also at night, as there are few hours of sleep. "My family in Ukraine wants to stay, fight, defend their leaders and the country. The family in Russia repeats Russian propaganda, they say they will free us from the fascist government. Replying that this is not the case, they don't believe it, they are afraid", explains Magdalena Konik.
At 24 years old, having lived in Portugal for two years, Magdalena also shares her family between Ukraine and Russia, and also in Poland. "My family members don't want to leave under any circumstances and have the opportunity to come to Portugal or Poland. They justify that they are in their homeland and, for it, they want to fight."
The two women are in a group of operators at the Teleperfomance call center. They feel well integrated and are grateful for the solidarity of the Portuguese. Lyudmyla Serbiyenko, 25 years old, carries a flag from Ukraine and another from Portugal, the latter in the name of her Portuguese boyfriend who was unable to come to the demonstration. Magdalena is also dating a Portuguese man and Victoria Teixeira was married to one and has dual nationality. He has lived in Portugal for seven years.
The hundreds of Ukrainians - also Portuguese, Romanians, Poles, Swedes, Belgians, among other nationalities - reveal unity in the protest, but also the immigrant experience and how they interact with the host society.
Maksym Khieko and Pedro Santos, a Ukrainian and a Portuguese, whose families are crossed with citizens of both countries
¬©¬†Rita Chantre / Global Imagens
Ukrainian Maksym Khieko, 27 years old, left his hometown of Sumy for Lisbon 17 years ago. He is with Pedro Santos, 47 years old, married to a Ukrainian and whose stepdaughter is dating Maksym. The two men carry the flags of their respective countries, they are there for the women who stayed to work. "
Ukrainians are fed up with Putin's lies, he says he wants to negotiate a ceasefire, but I spoke to family members in Sumy who tell me that a Russian military column just passed through, says Maksym. Pedro understands that international measures against the Russian government should be tougher. "They are concerned about international law, when Putin does not respect any law. Even this eventual stop to negotiate is just a way of getting back on the ground."
A group of Erasmus students made a small island out of their travel bags. They study in Beja and are visiting the capital. They feel it is their obligation to participate in the protest, not only for Ukrainians but for all Europeans. A Romanian flag displays its origins, there are also two Belgians.
Erasmus students: Anais (Belgian) Alexandra (Romanian) and Tudor (Romanian), behind, Ilinca (Romanian), Andrea (Romanian) and Maxime (Belgian)
¬©¬†Rita Chantre / Global Imagens
"We are an example of an exchange program that brings people together, what we are seeing should not happen. More economic restrictions are needed to guarantee peace in Europe. We hope it ends as quickly as possible", says Belgian M√°xime.

translated_text:
To
entrance to the Council's headquarters in Brussels, from where he directs the proceedings via videoconference, the EU High Representative for Foreign and Security Policy, Josep Borrell, explained that the objective of today's videoconference at the level of defense ministers is "to coordinate well what the Member States are doing on their part and what is possible to do with the 450 million euro package" that the European bloc decided to allocate to the Ukrainian armed forces.
The head of European diplomacy pointed out that this financial package aims to acquire and supply "defensive weapons, high-caliber weapons, anti-tank equipment, everything that can repel aggression".
Regarding the situation on the ground, Josep Borrell commented that "the fighting is fierce", Kiev and other cities "are resisting and Russia is paying a high price in terms of casualties", but emphasized that the Ukrainian armed forces need help to face a stronger aggressor.
"We have to supply ammunition, weapons and anti-tank equipment, as well as fuel, for the tanks, for the planes, and all of this has to be coordinated", he reinforced.
Josep Borrell reiterated that the world has to act in the face of what is happening in Ukraine, otherwise "it will be the law of the jungle".
"The world cannot allow a powerful country to crush a neighbor using its military capabilities. If we allow it, it is the law of the jungle, the law of the strongest: ¬´I am stronger than you, I kill you, I impose my will on you¬ª. It is the law of the jungle, and that, for us Europeans, is an existential threat. We will do everything we can to stop" Russian aggression, he declared.
On Sunday, the 27 Foreign Ministers approved a 450 million euro package to finance the supply of lethal weapons to the Ukrainian army, which is fighting against the Russian invasion, in a decision that marks a historic turning point in the EU.
Borrell explained at the time that the political agreement reached at the level of heads of diplomacy was the approval of armament financing, noting the convening of a meeting of defense ministers for today "to coordinate how to convert this assistance into material, and how to transport the material to the front line, for the Ukrainian armed forces fighting against the Russian invasion", he added.
The High Representative took the opportunity to "thank Poland, which offered to be a logistical hub for the transfer of this material assistance to Ukraine".
"I know that the term historical is often overused and abused, but this is certainly a historic moment, for two reasons: firstly, because it is the first time since the end of World War II that a military power invades another sovereign state, in violation of the international order; secondly, because Europeans have reacted in a way that has surprised many people, starting with the Russians," he said.
Russia launched a military offensive in Ukraine last Thursday, with ground forces and bombing of targets in several cities, which has already caused around 200 deaths, including civilians, and more than 1,100 injuries, on Ukrainian territory, according to Kiev. The UN reported nearly 370,000 people displaced to Poland, Hungary, Moldova and Romania.
Russian President Vladimir Putin said that the "special military operation" in Ukraine aims to demilitarize the neighboring country, with the Kremlin stating that the offensive will last as long as necessary.
The attack was condemned by most of the international community and led to emergency meetings of several governments, including the Portuguese, and the North Atlantic Treaty Organization (NATO), EU and UN Security Council, with mass sanctions being approved against Russia.

translated_text:
The War
World
International footballers' union calls for suspension of Russian federation
Lusa Agency
Feb 28, 2022
16:37
0
Comments
The International Union of Professional Footballers (FIFPro) today called for the suspension of the Russian Football Union (RFU), due to the military offensive in Ukraine, which would prevent the country's teams and selections from competing in official matches.
"We call for the suspension of the RFU with immediate effect, until peace, security and the rule of law are restored", says FIFPro in a statement, alluding to the country's most recent actions, which on Thursday launched a military offensive in Ukraine.
The union expresses its "disagreement" with the measures announced on Sunday by FIFA, which oblige Russian teams to play on a neutral field, without spectators and without anthem, and under the name of their national federation, not the country, and stands completely alongside the players and clubs.
"FIFPro supports all players and entities in world football who choose not to play against Russian teams, at this distressing time", says the statement, expressing full solidarity with the players from Poland, Sweden and the Czech Republic, involved in the qualifying play-offs for the World Cup 2022, together with Russia, and who have already guaranteed that they do not want to play, even on a neutral ground.
The footballers' union considers that the "united" response of the world's democracies to Russian aggression "showed unity in defending human dignity and the rule of law, and understands that football "has its own responsibility in the matter.
On Sunday, FIFA canceled games in Russia, imposing conditions for them to be played outside the country, days after UEFA transferred the Champions League final, scheduled for May 28, in Saint Petersburg, to Paris.
Several sports federations and competition organizing bodies have canceled or transferred events that were supposed to take place on Russian soil, responding to the appeal launched by the International Olympic Committee.
Russia launched a military offensive in Ukraine early Thursday morning, with ground forces and bombing of targets in several cities, which has already killed more than 350 civilians, including children, according to Kiev. The UN reported more than 100,000 displaced people and almost 500,000 refugees in Poland, Hungary, Moldova and Romania.
Russian President Vladimir Putin said that the "special military operation" in Ukraine aims to demilitarize the neighboring country and that it was the only way for Russia to defend itself, with the Kremlin specifying that the offensive will last as long as necessary.

Home
economy
Portuguese operators offer free calls to the country
Temporary measure comes following the Russian invasion.
Communications with Ukraine will be temporarily free
¬©¬†DR
Dinheiro Vivo/Lusa
28¬†February,¬†2022¬†‚Ä¢¬†21:08
Share
this article
Facebook
Twitter
WhatsApp
Email
Share
Comment
Telecommunications operators Meo (Altice Portugal), NOS, Nowo and Vodafone Portugal are offering free calls to Ukraine, a country that was the target of an invasion by Russia last week.
On Friday night, Meo informed customers that, "to facilitate communications and bring families closer together", it is "temporarily offering all its customers international mobile calls to Ukraine and making the Ukrainian TV 'pack' available free of charge".
This measure, according to the Altice Portugal operator, has been in force since February 26th to March 15th, "and may be extended depending on the situation's evolution".
On Saturday, Nowo said its customers can make calls to Ukraine for free.
Close
Subscribe to newsletter
Subscribe to our newsletter and have the news in your email every day
Subscribe
Thank you very much for your registration.
"In view of current events, Nowo has decided to offer international calls to Ukraine in order to help all those who need to get in touch with their family and friends who are currently in this country", said the operator, in a statement, highlighting that the conditions, also in force from February 26th to March 15th, "may be extended" depending on the "evolution of the situation".
Contacted by Lusa, Vodafone said that, "following the events in Ukraine", it decided, "from last Friday, February 25th, at 18:00, for prepaid, and on the 26th for postpaid, not to tax international communications originating in Portugal and ending in Ukraine", as well as "not taxing communications carried out in 'roaming' in Ukraine".
These measures are in force "until March 15th", says Vodafone Portugal.
An official NOS source told Lusa that "calls and SMS to Ukraine will not be charged".
Russia launched a military offensive in Ukraine early Thursday morning, with ground forces and bombing of targets in several cities, which has already killed more than 350 civilians, including children, according to Kiev. The UN reported more than 100,000 displaced people and almost 500,000 refugees in Poland, Hungary, Moldova and Romania.
Russian President Vladimir Putin said that the "special military operation" in Ukraine aims to demilitarize the neighboring country and that it was the only way for Russia to defend itself, with the Kremlin specifying that the offensive will last as long as necessary.
The attack was condemned by most of the international community and the European Union and the United States, among others, responded by sending weapons and ammunition to Ukraine and strengthening sanctions to further isolate Moscow.

Photo¬†EPA/Joedson Alves
Brazil "will remain neutral" and will not "take sides" on the Russian invasion of Ukraine, said Brazilian President Jair Bolsonaro on Sunday, indicating that he spoke for more than two hours with Russian President Vladimir Putin.
"We will not take sides, we will remain neutral and help according to our possibilities to find a solution. We want peace, but we do not want to bring consequences here", said Bolsonaro, also remembering that Brazil "is very dependent" on Russian fertilizers.
"I spoke earlier with President Putin, more than two hours of conversation, we talked about many things (...) Of course he said something about Ukraine, which I keep to myself, without going into details as you would like", said Bolsonaro at a press conference in Guaruj√°, state of S√£o Paulo.
On Thursday, Bolsonaro denied vice-president Hamilton Mour√£o, who had said that "Brazil does not agree with the invasion of Ukrainian territory".
Jair Bolsonaro was with Vladimir Putin two weeks ago, during a visit to Russia.
After the meeting, the Brazilian head of state assured that Putin wants "peace" and that Brazil is in solidarity with any country that seeks to resolve conflicts peacefully.
The trip drew criticism for Bolsonaro from the United States of America.
Russia launched a military offensive in Ukraine early Thursday morning, with ground forces and bombing of targets in several cities, which has already killed around 200 civilians, including children, according to Kiev. The UN reported nearly 370,000 people displaced to Poland, Hungary, Moldova and Romania.
Russian President Vladimir Putin said that the "special military operation" in Ukraine aims to demilitarize the neighboring country and that it was the only way for Russia to defend itself, with the Kremlin specifying that the offensive will last as long as necessary.
The attack was condemned by most of the international community and the European Union and the United States, among others, responded by sending weapons and ammunition to Ukraine and strengthening sanctions to further isolate Moscow.

Photo¬†EPA/STANISLAV KOZLIUK
Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky decided to release prisoners with military experience to join the fight against Russian forces, who launched an offensive against Ukraine five days ago.
"Anyone who can join the fight against the occupiers should do so. The decision was not easy, from a moral point of view, but useful from the point of view of our protection", declared the Ukrainian President.
"Under martial law, participants in hostilities, Ukrainians with combat experience, will be released and will be able to atone for their guilt in the most dangerous places of war. The key now is defense," Zelensky said.
"When I ran for President, I said that each of us is President, because we are all responsible for our State. For our beautiful Ukraine. And now, each of us has become a fighter", he stressed earlier in a video message before the start of Russian-Ukrainian negotiations on the Ukrainian border with Belarus.
Zelensky, speaking in Ukrainian, stated that in just four days of the Russian invasion, sixteen Ukrainian children were killed in Russian shelling and another 45 were injured.
Russia launched a military offensive in Ukraine early Thursday morning, with ground forces and bombing of targets in several cities, which has already killed around 200 civilians, including children, according to Kiev. The UN reported nearly 370,000 people displaced to Poland, Hungary, Moldova and Romania.
Russian President Vladimir Putin said that the "special military operation" in Ukraine aims to demilitarize the neighboring country and that it was the only way for Russia to defend itself, with the Kremlin specifying that the offensive will last as long as necessary.
The attack was condemned by most of the international community and the European Union and the United States, among others, responded by sending weapons and ammunition to Ukraine and strengthening sanctions to further isolate Moscow.

The War
World
Embassy urges Russian citizens to report threats to Portuguese authorities
Lusa Agency
Feb 28, 2022
23:12
0
Comments
Shutterstock
The Russian embassy today urged its citizens in Portugal to contact the Portuguese authorities and the consular service in case of threats to their security, following the invasion of Russian forces into Ukraine.
"In the event of threats to your security, you must immediately contact the Portuguese authorities (...), as well as inform the embassy's consular service about the incident via the emergency number, whose employees will provide assistance within the scope of their competence", can be read in a note published on the official website of the Russian Embassy in Portugal.
In a message encouraging the reporting of cases of "provocations, threats and prejudices" but also for Russian citizens in Portugal "not to give in to provocations", the embassy recalled that "in the territory of a foreign state" they are "under the jurisdiction of the host country".
Russia launched a military offensive in Ukraine early Thursday morning, with ground forces and bombing of targets in several cities, which has already killed more than 350 civilians, including children, according to Kiev. The UN reported more than 100,000 displaced people and almost 500,000 refugees in Poland, Hungary, Moldova and Romania.
Russian President Vladimir Putin said that the "special military operation" in Ukraine aims to demilitarize the neighboring country and that it was the only way for Russia to defend itself, with the Kremlin specifying that the offensive will last as long as necessary.
In the note, the Russian embassy in Portugal points out that a special operation is underway to protect the lives of inhabitants of the self-proclaimed people's republics of Donetsk and Luhansk, recognized by Moscow.
And he denounces ‚Äúunprecedented pressure‚Äù that is being ‚Äúexerted on Russian-speaking citizens‚Äù.
"These unacceptable actions are registered both by radical Ukrainian nationalists, who have successfully infiltrated the ranks of peace protesters, and by local citizens who are victims of the information war being waged against Russia due to its inability to isolate obvious falsifications of information flow aimed at discrediting the Russian military," he highlighted.
"Now, more than ever, the cohesion of our diaspora is important, the consolidation of efforts to defend our legitimate rights and interests", he adds.
The attack is being condemned by most of the international community and the European Union and the United States, among others, responded by sending weapons and ammunition to Ukraine and strengthening sanctions to further isolate Moscow.
In Portugal, demonstrations against Russia's invasion of Ukraine have multiplied, with events in various locations across the country, including in front of the Russian embassy, ‚Äã‚Äãin Lisbon, or next to the Russian consulate in Porto.

translated_text:
The War
World
Zelensky defends "no-fly zone", but West rules out this scenario
Lusa Agency
Feb 28, 2022
19:33
0
Comments
Photo EPA
Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky today asked the United States and NATO to impose a "no-fly zone" in Ukraine to contain bombing by Russian forces, a scenario that the West rules out.
The North American news website Axios published a statement from the Ukrainian head of state, where he explains that if the West decrees a no-fly zone over "significant parts" of Ukrainian territory, the country will be able to defeat Russia "with much less blood".
"Ukraine can defeat the aggressor. We are showing this to the world. But our allies must also do their part", stressed Volodymyr Zelensky.
However, both Washington and NATO have ruled out sending troops and combat aircraft to Ukraine, a country that is not part of the Atlantic Alliance.
White House spokeswoman Jen Psaki said in statements to MSNBC that imposing a no-fly zone in Ukraine "would mean that the US military would shoot down Russian planes", something that President Joe Biden "does not want to do".
Also speaking to the same media outlet, NATO Secretary General Jens Stoltenberg assured that the Atlantic Alliance has no intention "of entering Ukraine by land or air".
Still speaking to Axios, Volodymyr Zelensky praised the sanctions announced by the United States and the European Union to isolate the Russian central bank and exclude several Russian financial institutions from the international SWIFT system, adding that they "are going in the right direction".
Russia launched a military offensive in Ukraine early Thursday morning, with ground forces and bombing of targets in several cities, which has already killed more than 350 civilians, including children, according to Kiev. The UN reported more than 100,000 displaced people and almost 500,000 refugees in Poland, Hungary, Moldova and Romania.
Russian President Vladimir Putin said that the "special military operation" in Ukraine aims to demilitarize the neighboring country and that it was the only way for Russia to defend itself, with the Kremlin specifying that the offensive will last as long as necessary.
The attack was condemned by most of the international community and the European Union and the United States, among others, responded by sending weapons and ammunition to Ukraine and strengthening sanctions to further isolate Moscow.

The Portuguese Basketball Federation (FPB) today expressed its "solidarity" with the Ukrainian people, making its resources available to help the community in the eastern country with links to the sport in Portugal.
"In the difficult time that all Ukrainians are facing, the FPB expresses in the people of Valentin Melnychuk, former national coach, Andrii Melnychuk, coach of CAR de Ponte de Sor, and Vlad Voytso, player of the national team, its solidarity with all Ukrainians and willingness to use its resources to support the Ukrainian basketball community in this difficult period of their lives", he informed.
In a short note, the FPB recalls the "active collaboration of citizens of Ukrainian origin" in Portuguese basketball, as well as the "skills and capabilities" that they put "at the service of the sport".
Russia launched a military offensive in Ukraine early Thursday morning, with ground forces and bombing of targets in several cities, which has already caused at least 198 deaths, including civilians, and more than 1,100 injuries, on Ukrainian territory, according to Kiev. The UN reported 150,000 displaced people to Poland, Hungary, Moldova and Romania.
Russian President Vladimir Putin said that the "special military operation" in Ukraine aims to demilitarize the neighboring country and that it was the only way for Russia to defend itself, with the Kremlin specifying that the offensive will last as long as necessary.
The attack was condemned by most of the international community and led to emergency meetings of several governments, including the Portuguese, and the North Atlantic Treaty Organization (NATO), EU and UN Security Council, with mass sanctions being approved against Russia.

London-based media oligarch asks Putin to end war
Lusa Agency
Feb 28, 2022
23:20
0
Comments
Photo EPA
Russian-born, UK-based oligarch and media mogul Evgeny Lebedev used the pages of one of his newspapers to call on Russian President Vladimir Putin to end the invasion of Ukraine.
Today's edition of the Evening Standard newspaper in London publishes a statement by Lebedev on the front page.
"President Putin, please stop this war", reads the front page of the newspaper, which features an image of doctors fighting to save a six-year-old girl who was the victim of a bombing in Mariupol, the second largest city in Donbass (eastern Ukraine).
"As a Russian citizen, I ask you to stop the Russians from killing their Ukrainian brothers and sisters. As a British citizen, I ask you to save Europe from war," wrote Lebedev, in the text published in the newspaper.
Lebedev, whose father, fellow oligarch Alexander Lebedev, worked for the secret services of the former Soviet Union (KGB), became a member of the House of Lords (upper house of the United Kingdom Parliament) in 2020.
Oligarchs Oleg Deripaska, an ally of Putin, and Mikhail Fridman, who is on the US sanctions list, also called for an end to the violence.
Meanwhile, Russian businessman Roman Abramovich accepted a request from Ukraine to help mediate peace talks with Russia, a spokeswoman for the owner of English football club Chelsea said today.
"I can confirm that Roman Abramovich was contacted by the Ukrainian side for support in reaching a peaceful resolution, and that he has been trying to help since then," said the spokeswoman, quoted by Al Jazeera television.
The spokeswoman declined to comment on the war between Russia and Ukraine, as well as Abramovich's involvement, "considering what is at stake."
Abramovich's involvement in mediating the conflict was initially reported by the British newspaper Jewish News, which said that Ukrainian authorities had contacted the Russian businessman through his Jewish contacts in Ukraine.
Russia launched a military offensive in Ukraine early Thursday morning, with ground forces and bombing of targets in several cities, which has already killed more than 350 civilians, including children, according to Kiev.
The UN reported more than 100,000 displaced people and almost 500,000 refugees in Poland, Hungary, Moldova and Romania.
Russian President Vladimir Putin said that the "special military operation" in Ukraine aims to demilitarize the neighboring country and that it was the only way for Russia to defend itself, with the Kremlin specifying that the offensive will last as long as necessary.
The attack was condemned by most of the international community and the European Union and the United States, among others, responded by sending weapons and ammunition to Ukraine and strengthening sanctions to further isolate Moscow.

The State Budget for 2022 [OE2022] will have to reflect from now on, particularly in the fiscal area, the necessary adjustments to respond to the rise in raw material prices, the increase in energy costs, particularly fuel, and inflation", says the CNCP in a statement.

"The impact of this war on Portuguese companies and the economy will be direct, mainly due to the increase in energy costs and agricultural products, which will have an impact on inflation", and will also be indirect, "since the entire European economy will be affected", they add.
The CNCP is a platform that brings together the Confederation of Farmers of Portugal (CAP), the Confederation of Commerce and Services of Portugal (CCP), the Business Confederation of Portugal (CIP), the Portuguese Confederation of Construction and Real Estate (CPCI) and the Confederation of Tourism of Portugal (CTP).
Russia launched a military offensive in Ukraine early Thursday morning, with ground forces and bombing of targets in several cities, which has already killed more than 350 civilians, including children, according to Kiev. Russian President Vladimir Putin said that the "special military operation" in Ukraine aims to demilitarize the neighboring country and that it was the only way for Russia to defend itself, with the Kremlin specifying that the offensive will last as long as necessary.
The attack was condemned by most of the international community and the European Union and the United States, among others, responded by sending weapons and ammunition to Ukraine and strengthening sanctions to further isolate Moscow.

translated_text:
The War
World
Chinese social networks delete thousands of posts about conflict
Lusa Agency
Feb 28, 2022
07:41
0
Comments
Photo¬†A9 STUDIO/Shutterstock.com
Chinese social networks Weibo, equivalent to Twitter, and Douyin, a version of the Tiktok video application, deleted, respectively, 1,400 and 6,400 publications with "offensive content" about the conflict in Ukraine, China Daily reported today.
Since Friday, Weibo has targeted 262 users with punishments ranging from a seven-day suspension to permanent account deletion.
The service will "investigate and deal" with "inappropriate and hostile messages" that "promote hatred and oppose gender equality", according to an official statement released this weekend, in a reference to "vulgar publications" about "beautiful Ukrainian women".
The social network also explained that messages that "glorify and encourage" war are "a violation" of the rules of use.
Wechat, the most used messaging application in China, called on users on Saturday to maintain "an objective and rational attitude" in order to create a "clean cyberspace".
Although messages supporting both sides of the war in Ukraine can be found on Chinese networks, there are cases of censorship against some publications critical of the actions of Russia, a country with which China maintains close relations.
On Saturday, five historians from prestigious Chinese universities, such as Tsinghua, published an article criticizing "the large-scale invasion of Ukraine" and declared their "firm opposition" to the Russian offensive, which has since been deleted from WeChat, although it can still be found on other social networks in the country.
International services such as Google, Facebook, Twitter, YouTube and WhatsApp remain censored and inaccessible in China.
China, which has so far avoided condemning Russia's actions and using the word "invasion", maintains a difficult balance during the Ukrainian crisis, in which it tries to combine support for sovereignty, the territorial integrity of all states and a dialogue solution that responds to Russia's security demands.
Beijing has also expressed opposition to sanctions against Russia. "Unilateral sanctions that have no basis in international law (...) will not solve problems, but will create new problems," explained Foreign Minister Wang Yi over the weekend.
Russia launched a military offensive in Ukraine early Thursday morning, with ground forces and bombing of targets in several cities, which has already killed at least 352 civilians, including children, according to Kiev. The UN reported nearly 370,000 people displaced to Poland, Hungary, Moldova and Romania.
Russian President Vladimir Putin said that the "special military operation" in Ukraine aims to demilitarize the neighboring country and that it was the only way for Russia to defend itself, with the Kremlin specifying that the offensive will last as long as necessary.
The attack was condemned by most of the international community and the European Union and the United States, among others, responded by sending weapons and ammunition to Ukraine and strengthening sanctions to further isolate Moscow.

translated_text:
The War
World
Ireland admits expelling Russian diplomats, but wants channels with Moscow
Lusa Agency
Feb 28, 2022
13:04
0
Comments
Photo Irish Department of Foreign Affairs
The Irish Government assured today that it does not rule out the expulsion of Russian diplomats, but recognized the need to maintain "open channels" of communication with its ambassador to deal with humanitarian issues, after the invasion of Ukraine.
Irish Foreign Minister Simon Coveney admitted the possibility of sending Russian diplomats out, in response to a wave of protests from citizens and most opposition parties, who are calling for the expulsion of the Russian ambassador in Dublin, Yury Filatov.
"I completely understand your feelings and discontent, but I am Foreign Minister and I also have to think about the interests of Irish citizens in Russia and Ukraine," said Coveney.
The head of Irish diplomacy insisted that "some kind of diplomatic channel" and model of communication with Moscow must be maintained to protect the "humanitarian interests of these people", regardless of "what happens in the coming days or weeks".
"That doesn't mean we won't expel diplomats and, in fact, perhaps we will... But I don't think it's smart to expel the Russian ambassador and lose Russia's presence in Ireland which allows us to have a direct line to Moscow," explained Coveney.
The minister also said that his country intends to act in line with other European Union partners, who are meeting today to study a coordinated response to the issue of Russian diplomats.
Russia launched a military offensive in Ukraine last Thursday, with ground forces and bombing of targets in several cities, which has already caused around 200 deaths, including civilians, and more than 1,100 injuries, on Ukrainian territory, according to Kiev. The UN reported nearly 370,000 people displaced to Poland, Hungary, Moldova and Romania.
The operation was condemned by most of the international community and led to emergency meetings between several governments, including the Portuguese, and the North Atlantic Treaty Organization (NATO), the EU and the UN Security Council, with mass sanctions being approved against Russia.

Ukraine: International footballers' union calls for suspension of Russian federation
Share

Ukraine was militarily invaded by Russia
Photography:¬†AFP
Share
on Facebook
Writing with Lusa
28¬†February¬†2022¬†at¬†16:55
Union expresses its "disagreement" with the measures announced on Sunday by FIFA, which oblige Russian teams to play on a neutral field, without spectators and without anthem, and under the name of their national federation, and not the country
The International Union of Professional Footballers (FIFPro) today called for the suspension of the Russian Football Union (RFU), due to the military offensive in Ukraine, which would prevent the country's teams and selections from competing in official matches.
Related
International.
Days after facing Braga, Sheriff's coach joined the Ukrainian army
International.
Ukraine: Zinchenko demands total exclusion of Russia from international sport
"We call for the suspension of the RFU with immediate effect, until peace, security and the rule of law are restored", says FIFPro in a statement, alluding to the country's most recent actions, which on Thursday launched a military offensive in Ukraine.
The union expresses its "disagreement" with the measures announced on Sunday by FIFA, which oblige Russian teams to play on a neutral field, without spectators and without anthem, and under the name of their national federation, not the country, and stands completely alongside the players and clubs.
Also read
FC Porto
Galeno came on and was replaced against Gil Vicente: S√©rgio Concei√ß√£o's explanation
Statements by S√©rgio Concei√ß√£o, coach of FC Porto, after the 1-1 draw with Gil Vicente, in the 24th round of the Bwin League.
"FIFPro supports all players and entities in world football who choose not to play against Russian teams, at this distressing time", says the statement, expressing full solidarity with the players from Poland, Sweden and the Czech Republic, involved in the qualifying play-offs for the 2022 World Cup, together with Russia, and who have already guaranteed that they do not want to play, even on a neutral ground.
The footballers' union considers that the "united" response of the world's democracies to Russian aggression "showed unity in defending human dignity and the rule of law, and understands that football "has its own responsibility in the matter.
Also read
International

Russian tycoon did not comment on whether or not he supported the war in Ukraine, something that the former English full-back did not fail to notice
On Sunday, FIFA canceled games in Russia, imposing conditions for them to be played outside the country, days after UEFA transferred the Champions League final, scheduled for May 28, in Saint Petersburg, to Paris.
Several sports federations and competition organizing bodies have canceled or transferred events that were supposed to take place on Russian soil, responding to the appeal launched by the International Olympic Committee.
Russia launched a military offensive in Ukraine early Thursday morning, with ground forces and bombing of targets in several cities, which has already killed more than 350 civilians, including children, according to Kiev. The UN reported more than 100,000 displaced people and almost 500,000 refugees in Poland, Hungary, Moldova and Romania.
Russian President Vladimir Putin said that the "special military operation" in Ukraine aims to demilitarize the neighboring country and that it was the only way for Russia to defend itself, with the Kremlin specifying that the offensive will last as long as necessary.

The War

Around 22 thousand people crossed the border from Poland to Ukraine
Lusa Agency
Feb 27, 2022
23:47
0
Comments
Around 22,000 people have crossed the border from Poland to Ukraine since the Russian invasion on Thursday, the Polish border guard said today.
At the Medyka border checkpoint, in southeastern Poland, many people waited in line today to cross into Ukraine.
According to the Associated Press news agency, Ukrainians are returning to their country to defend it from the Russian offensive or to rescue their children.
On the other hand, according to the Polish border guard, more than 150,000 people have fled Ukraine and entered Poland since the conflict began.
At least one million Ukrainians work or study in Poland. Women, who work as nannies or companions for the elderly in several European Union countries, often leave their children in Ukraine in the care of grandparents or other relatives.
The Czech Republic, which borders Poland, plans to financially support Ukrainian families living in the country whose men decide to return to Ukraine to fight.
There are around 200,000 Ukrainian workers in the Czech Republic, the majority of whom are men. Rail transport is now free for Ukrainians wishing to reach Poland or Slovakia to enter Ukraine.
Russia launched a military offensive in Ukraine early Thursday morning, with ground forces and bombing of targets in several cities, which has already killed around 200 civilians, including children, according to Kiev. The UN reported nearly 370,000 people displaced to Poland, Hungary, Moldova and Romania.
Russian President Vladimir Putin said that the "special military operation" in Ukraine aims to demilitarize the neighboring country and that it was the only way for Russia to defend itself, with the Kremlin specifying that the offensive will last as long as necessary.
The attack was condemned by most of the international community, and the European Union and the United States, among others, responded by sending weapons and ammunition to Ukraine and strengthening sanctions to further isolate Moscow.

Ukraine withdraws from the Fencing World Cup because it does not want to face Russia (and the Russians applauded the¬†position)
The Ukrainian team refused to face a Russian team in the round of 16 of the World Cup and was applauded even by their opponents. Leader of the Fencing Federation, who is very close to Putin, was also targeted.
Bruno Roseiro
Text
Feb 28, 2022, 00:25
Offer article

‚ñ≤
Ukrainian team displayed a poster calling for an end to the war before leaving the Cairo International Stadium
You have free access to all Observador articles by being our subscriber.
A
European futsal semi-final between Russia and Ukraine
, at the beginning of February and when there was only talk about the climate of tension that existed between the two countries, it generated particular discomfort in UEFA despite everything going well at the Ziggo Dome, in Amsterdam. Reason? Since 2007,
There was no confrontation between the two countries
in competitions organized by UEFA. And in football, for example, they have not met since the qualifying rounds for the 2002 European Championship. Furthermore: as The Guardian recalled at that time, since the invasion of Crimea which led to there being always different pots in the draws, there has only been one match and that was at the women's futsal European Championship, in 2019.
A lot of tension, reinforced security, an alleged increase in premiums. After all, it was just a game. And Russia beat Ukraine
This is how it is in the sports under the auspices of UEFA, it is not always like this in other sports. And just this month some examples emerged of how the
sport can build the bridges that others destroy,
as seen on the acrobatic skiing podium with the symbolic embrace between the Ukrainian Oleksandr Abramenko and the Russian Ilya Burov, winners of the silver and bronze medals in acrobatic skiing at the Beijing Olympic Games (and who had already recorded the same moment four years earlier in PyeongChang, South Korea) and as seen in the new and growing world of e-sports, where Russians and Ukrainians compete on the same teams.
However, increasingly,
everything has its time and its context.
And a Ukrainian group decided to take a position of strength in the face of what it considers to be a crossing of all red lines.
PUB
‚Ä¢ CONTINUE READING BELOW
ŸÅŸÄŸäŸÄÿØŸäŸÄŸà ŸäŸÄÿ≠ŸÄŸÖŸÄŸÑ ŸÖŸÄÿπŸÄÿßŸÜŸÄŸä ŸÉŸÄÿ´ŸÄŸäŸÄÿ±ÿ© ŸÖŸÄŸÜ ÿßŸÑŸÄŸÇŸÄÿßŸáŸÄÿ±ÿ©.. ŸÑŸÄÿ≠ŸÄÿ∏ŸÄÿ© ÿßŸÜŸÄÿ≥ŸÄÿ≠ŸÄÿßÿ® ŸÖŸÄŸÜŸÄÿ™ŸÄÿÆŸÄÿ® ÿ£ŸàŸÉŸÄÿ±ÿßŸÜŸÄŸäŸÄÿß ŸÖŸÄŸÜ ŸÖŸÄŸàÿßÿ¨ŸÄŸáŸÄÿ© ÿ±Ÿàÿ≥ŸÄŸäŸÄÿß ŸÅŸÄŸä ŸÉŸÄÿ£ÿ≥ ÿßŸÑŸÄÿπŸÄÿßŸÑŸÄŸÖ ŸÑŸÄÿ≥ŸÄŸÑÿßÿ≠ ÿßŸÑŸÄÿ¥ŸÄŸäŸÄÿ¥ ŸÅŸÄŸä ŸÖŸÄÿµŸÄÿ± Ÿàÿ≥ŸÄÿ∑ ÿ™ŸÄÿ≥ŸÄŸÇŸÄŸäŸÄŸÅ Ÿàÿ™ŸÄÿ≠ŸÄŸäŸÄÿ© ÿ¨ŸÄŸÖŸÄŸäŸÄÿπ ÿßŸÑŸÄÿ≠ŸÄÿ∂ŸÄŸàÿ± ŸÅŸÄŸä ÿµŸÄÿßŸÑŸÄÿ© ÿßÿ≥ŸÄÿ™ŸÄÿßÿØ ÿßŸÑŸÄŸÇŸÄÿßŸáŸÄÿ±ÿ© ?????????‚ù§Ô∏è?????????
ÿßŸÑŸÖÿµÿØÿ±: ŸÖŸàŸÇÿπ ÿ™ÿ™ŸàŸäÿ¨
pic.twitter.com/MFsQRFncp3
‚Äî Egypt Sports Network (@ESNEgypt_)
February 27, 2022
This Sunday, when the fencing World Cup being held at the International Stadium in Cairo, Egypt, the team foil event reached the round of 16, Ukraine decided to withdraw from the competition because it did not want to face the Russian team, explaining the reason for the gesture and leaving the venue with a small sign that said
‚ÄúStop the war, save Ukraine.‚Äù
And the moment had even more impact because you can see in the video that two of the Russian athletes still applaud the action for a few seconds.
While HK athletes may feel they cannot post what they really feel about Russia‚Äôs invasion of Ukraine, fencing champion Cheung Ka Long did post this on his Instagram story earlier today:
pic.twitter.com/PT0gUhFU23
‚ÄîBrandon (@b3108)
February 27, 2022
The Ukrainian team left the Cairo International Stadium under
a big ovation
of those present, in what was the great moment of a competition that under normal conditions would have been just a Fencing World Cup but which quickly became viral with the countless demonstrations of support for the country and calls for an end to the war that have spread across several countries in various modalities. "This is our protest against the war. We cannot compete against them while our families are in danger, while everyone in our country is in danger", the team later explained in a statement.
The Ukrainian team refuses to face the Russian team in a tournament in Cairo, valid for the world fencing circuit.
The sport's International Federation is commanded by a billionaire from Putin's oligarchy.
pic.twitter.com/2E5JK5Kl4S
‚Äî Dem√©trio Vecchioli (@Olhar_Olimpico)
February 27, 2022
Another point that was not overlooked was the fact that the International Fencing Federation is led by the Russian Alisher Usmanov, a tycoon who made his fortune with the collapse of the Soviet Union and who is someone
very close to the President of the Russian Federation, Vladimir Putin,
since the 90s. Usmanov is also a shareholder in Arsenal, which has led to many questions in recent days among other Premier League clubs that are asking for a position to be taken, as happened with Roman Abramovich at Chelsea.

original_text:
A
edi√ß√£o de hoje do jornal Evening Standard, de Londres, publica na primeira p√°gina uma declara√ß√£o de Lebedev.
"Presidente Putin, por favor, pare esta guerra", l√™-se na primeira p√°gina do jornal, que tem em destaque uma imagem de m√©dicos que lutam para salvar uma menina de seis anos v√≠tima de um bombardeamento em Mariupol, a segunda maior cidade do Donbass (leste da Ucr√¢nia).
"Como cidad√£o russo, pe√ßo-lhe que impe√ßa os russos de matar os seus irm√£os e irm√£s ucranianos. Como cidad√£o brit√¢nico, pe√ßo-lhe que salve a Europa da guerra", escreveu Lebedev, no texto publicado no jornal.
Lebedev, cujo pai, o tamb√©m oligarca Alexander Lebedev, chegou a trabalhar para os servi√ßos secretos da antiga Uni√£o Sovi√©tica (KGB), tornou-se membro da C√¢mara dos Lordes (c√¢mara alta do Parlamento do Reino Unido) em 2020.
Tamb√©m os oligarcas Oleg Deripaska, aliado de Putin, e Mikhail Fridman, que est√° na lista de san√ß√µes dos Estados Unidos, pediram o fim da viol√™ncia.

translated_text:
A
Today's edition of the Evening Standard newspaper in London publishes a statement by Lebedev on the front page.
"President Putin, please stop this war", reads the front page of the newspaper, which features an image of doctors fighting to save a six-year-old girl who was the victim of a bombing in Mariupol, the second largest city in Donbass (eastern Ukraine).
"As a Russian citizen, I ask you to stop the Russians from killing their Ukrainian brothers and sisters. As a British citizen, I ask you to save Europe from war," wrote Lebedev, in the text published in the newspaper.
Lebedev, whose father, fellow oligarch Alexander Lebedev, worked for the secret services of the former Soviet Union (KGB), became a member of the House of Lords (upper house of the United Kingdom Parliament) in 2020.
Oligarchs Oleg Deripaska, an ally of Putin, and Mikhail Fridman, who is on the US sanctions list, also called for an end to the violence.
Meanwhile, Russian businessman Roman Abramovich accepted a request from Ukraine to help mediate peace talks with Russia, a spokeswoman for the owner of English football club Chelsea said today.
"I can confirm that Roman Abramovich was contacted by the Ukrainian side for support in reaching a peaceful resolution, and that he has been trying to help since then," said the spokeswoman, quoted by Al Jazeera television.
The spokeswoman declined to comment on the war between Russia and Ukraine, as well as Abramovich's involvement, "considering what is at stake."
Abramovich's involvement in mediating the conflict was initially reported by the British newspaper Jewish News, which said that Ukrainian authorities had contacted the Russian businessman through his Jewish contacts in Ukraine.
Russia launched a military offensive in Ukraine early Thursday morning, with ground forces and bombing of targets in several cities, which has already killed more than 350 civilians, including children, according to Kiev.
The UN reported more than 100,000 displaced people and almost 500,000 refugees in Poland, Hungary, Moldova and Romania.
Russian President Vladimir Putin said that the "special military operation" in Ukraine aims to demilitarize the neighboring country and that it was the only way for Russia to defend itself, with the Kremlin specifying that the offensive will last as long as necessary.
The attack was condemned by most of the international community and the European Union and the United States, among others, responded by sending weapons and ammunition to Ukraine and strengthening sanctions to further isolate Moscow.

translated_text:
The War
Country
Portuguese operators offer free calls to Ukraine
Lusa Agency
Feb 28, 2022
20:52
0
Comments
Shutterstock photo
Telecommunications operators Meo (Altice Portugal), NOS, Nowo and Vodafone Portugal are offering free calls to Ukraine, a country that was the target of an invasion by Russia last week.
On Friday night, Meo informed customers that, "to facilitate communications and bring families closer together", it is "temporarily offering all its customers international mobile calls to Ukraine and making the Ukrainian TV 'pack' available free of charge".
This measure, according to the Altice Portugal operator, has been in force since February 26th to March 15th, "and may be extended depending on the situation's evolution".
On Saturday, Nowo said its customers can make calls to Ukraine for free.
"In view of current events, Nowo has decided to offer international calls to Ukraine in order to help all those who need to get in touch with their family and friends who are currently in this country", said the operator, in a statement, highlighting that the conditions, also in force from February 26th to March 15th, "may be extended" depending on the "evolution of the situation".
Contacted by Lusa, Vodafone said that, "following the events in Ukraine", it decided, "from last Friday, February 25th, at 18:00, for prepaid, and on the 26th for postpaid, not to tax international communications originating in Portugal and ending in Ukraine", as well as "not taxing communications carried out in 'roaming' in Ukraine".
These measures are in force "until March 15th", says Vodafone Portugal.
An official NOS source told Lusa that "calls and SMS to Ukraine will not be charged".
Russia launched a military offensive in Ukraine early Thursday morning, with ground forces and bombing of targets in several cities, which has already killed more than 350 civilians, including children, according to Kiev. The UN reported more than 100,000 displaced people and almost 500,000 refugees in Poland, Hungary, Moldova and Romania.
Russian President Vladimir Putin said that the "special military operation" in Ukraine aims to demilitarize the neighboring country and that it was the only way for Russia to defend itself, with the Kremlin specifying that the offensive will last as long as necessary.
The attack was condemned by most of the international community and the European Union and the United States, among others, responded by sending weapons and ammunition to Ukraine and strengthening sanctions to further isolate Moscow.

translated_text:
The War
Country
Bosses ask for measures in OE2022 to mitigate impact on companies
Lusa Agency
Feb 28, 2022
18:48
0
Comments
The National Council of Employers' Confederations (CNCP) today condemned Russia's invasion of Ukraine and argued that the State Budget for 2022 should provide for fiscal "adjustments" to respond to the impact that the conflict will have on companies.
"The State Budget for 2022 [OE2022] will have to reflect from now on, particularly in the fiscal area, the necessary adjustments to respond to the rise in raw material prices, the increase in energy costs, particularly fuel, and inflation", states the CNCP in a statement.
In a document "vehemently" condemning Russia's invasion of Ukraine, the employers' confederations state that "companies will be affected by this entire situation, including those trading and operating in Russia and Ukraine", and ask for "support measures to mitigate the impact on these economic operators".
The CNCP also says that employer confederations are available to cooperate with the Institute of Employment and Professional Training (IEFP) for the professional integration of refugees from Ukraine.
"Aware of the serious humanitarian crisis that this conflict will also produce, the CNCP reiterates its total availability, in conjunction with the IEFP, for the professional integration of refugees that Portugal may welcome in the coming months", the statement reads.
The employers' confederations also say that the "inevitable economic impact" that the conflict will have on Portugal, especially in the energy and food domain, will be "further aggravated by the dramatic drought situation that is plaguing the country".
"The impact of this war on Portuguese companies and the economy will be direct, mainly due to the increase in energy costs and agricultural products, which will have an impact on inflation", and will also be indirect, "since the entire European economy will be affected", they add.
The CNCP is a platform that brings together the Confederation of Farmers of Portugal (CAP), the Confederation of Commerce and Services of Portugal (CCP), the Business Confederation of Portugal (CIP), the Portuguese Confederation of Construction and Real Estate (CPCI) and the Confederation of Tourism of Portugal (CTP).
Russia launched a military offensive in Ukraine early Thursday morning, with ground forces and bombing of targets in several cities, which has already killed more than 350 civilians, including children, according to Kiev. The UN reported more than 100,000 displaced people and almost 500,000 refugees in Poland, Hungary, Moldova and Romania.
Russian President Vladimir Putin said that the "special military operation" in Ukraine aims to demilitarize the neighboring country and that it was the only way for Russia to defend itself, with the Kremlin specifying that the offensive will last as long as necessary.
The attack was condemned by most of the international community and the European Union and the United States, among others, responded by sending weapons and ammunition to Ukraine and strengthening sanctions to further isolate Moscow.

translated_text:
The War
World
Seven dead and at least 44 injured in clashes with Russians in Kharkiv
Lusa Agency
Feb 28, 2022
19:23
0
Comments
Photo EPA
Seven people were killed and at least 44 injured in fighting against Russian forces in Kharkiv, eastern Ukraine, according to Ukrainian authorities, who estimate more civilian casualties as bombings of residential areas are assessed.
According to the Associated Press (AP), it was not clear, in this assessment of the last 24 hours, whether all the casualties were civilians.
The state emergency agency stressed that casualties could be higher because damage from Russian forces' shelling of residential areas in Ukraine's second-largest city was still being assessed.
In the early afternoon, the regional governor said that at least 11 people died and hundreds were injured today in a Russian missile attack on residential neighborhoods in Kharkiv.
"Kharkiv. A merciless and senseless attack on a residential neighborhood with missiles! Corpses in the streets," wrote Anton Guerashenko, an advisor to Ukraine's Interior Ministry, on the Telegram messaging service, where he posted videos with images of the attack.
In one of the videos circulating on social media, bodies of the fatal victims and injured could be seen on the streets of the neighborhoods.
In another, lasting 30 seconds, images appeared of around 15 missiles hitting a sector of the city, located in northeastern Ukraine.
This attack occurred while, at the other end of the country, on the Ukrainian-Belarusian border, delegations from Ukraine and Russia were meeting to negotiate for the first time since Russia began its invasion of Ukraine last Thursday.
The Ukrainian and Russian delegations ended the talks they held throughout the day in Belarus, and admitted a new meeting "soon".
"The parties have established a series of priorities and issues that require certain decisions" before a second round of talks, said Mikhail Podoliak, one of the Ukrainian negotiators, cited by the AFP agency.
His Russian counterpart, Vladimir Medinsky, said the new meeting would take place "soon" on the border between Poland and Belarus.
Russia launched a military offensive in Ukraine early Thursday morning, with ground forces and bombing of targets in several cities, which has already killed more than 350 civilians, including children, according to Kiev. The UN reported more than 100,000 displaced people and almost 500,000 refugees in Poland, Hungary, Moldova and Romania.
Russian President Vladimir Putin said that the "special military operation" in Ukraine aims to demilitarize the neighboring country and that it was the only way for Russia to defend itself, with the Kremlin specifying that the offensive will last as long as necessary.
The attack was condemned by most of the international community and the European Union and the United States, among others, responded by sending weapons and ammunition to Ukraine and strengthening sanctions to further isolate Moscow.

The Russian club would face Leipzig in the round of 16 of the competition.
Spartak Moscow has already reacted to its exclusion from the Europa League, confirmed after FIFA and UEFA announced the suspension of Russian teams and selections from continental competitions.
Related

International.

"The decision to exclude our team from the Europa League is disturbing. We believe that sport, even in the most difficult times, should aim to build bridges, not destroy them", the Russian club began by writing on social media.
"We will focus on national competitions and hope for a quick achievement of the peace we all need", he concluded.
Also read
International
Szczesny: "I refuse to be on a pitch, wear my country's colors and listen to the Russian anthem"
Poland's Guardian spoke after his team had already officially announced that they would not be playing in what would be the semi-final to qualify for the next World Cup.
Spartak took the opportunity to wish success to Domenico Tedesco, former coach of the Russian club and currently in charge of Leipzig, a club that Spartak would face in the round of 16 and which will therefore advance directly to the "quarters".
"We want to wish our former coach Domenico Tedesco the best in the Europa League. We hope that our paths will cross again in the future, but under more peaceful conditions", it reads.

International

After the meeting with Braga in the Europa League play-off, Yuriy Vernydub had demonstrated his desire to return to his country and his full availability to help with whatever was necessary.
It should be remembered that Russia launched a military offensive in Ukraine on Thursday morning, with ground forces and bombing of targets in several cities, which has already killed more than 350 civilians, including children, according to Kiev. The UN reported almost 500,000 people displaced to Poland, Hungary, Moldova and Romania.
Russian President Vladimir Putin said that the "special military operation" in Ukraine aims to demilitarize the neighboring country and that it was the only way for Russia to defend itself, with the Kremlin specifying that the offensive will last as long as necessary.
The attack was condemned by most of the international community and the European Union and the United States, among others, responded by sending weapons and ammunition to Ukraine and strengthening sanctions to further isolate Moscow.
