translated_text:
The War
World
Vatican available to help with negotiations
Lusa Agency
Feb 28, 2022
09:55
0
Comments
Photo¬†Drop of Light/Shutterstock.com
The Vatican is willing to help in negotiations between Russia and Ukraine, according to the Secretary of State and head of Vatican diplomacy, Pietro Parolin, in an interview published today in several Italian newspapers.
"The Holy See, which in recent years has constantly, discreetly and with great attention followed events in Ukraine, offering its availability to facilitate dialogue with Russia, is always ready to help the parties to resume this path," said Parolin.
Negotiations between Russia and Ukraine on the Ukrainian-Belarusian border begin this morning, according to sources from both countries cited by Russian and Ukrainian media.
The Vatican's "number two" was "convinced that there is always room for negotiation."
"It is never too late. Because the only reasonable and constructive way to resolve differences is through dialogue, as the Pope never tires of repeating", he stated.
Faced with the danger of the conflict spreading to the rest of Europe, Parolin warned that "it would be a catastrophe of gigantic proportions", adding that, "unfortunately, it is not an eventuality that can be completely ruled out".
For the Vatican, it is necessary to "avoid any escalation, stop the war and negotiate."
"Even the eventual return to a new cold war with two opposing blocs is a truly disturbing scenario," he said.
Pope Francis went to the Russian embassy on Friday, in an unprecedented gesture to express his concern about the conflict and ask "for the fighting to cease and for negotiations to be resumed", explained the Vatican Secretary of State.
On Sunday, during the Angelus prayer, the pontiff stated that "those who wage war forget humanity" because "ordinary people are the real victims, those who pay with their own skin for the follies of war."
He also called for the opening of humanitarian corridors for Ukrainians, "who must be welcomed".
Russia launched a military offensive in Ukraine early Thursday morning, with ground forces and bombing of targets in several cities, which has already killed at least 352 civilians, including children, according to Kiev. The UN reported nearly 370,000 people displaced to Poland, Hungary, Moldova and Romania.
Russian President Vladimir Putin said that the "special military operation" in Ukraine aims to demilitarize the neighboring country and that it was the only way for Russia to defend itself, with the Kremlin specifying that the offensive will last as long as necessary.
The attack was condemned by most of the international community and the European Union and the United States, among others, responded by sending weapons and ammunition to Ukraine and strengthening sanctions to further isolate Moscow.

translated_text:
V
olodymyr Zelensky, the president of Ukraine, signed, this Monday, the formal application for membership of the European Union. The announcement was made through a publication made by the official account of the Ukrainian Parliament on the social network Twitter.
"President Volodymyr Zelensky signed Ukraine's application for membership in the European Union," it reads. "This is a historic moment", the organization also celebrated.
The information was released after, also this Monday, the Ukrainian president asked the European Union to allow Ukraine to immediately become part of the bloc. Something that, according to The Independent, would be done under a "special" procedure, with the aim of helping the country defend itself from the Russian invasion that has been going on for five days.

"Our goal is to be together with all Europeans and, most importantly, to be on an equal footing", said Zelensky regarding this accession, during a video speech, reports The New York Times.
Also on Saturday, the Ukrainian president had said that this was a "crucial moment" to decide on Ukraine's accession to the European Union, following the attack that Russia has carried out on its territory.
This Monday, representatives of the Russian and Ukrainian governments have been meeting on the border with Belarus to discuss the possibility of a ceasefire.

The announcement of these dramatic measures comes at a time when the Russian economy is trying to strengthen its defenses against the sanctions announced by Western countries in reaction to Moscow's invasion of Ukraine, which began last Thursday.
Even today, Canada banned its financial institutions from carrying out "transactions" with the Bank of Russia to prevent it from using international foreign exchange reserves and limit Moscow's ability to finance the war.
"We will continue to work closely to hold Russia accountable for its unjustified invasion of Ukraine," said Canadian Prime Minister Justin Trudeau, who announced via the social network Twitter that the ban came into force "immediately" and that the decision was taken "in coordination" with the other G7 countries (the most industrialized in the world).
Additionally, Canada imposed an asset freeze and a ban on carrying out operations with Russian sovereign investment funds.
The Canadians' decision follows measures announced particularly by the United States and the European Union, which announced the exclusion of certain Russian banks from the Swift international banking payment system and banned all transactions with the Russian Central Bank.
This latest measure aims to neutralize some of the huge foreign currency reserves that Russia has accumulated in recent years, especially from oil revenues.
The sale of foreign currency is one of the main tools used by countries that wish to support their national currency.
However, the ruble fell today against the dollar and the euro at the opening of markets, reaching historic lows.
Western sanctions have already led the Russian Central Bank to increase the interest rate by 10.5 percentage points to 20% in order to contain inflation.
Russia launched a military offensive in Ukraine early Thursday morning, with ground forces and bombing of targets in several cities, which has already killed more than 350 civilians, including children, according to Kiev. The UN reported almost 500 thousand refugees to Poland, Hungary, Moldova and Romania.
Russian President Vladimir Putin said that the "special military operation" in Ukraine aims to demilitarize the neighboring country and that it was the only way for Russia to defend itself, with the Kremlin specifying that the offensive will last as long as necessary.
The attack was condemned by most of the international community and the European Union and the United States, among others, responded by sending weapons and ammunition to Ukraine and strengthening sanctions to further isolate Moscow.

International Football
FIFA and UEFA suspend Russian clubs and teams from all competitions
by Lusa
Want to share this article?
cancel
Reuters
Russian football clubs and teams were suspended this Monday from all competitions, by joint decision of UEFA and FIFA, due to the country's military offensive in Ukraine.
SEE MORE
"Following the initial decisions adopted by the FIFA Council and the UEFA Executive Committee, which provided for the adoption of additional measures, FIFA and UEFA today jointly decided that all Russian teams, whether national teams or clubs, should be suspended from participating in FIFA and UEFA competitions until further notice", reads the statement from the two bodies that govern world and European football.
The exclusion of Russian representations from European and world competitions was decided at the highest level, by the "FIFA Council Bureau and the UEFA Executive Committee, the two highest decision-making bodies of the two institutions in such urgent matters".
"Football is totally united and in total solidarity with the people affected in Ukraine. The two presidents hope that the situation in Ukraine will improve significantly and quickly, so that football can once again be a vector of unity and peace among people", concludes the statement from the structures chaired by Gianni Infantino and Aleksander Ceferin.
This decision comes one day after FIFA canceled football matches in Russia, allowing the country's teams to play on a neutral field, without spectators and without an anthem, and under the name of their national federation and not the country.
"No international competition will be played on the territory of Russia, and 'home' matches must be played on neutral territory and without spectators", FIFA detailed in a statement on Sunday.
At the time, FIFA reported on the dialogue with the Polish federation, Russia's opponent in the qualifying play-offs for the 2022 World Cup, and with its associations from the Czech Republic and Sweden, possible opponents in the knockout stage, stating that it had "taken note of the concerns expressed".
Russia should face Poland in Moscow in one of the semi-finals, with the winner of that match receiving the team that won the game between Sweden and the Czech Republic in the World Cup play-off final, in a match that could once again be on Russian territory.
The game between Russia and Poland is scheduled for March 24th and the final of that play-off, with the winner of Sweden-Czech Republic, on the 29th of the same month.
Previously, the International Olympic Committee (IOC) had asked all international sports federations to cancel or change the venue of any competitions planned for Russian or Belarusian soil, and UEFA had transferred the Champions League final, scheduled for Saint Petersburg, to Paris.
On Thursday, Russia launched a military offensive in Ukraine, with ground forces and bombing of targets in several cities, which has killed more than 350 civilians, including children, according to Kiev. The UN reported more than 100,000 displaced people and almost 500,000 refugees in Poland, Hungary, Moldova and Romania.
Russian President Vladimir Putin said that the "special military operation" in Ukraine aimed to demilitarize the neighboring country and that it was the only way for Russia to defend itself, with the Kremlin stating that the offensive would last as long as necessary.
The attack was condemned by most of the international community and the European Union and the United States, among others, responded by sending weapons and ammunition to Ukraine and strengthening sanctions to further isolate Moscow.
